sentence: After depriving most African Americans and many poor whites in the 1901 constitution, the Alabama Legislative Assembly passed more Jim Crow laws at the beginning of the 20th century to impose segregation in everyday life.

name: alabama
sentence: The new Alabama Constitution of 1901 contained provisions for the registration of voters who effectively deprived a large proportion of the population, including almost all African Americans and Native Americans, and tens of thousands of poor whites, making it difficult to register voters, demanding a tax and literacy test.

name: alabama
sentence: The Constitution of 1901 required racial segregation of public schools.

sentence: In 1903, only 2,980 African-Americans were registered in Alabama, but at least 74,000 were literate.

name: alabama
sentence: Compared to over 181,000 African-Americans who had the right to vote in 1900.

sentence: The State Legislative Assembly passed additional legislation on racial segregation in public institutions in the 1950s: prisons were separated in 1911, hospitals in 1915, toilets, hotels and restaurants in 1928 and waiting rooms for bus stops in 1945.

sentence: Although the class of planters persuaded the white poor to vote in favour of this legislative effort to remove the black vote, the new restrictions also deprived them of their right to vote, mainly because of the imposition of a combined voting fee.

sentence: In 1941, whites constituted a slight majority of those who had been deprived of their rights under these laws: 600,000 whites versus 520,000 African-Americans.

sentence: Despite numerous legal challenges that have succeeded in overturning certain provisions, the state legislator would create new ones to maintain the right to vote.

name: alabama
sentence: The Alabama Legislative Assembly, dominated by rural areas, has always underfunded schools and services for Afro-Americans deprived of their rights, but it has not exempted them from taxes.

name: alabama
sentence: Partly in response to the chronic underfunding of Afro-American education in the South, the Rosenwald Fund began to finance the construction of what has been called Rosenwald schools.

name: alabama
sentence: In Alabama, these schools were designed and the construction partly financed by the Rosenwald funds, which paid one third of the construction costs.

name: alabama
sentence: The fund required the local community and the State to raise matching funds to pay for the remainder.

name: alabama
sentence: Black residents have indeed taxed themselves twice, raising additional funds to provide matching funds for these schools, which have been built in many rural areas.

name: alabama
sentence: They have often given land and labour as well.

name: alabama
sentence: From 1913, the first 80 Rosenwald schools were built in Alabama for Afro-American children.

name: alabama
sentence: A total of 387 schools, seven teaching houses and several professional buildings were completed in 1937 in the state.

sentence: Several of the remaining school buildings in the state are now registered in the National Register of Historic Sites.

name: alabama
sentence: The continuation of racial discrimination and lynching, the agricultural depression and the failure of cotton crops due to the infestation of ploughs has led tens of thousands of African-Americans from rural areas of Alabama and other states to seek opportunities in the cities of the north and center-west during the first decades of the 20th century as part of the Great Migration out of the South.

name: alabama
sentence: In view of this emigration, the rate of population growth in Alabama (see the table "historical populations" below) declined by almost half between 1910 and 1920.

sentence: Birmingham grew so rapidly that it was called the Magic City.

name: alabama
sentence: Heavy industry and the mining industry are at the root of its economy.

sentence: Its residents were underrepresented for decades in the State Parliament, which refused to redistribute after each decennial census according to population changes, as required by the state constitution.

sentence: This did not change until the late 1960s as a result of a prosecution and court order.

name: alabama
sentence: Industrial development linked to the demands of the Second World War has brought a level of prosperity to the unseen state since before the civil war.

sentence: Rural workers have entered the largest cities in the State to obtain better jobs and a higher standard of living.

sentence: An example of this massive influx of workers took place in Mobile.

name: alabama
sentence: Cotton and other commercial crops have become less important when the State has developed a production and service base.

name: alabama
sentence: Despite the massive population changes in the state from 1901 to 1961, the predominantly rural legislature refused to renew the seats of the House and Senators on the basis of the population, as required by the constitution of the State in order to follow the results of the decennial censuses.

name: alabama
sentence: They maintained an old representation to maintain political and economic power in agricultural areas.

name: alabama
sentence: As a result, Jefferson County, home to Birmingham's industrial and economic power, paid more than a third of all tax revenues to the state, but did not receive a proportionate amount in services.

name: alabama
sentence: Urban interests are still under-represented in the legislature.

name: alabama
sentence: According to a study carried out in 1960, due to rural domination, "a minority of about 25 per cent of the total population of the state controls the majority of the Alabama Legislative Assembly".

name: alabama
sentence: In Baker v. Carr (1962) and Reynolds v. Sims (1964), the United States Supreme Court held that the principle of "one man, one vote" should be the basis of both chambers of state legislatures, and that their districts should be based on population rather than geographic counties.

name: alabama
sentence: In 1972, for the first time since 1901, the legislature completed the redistribution of Congress on the basis of the decennial census.

name: alabama
sentence: This has benefited urban areas that have developed, as well as the population as a whole that has been underrepresented for more than 60 years.

name: alabama
sentence: Other changes have been made to the establishment of a representative state house and senate districts.

sentence: African-Americans continued to lobby in the 1950s and 1960s to end exclusion and segregation in the state through the civil rights movement, including legal challenges.

sentence: The civil rights movement experienced significant events in Alabama, including the boycott of the Montgomery buses (1955-1956), the Freedom Rides in 1961 and the Selma marches to Montgomery in 1965.

sentence: They contributed to the adoption and adoption by the U.S. Congress of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

name: alabama
sentence: Alabama has made some changes since the end of the twentieth century and has used new types of voting to increase representation.

name: alabama
sentence: In the 1980s, an omnibus case of redistriction, Dillard v. Crenshaw County, challenged the general vote for seats representing 180 Alabama jurisdictions, including counties and school boards.

name: alabama
sentence: Voting in general had diluted the votes of any minority in a county, as the majority tended to take all seats.

name: alabama
sentence: Despite the African-Americans who constitute an important minority in the state, they have not been able to elect any representative in most jurisdictions in general.

name: alabama
sentence: As part of the resolution of this case, five Alabama towns and counties, including Chilton County, have adopted a cumulative voting system for the election of representatives in multiple-seat jurisdictions.

name: alabama
sentence: This has led to a more proportional representation of voters.

name: alabama
sentence: In another form of proportional representation, 23 jurisdictions use limited voting, as in the County of Conecuh.

name: alabama
sentence: In 1982, the limited vote was first tested in Conecuh County.

name: alabama
sentence: Together, the use of these systems has increased the number of African American women and women elected to local offices, leading to more representative governments of their citizens.

sentence: Alabama is the thirtieth state of the United States with 52,419 square miles (135,760 km2) of the total area: 3.2% of the area is water, making the Alabama 23rd in quantity of surface water, also giving it the second largest inland waterway system in the United States.

name: alabama
sentence: Notable natural wonders include: the "Natural Bridge" rock, the longest natural bridge east of the Rocky Mountains, located just south of Haleyville; the Caverns Cathedral in Marshall County, named for its cathedral appearance, has one of the largest cave entrances and stalagmites in the world; the Red Escort in Fairhope, the highest point on the coast between Maine and Mexico; DeSoto Caverns in Childersburg, the first officially recorded cave in the United States; the Noccalula Falls in Gadsden have a 90-foot waterfall; the Dismals Canyon near Phil Campbell, home to two waterfalls, six natural bridges and a hiding place for the legendary outlaw Jesse James; the Stephens Gap cave in Jackson County has a 143-foot pit, two waterfalls and is one of the most photographed wild cave scenes in America; the Little River Canyon near Fort Payne, one of the longest mountain rivers in the country; and the Warwood Caver Redfish, one of the longest-aged 260-million-year-old Redfish, one-footedged.

sentence: An 8 km wide meteorite impact crater is located in Elmore County just north of Montgomery.

sentence: The Alabama, as well as Oklahoma and Iowa, have the most confirmed F5 and EF5 tornadoes of any state, according to the statistics of the National Climate Data Centre for the period from 1 January 1950 to June 2013.

sentence: According to statistics collected by the 2010 Association of Religion Data Archives, about 34% of Alaskans were members of religious congregations.

name: alaska
sentence: The oil and gas industry dominates the Alaskan economy, with more than 80 per cent of the government's revenues from oil extraction.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's main export product (excluding oil and natural gas) is sea fish, mainly salmon, cod, Pollock and crab.

name: alaska
sentence: Agriculture accounts for a very small fraction of Alaska's economy.

name: alaska
sentence: Agricultural production is mainly intended for consumption within the state and includes nurseries, dairy products, vegetables and livestock.

name: alaska
sentence: Manufacturing is limited, with most food and general goods being imported from other countries.

name: alaska
sentence: Employment primarily affects government and industries such as natural resource extraction, marine transportation and transportation.

name: alaska
sentence: Military bases are an important part of the economy of Fairbanks North Star, Anchorage and Kodiak Island, as well as Kodiak.

name: alaska
sentence: Federal subsidies are also an important part of the economy, allowing the government to keep taxes low.

name: alaska
sentence: Its industrial outputs include crude oil, natural gas, coal, gold, precious metals, zinc and other extractive industries, seafood processing, wood and wood products.

name: alaska
sentence: There is also an expanding services and tourism sector.

name: alaska
sentence: Tourists contributed to the economy by supporting local accommodation.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska has significant energy resources, although its oil reserves have been extensively depleted.

name: alaska
sentence: Significant oil and gas reserves were found in the Alaska North Slope (ANS) and Cook Inlet basins, but according to the Energy Information Administration, in February 2014, Alaska was ranked fourth in crude oil production after Texas, North Dakota and California.

name: alaska
sentence: Prudhoe Bay on the northern slope of Alaska is still the second-high-yielding oil field in the United States, generally producing about 400,000 barrels per day (64,000 m3/d), although at the beginning of 2014, the North Dakota Bakken Formation produced more than 900,000 barrels per day (140,000 m3/d).

name: alaska
sentence: Prudhoe Bay was the largest conventional oil deposit ever discovered in North America, but it was much smaller than the huge Athabasca oil sands deposit in Canada, which in 2014 produced approximately 1,500 000 barrels per day (240,000 m3/d) of unconventional oil, and had hundreds of years of productive reserves at that rate.

name: alaska
sentence: The Trans-Alaska pipeline can transport and pump up to 2.1 million barrels (330,000 m3) of crude oil per day, more than any other crude oil pipeline in the United States.

name: alaska
sentence: In addition, large coal deposits are found in Alaska's oil, subbituminous, and lignite basins.

name: alaska
sentence: The U.S. Geological Survey estimates that there are 85.4 trillion cubic feet (2,420 km3) of undiscovered gas technically recoverable from natural gas hydrates on the northern slope of Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska also has some of the country's highest hydroelectric potential from its many rivers.

name: alaska
sentence: Large stretches of Alaska's coastline also offer potential for wind and geothermal energy.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's economy relies heavily on increasingly expensive diesel fuel for heating, transportation, electricity and light.

name: alaska
sentence: While wind and hydro power are abundant and underdeveloped, proposals for state-wide energy systems (e.g., wind and hydro power) are not yet fully developed.

name: alaska
sentence: It was found to be unprofitable (at the time of the report, 2001) due to low fuel prices (less than 50¢/gal), long distances and low population.

name: alaska
sentence: The cost of one gallon of gas in urban Alaska is generally thirty to sixty cents higher than the national average; prices in rural areas are generally much higher, but vary greatly depending on transportation costs, seasonal peaks of use, nearby oil development infrastructure and many other factors.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Permanent Fund is an appropriation authorized by the Constitution of Oil Revenues, established by voters in 1976 to manage a surplus of the state's oil revenues, largely in anticipation of the recently constructed Trans Alaska pipeline system.

name: alaska
sentence: The fund was originally proposed by Governor Keith Miller on the eve of the sale of the Prudhoe Bay lease in 1969, for fear that legislators would spend all of the proceeds of the sale (i.e. $900 million) at the same time.

name: alaska
sentence: He was later defended by Governor Jay Hammond and State representative Kenai Hugh Malone.

name: alaska
sentence: This is an attractive political perspective since then, which diverts revenue that would normally be deposited into the general fund.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaskan Constitution was drafted to discourage the allocation of public funds for specific purposes.

name: alaska
sentence: The Permanent Fund has become the rare exception to this, mainly because of the political climate of distrust that existed at the time of its creation.

name: alaska
sentence: From its initial capital of $734,000, the fund has increased to $50 billion due to oil royalties and capital investment programs.

name: alaska
sentence: Most if not all of the capital is invested conservatively outside Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: This has led to frequent calls from Alaskan politicians for the Fund to invest in Alaska, although such a position has never gained momentum.

name: alaska
sentence: Beginning in 1982, dividends from the annual growth of the fund were paid each year to eligible Alaskans, ranging from an initial amount of $1,000 in 1982 (equal to three years of payment, since the distribution of payments was suspended in a distribution plan prosecution) to $3,269 in 2008 (which included a one-time amount of $1,200 "Resource Rebate").

name: alaska
sentence: Each year, the state legislature withdraws 8% of the earnings, gives 3% to the capital for proof of inflation, and the remaining 5% is distributed to all eligible Alaskans.

name: alaska
sentence: To be eligible for the dividend from the Permanent Fund, one must have lived in the State for a minimum of 12 months, maintain permanent residence subject to authorized absences and not be subject to judicial judgements or criminal convictions that fall within various categories of exclusion or may subject the amount of the payment to civil arrest.

name: alaska
sentence: The Permanent Fund is often seen as one of the main examples of a "core income" policy in the world.

name: alaska
sentence: The cost of goods in Alaska has long been higher than the 48 contiguous states.

name: alaska
sentence: Federal government officials, particularly U.S. Postal Service (USPS) workers and active members, receive a subsistence allowance usually set at 25% of basic pay because, although the cost of living has decreased, it remains one of the highest in the country.

name: alaska
sentence: Rural Alaska suffers from extremely high prices for food and consumer goods compared to the rest of the country, due to relatively limited transport infrastructure.

name: alaska
sentence: Because of the northern climate and the short growing season, there is relatively little farming in Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: Most farms are located either in the Matanuska Valley, about 64 km northeast of Anchorage, or on the Kenai Peninsula, about 97 km southwest of Anchorage.

name: alaska
sentence: The short 100-day growing season limits the crops that can be grown, but the long sunny summer days make for productive growing seasons.

name: alaska
sentence: The main crops are potatoes, carrots, lettuce, and cabbage.

name: alaska
sentence: The Tanana Valley is another remarkable agricultural site, particularly the Delta Junction area, about 160 kilometres south-east of Fairbanks, with a large concentration of farms growing agronomic crops, mainly to the north and east of Fort Greely.

name: alaska
sentence: This region was largely set aside and developed as part of a state programme led by Hammond during his second term as governor.

name: alaska
sentence: Crops in the delta area consist mainly of barley and hay.

name: alaska
sentence: To the west of Fairbanks is another concentration of small farms that deal with restaurants, the hotel and tourism industry and community-supported agriculture.

name: alaska
sentence: In recent years, Alaskan agriculture has seen strong growth in market gardeners, small farms and agricultural markets, with the largest percentage increase (46%) in agricultural market growth in the country in 2011, compared to 17% in the country as a whole.

name: alaska
sentence: The peony industry has also grown, as the growing season allows farmers to harvest during a supply gap elsewhere in the world, filling a niche on the flower market.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska, without counties, does not have county fairs.

name: alaska
sentence: However, a small assortment of state fairs and local fairs (with Alaska's largest state fair in Palmer) take place mainly in late summer.

name: alaska
sentence: Fairs are primarily located in communities with historical or current farming activities, and include local farmers who exhibit products in addition to more publicized commercial activities such as carnival walks, concerts and food.

name: alaska
sentence: "Alaska Grown" is used as an agricultural slogan.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska has an abundance of seafood, with the main fisheries of the Bering Sea and the North Pacific.

name: alaska
sentence: Seafish is one of the few food products that is often cheaper within the state than outside.

name: alaska
sentence: Many Alaskans take advantage of the salmon season to harvest portions of their domestic food while fishing for their livelihood, as well as for sport.

name: alaska
sentence: This includes fish caught by hook, net, or wheel.

name: alaska
sentence: Subsistence hunting, mainly caribou, moose and Dall sheep, is still common in the state, particularly in remote Bush communities.

name: alaska
sentence: An example of traditional indigenous diet is Akutaq, the Eskimo Ice Cream, which may consist of reindeer fat, seal oil, dried fish meat and local berries.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska reindeer farming focuses on the Seward Peninsula, where wild caribou can be prevented from mixing and migrating with domestic reindeer.

name: alaska
sentence: Most foods in Alaska are transported to the state from "outside," and shipping costs make food relatively expensive in cities.

name: alaska
sentence: In rural areas, hunting and subsistence gathering is an essential activity because imported foods are prohibitive.

name: alaska
sentence: Although most of the small towns and villages in Alaska are along the coast, the cost of importing food into remote villages can be high, due to terrain and difficult road conditions, which change significantly due to climate change and precipitation.

name: alaska
sentence: The cost of transportation can be up to 50¢ per pound ($1.10/kg) or more in some remote areas, during the most difficult periods, if these locations can be reached at all during these adverse weather and terrain conditions.

name: alaska
sentence: The cost of delivering an American gallon of milk (3.8 L) is approximately $3.50 in many villages where per capita income can be $20,000 or less.

name: alaska
sentence: The cost of fuel per gallon is consistently twenty to thirty cents higher than the United States' contiguous average, with only Hawaii having higher prices.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska has few road links compared to the rest of the United States.

name: alaska
sentence: The state's road network covers a relatively small area of the state, connecting the central population centres and the Alaska Highway, Canada's main exit route from the state.

name: alaska
sentence: The state capital, Juneau, is not accessible by road, only a motor ferry; for decades this has sparked the debate about moving the capital to a city on the road network, or the construction of a road link from Haines.

name: alaska
sentence: The western part of Alaska has no road network connecting communities to the rest of Alaska.

name: alaska
sentence: The inter-state highways in Alaska consist of a total of 1082 miles.

name: alaska
sentence: One of the unique features of the Alaska Highway system is the Anton Anderson Memorial Tunnel, an Alaskan railway tunnel in operation recently renovated to provide asphalt road connections to the isolated community of Whittier, Prince William Sound, to the Seward Road, approximately 80 km southeast of Anchorage, Portage.

name: alaska
sentence: At 4.0 km, the tunnel is North America's longest road tunnel until 2007.

name: alaska
sentence: This tunnel is North America's longest road and rail tunnel.

name: alaska
sentence: Built around 1915, the Alaskan Railway (ARR) played a key role in the development of Alaska up to the 20th century.

name: alaska
sentence: It connects North Pacific vessels by providing critical infrastructure with routes from Seward to the interior of Alaska through south-central Alaska, through Anchorage, Eklutna, Wasilla, Talkeetna, Denali and Fairbanks, with spurs to Whittier, Palmer and the North Pole.

name: alaska
sentence: Cities, villages and the area served by the ARR are known throughout the state as the "Rail Belt".

name: alaska
sentence: In recent years, the continuous improvement of the paved road network has begun to overshadowed the importance of the railway to the Alaskan economy.

name: alaska
sentence: The railway played a key role in Alaska's development, moving freight to Alaska while transporting natural resources to the south, such as coal from the Usibelli coal mine near Healy at Seward and gravel from the Matanuska Valley to Anchorage.

name: alaska
sentence: It is well known for its summer excursion service.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Railway was one of the last railways in North America to use cabbages in regular service and still use them on some gravel trains.

name: alaska
sentence: It continues to offer one of the last stopping roads of the country's flag.

name: alaska
sentence: A section of approximately 100 kilometres of track along an area north of Talkeetna remains inaccessible by road

name: alaska
sentence: Until the park road was built in the 1970s, the railway provided the only land access to most of the area along its entire road.

name: alaska
sentence: In northeastern Alaska, the White Pass and Yukon Highway also crosses part of the state from Skagway northward to Canada (British Columbia and Yukon), crossing the border at the White Pass Summit.

name: alaska
sentence: This line is now used mainly by tourists, often arriving by cruise ship in Skagway.

name: alaska
sentence: It was presented in the 1983 BBC television series Great Little Railways.

name: alaska
sentence: The Alaska Rail network is not connected to the outside.

name: alaska
sentence: (The closest link to the North American rail system is the northwest terminus of Canada's national railway at Prince Rupert, British Columbia, several hundred miles southeast.)

sentence: Many cities, towns and villages in the State do not have access to the road or highway; the only modes of access are air, river or sea travel.

name: alaska
sentence: Alaska's well-developed ferry system (called the Alaska Highway) serves the cities of the southeast, the Gulf Coast and the Alaska Peninsula.

name: alaska

sentence: Other major airports without scheduled commercial flights include Scottsdale Municipal Airport (IATA: CWS, ICAO: KSDL) in Scottsdale, and Deer Valley Airport (IATA: DVT, ICAO: KDVT, FAA: DVT), which houses two flight training academies and the busiest general aviation airport in the country.

name: arizona
sentence: Phoenix is the capital city of Arizona.

name: arizona
sentence: The original Capitol building, with its distinctive copper dome, was dedicated in 1901 (the construction was completed for $136,000 in 1900), while the area was a territory.

sentence: Phoenix became the state's official capital with Arizona's admission to union in 1912.

sentence: The House of Representatives and Senators' buildings were dedicated in 1960, and an executive office building was dedicated in 1974 (the ninth floor of this building is where the Governor's office is located).

name: arizona
sentence: The original Capitol building was transformed into a museum.

sentence: The site also includes many monuments and memorials, including the anchor and signal mast of the USARIZona (one of the ships of the American Navy sunk in Pearl Harbor) and a granite version of the Ten Commandments.

name: arizona
sentence: The Arizona Legislature is bicameral (such as the Legislature of all other states except Nebraska) and consists of a thirty-member Senator and a 60-member House of Representatives.

name: arizona
sentence: Each of the thirty legislative districts has one senator and two representatives.

name: arizona
sentence: Parliamentarians are elected for a term of two years.

name: arizona
sentence: Each legislature is for a term of two years.

name: arizona
sentence: The first session following the general election is known as the first regular session, and the second year session is known as the second regular session.

name: arizona
sentence: Each ordinary session shall begin on the second Monday of January and shall adjourn sine die (duration of the year) no later than the Saturday of the week during which the hundredth day of the beginning of the ordinary session falls.

name: arizona
sentence: The Speaker of the Senate and Speaker of the House, by regulation, may extend the session for an additional seven days.

name: arizona
sentence: Subsequently, the session may be extended only by a majority vote of the members present in each chamber.

name: arizona
sentence: The majority party is the Republican Party, which has held power in both chambers since 1993.

name: arizona
sentence: Senators and representatives of Arizona states are elected for a two-year term and are limited to four consecutive terms in a chamber, even if there is no limit to the total number of terms.

name: arizona
sentence: When a legislator is limited to a term of office, it is common for him to run for election to the other House.

name: arizona
sentence: The 2006-2007 general funds budget, approved by the Arizona Legislative Assembly in June 2006, was slightly less than $10 billion.

sentence: In addition to the money spent on government agencies, it also included over $500 million in income and property tax reductions, salary increases for government employees and additional funds for the K-12 education system.

name: arizona

name: arizona
sentence: The Governor can carry out any number of warrants, but not more than two in a row.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona is one of the few states that do not have a governor's home.

sentence: Arizona had four female governors, more than any other state.

sentence: The Secretary of State, the Treasurer of the State, the Attorney General of the State, the Director of Public Investigation, the State Inspector of Mines and a five-member Commission of the Society are also elected.

name: arizona

name: arizona

name: arizona
sentence: The Arizona Supreme Court is the highest court in Arizona, consisting of a Chief Justice, a Chief Deputy Judge and five Associate Judges.

sentence: Arizona obtained a ninth seat in the House of Representatives as a result of the redistribution based on the 2010 census.

name: arizona
sentence: From the state until the late 1940s, Arizona was dominated primarily by the Democratic Party.

name: arizona
sentence: During this period, the Democratic presidential candidate carried the state each election, the only exceptions being the 1920, 1924 and 1928 elections - the three were national Republican landslides.

name: arizona
sentence: In 1924, Congress had passed a law granting citizenship and suffrage to all Amerindians, some of whom had previously been excluded as tribal members on reserve.

name: arizona
sentence: The legal interpretations of the Arizona constitution prohibited Amerindians living on reserve from voting, classifying them as "custodial."

name: arizona
sentence: This interpretation was quashed as incorrect and unconstitutional in 1948 by the Arizona Supreme Court, following an action brought by Frank Harrison and Harry Austin, World War II Indian veterans, both of the Yavapai Nation of Fort McDowell.

name: arizona
sentence: The most significant case is Harrison and Austin v. Laveen.

name: arizona
sentence: After the men were denied the opportunity to register in Maricopa County, they filed an action against the Registrar.

name: arizona
sentence: The National Congress of American Indians, the Department of Justice, the Ministry of the Interior and the American Civil Liberties Union all filed amicus curiae (friends of the court) briefs in the case.

name: arizona
sentence: The Supreme Court of the State established the right of Amerindians to vote in the State; at the time they constituted approximately 11 per cent of the population.

name: arizona
sentence: That year, a similar provision was overturned in New Mexico when another Indian veteran was challenged in court.

name: arizona
sentence: They were the only two States that had continued to prohibit Amerindians from voting.

name: arizona
sentence: From the election of Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1952 to 2020, the majority of state voters favored Republicans in the presidential elections.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona voted Republican in every presidential election from 1952 to 1992, with Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan winning the state with particularly high margins.

name: arizona
sentence: During this period of forty years, it was the only state not to be carried by a democrat at least once.

name: arizona
sentence: Democrat Lyndon Johnson, in 1964, lost the state by less than 5,000 votes against Arizona senator Barry Goldwater.

name: arizona
sentence: (This was the most disputed state in what was otherwise a shaken victory for Johnson that year.)

name: arizona
sentence: Democratic Bill Clinton ended this series in 1996, when he won Arizona by just over two percentage points (Clinton had previously obtained less than two per cent of Arizona's electoral votes in 1992).

name: arizona
sentence: From 2000 to 2016, the majority of the state continued to support candidates for the Republican presidency through solid margins.

name: arizona
sentence: In the 2020 presidential election in the United States, Joe Biden once again broke the chain by becoming the first democratic presidential candidate to win Arizona since 1996.

name: arizona
sentence: Since the end of the 20th century, the Republican Party has also dominated Arizona politics in general.

name: arizona
sentence: The growing suburbs of Phoenix and Tucson became more and more friendly with the Republicans since the 1950s.

name: arizona
sentence: Meanwhile, many "Pinto Democrats", or conservative democrats from rural areas, have become more and more willing to support Republicans at state and national level.

name: arizona
sentence: Although the state normally supports republicans at the federal level, democrats are often competitive in state-wide elections.

name: arizona
sentence: Two of the last six governors are democrats.

name: arizona
sentence: On March 4, 2008, Senator John McCain actually obtained the Republican nomination for 2008, becoming the first candidate for the state presidency since Barry Goldwater in 1964.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona's policy is dominated by a long-standing rivalry between its two largest counties, Maricopa and Pima, where Phoenix and Tucson live respectively.

name: arizona
sentence: Both counties account for nearly 75 per cent of the state's population and account for almost 80 per cent of the state's votes.

name: arizona
sentence: They also elect a large majority of the state legislature.

name: arizona
sentence: Maricopa County is home to nearly 60 per cent of the state's population, and most of the state's elected officials live there.

name: arizona
sentence: Before Joe Biden won Maricopa County in 2020, he had voted Republican in each presidential election since 1948.

name: arizona
sentence: This included the 1964 race of the native son Barry Goldwater; he would not have worn his original condition without his margin of 20,000 votes in Maricopa County.

name: arizona
sentence: Similarly, McCain won Arizona by eight percentage points in 2008, with a margin of 130,000 votes in Maricopa County.

name: arizona
sentence: On the other hand, Pima County, home to Tucson, and most of southern Arizona, have always voted more democraticly.

name: arizona
sentence: While the suburbs of Tucson lean republican, they hold a somewhat more moderate mark of republicanism than is common in the Phoenix area.

sentence: Arizona rejected the prohibition of same-sex marriage in a referendum in the 2006 elections.

sentence: Arizona was the first State to do so.

sentence: Same-sex marriage was not recognized in Arizona, but this amendment would have denied legal or financial benefits to unmarried homosexual or heterosexual couples.

name: arizona
sentence: In 2008, Arizona voters adopted Proposal 102, an amendment to the state constitution to define marriage as a union of a man and a woman.

name: arizona
sentence: It was adopted by a narrower majority than similar votes in a number of other states.

name: arizona
sentence: In 2010, Arizona adopted SB 1070, called the most severe illegal immigration legislation in the nation.

name: arizona
sentence: A fierce debate broke out between partisans and detractors of the law.

name: arizona
sentence: The 2018 West Virginia Teachers' Strike prompted teachers in other states, including Arizona, to take similar action.

name: arizona
sentence: In 2006, Arizona became the first state in the United States to reject a proposal, Prop 107, which allegedly prohibited same-sex marriage and civil unions.

name: arizona
sentence: However, in 2008, Arizona voters approved section 102, a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage, but not other unions.

name: arizona
sentence: Before same-sex marriage was legal, the City of Bisbee became the first jurisdiction in Arizona to approve civil unions.

name: arizona
sentence: The State Attorney General at the time, Tom Horne, threatened to prosecute, but cancelled the threat when Bisbee amended the order; Bisbee approved the civil unions in 2013.

name: arizona
sentence: The municipalities of Clarkdale, Cottonwood, Jerome, Sedona and Tucson also have civil unions.

name: arizona
sentence: A November 2011 public policy survey revealed that 44 per cent of Arizona voters supported the legalization of same-sex marriage, while 45 per cent opposed it and 12 per cent were not sure.

name: arizona
sentence: Another question from the same survey revealed that 72% of respondents supported the legal recognition of same-sex couples, 40% supported same-sex marriage, 32% supported civil unions, 27% opposed legal recognition and 1% were unsure.

name: arizona
sentence: Arizona's proposal 102, known by its supporters as the Marriage Protection Amendment, appeared as a constitutional amendment mentioned by law in the November 4, 2008, Arizona election, where it was approved: 56.2% to 43%.

name: arizona
sentence: It amended the Arizona Constitution to define a marriage between a man and a woman.

name: arizona
sentence: On October 17, 2014, Arizona Attorney General Tom Horne announced that his office would no longer oppose homosexual marriage in response to a decision of the U.S. District Court on Arizona Proposal 102.

name: arizona
sentence: On that day, the clerk of the Superior Court of each county began issuing same-sex marriage permits, and Arizona became the 31st state to legalize same-sex marriage.

name: arizona
sentence: In Arizona, public schools are divided into some 220 local school districts that operate independently but are in most cases governed by elected county principals, who in turn are overseen by the Arizona National Education Council and the Arizona Department of Education.

name: arkansas
sentence: Arkansas () is a state in the south-central United States of America, with more than three million people in 2018.

name: arkansas
sentence: His name is from the language of the Osage, from the Siwan diversion; he indicated their related parent, the Quapaw people.

name: arkansas
sentence: The geographical diversity of the State extends from the mountainous regions of the Ozark and Ouachita Mountains, which make up the United States.

name: arkansas
sentence: The interior Highlands, to the densely wooded lands in the south known as Timberlands Arkansas, to the eastern lowlands along Mississippi and Arkansas Delta.

name: arkansas
sentence: Arkansas is the 29th largest by region and the 33rd most populous US state.

name: arkansas
sentence: The capital and most populated city is Little Rock, in the central part of the state, a centre for transportation, business, culture and government.

name: arkansas
sentence: The northwest corner of the state, including the Fayetteville–Springdale–Rogers metropolitan area and the Fort Smith metropolitan area, is a centre of population, education and economics.

name: arkansas
sentence: The largest city in the eastern part of the State is Jonesboro.

name: arkansas
sentence: The largest city in the south-eastern part of the state is Pine Bluff.

name: arkansas
sentence: The territory of Arkansas was admitted into the Union as the 25th State on 15 June 1836.

name: arkansas
sentence: Much of the delta has been developed for cotton plantations, and landowners depend largely on the enslaved work of African Americans.

name: arkansas
sentence: In 1861, Arkansas left the United States and entered the Confederate States of America during the civil war.

name: arkansas
sentence: Returning to the Union in 1868, Arkansas continued to suffer because of its dependence on the economy of large plantations.

name: arkansas
sentence: Cotton remains the primary commodity crop, although the cotton market has declined.

name: arkansas
sentence: Because farmers and businessmen were not diversifying and there was little industrial investment, the state was lagging behind the economic outlook.

name: arkansas
sentence: White rural interests dominated Arkansas politics by depriving Afro-Americans of their right to vote and refusing to reintroduce legislative power.

name: arkansas
sentence: It was only after the civil rights movement and the federal intervention that more Africans were able to vote.

name: arkansas
sentence: The Supreme Court reversed rural domination in the South and other states that had refused to renew their state legislatures or maintained rules based on geographical districts.

name: arkansas
sentence: In a man's historic decision, a voice, she said that states had to organize their legislatures by districts with roughly equal populations, and that they had to be redefined if necessary after the census of each decade.

name: arkansas
sentence: After the Second World War, Arkansas began to diversify its economy.

name: arkansas
sentence: In the 21st century, its economy was based on service industries, aircraft, poultry, steel and tourism, as well as important commodity crops such as cotton, soybeans and rice.

sentence: Arkansas culture can be seen in museums, theatres, novels, television programmes, restaurants and sports venues in the state.

sentence: It comes from a French term, Arcansas, their plural term for their transliteration of akansa, an Algonquian term for the Quapaw people.

sentence: The state's varied geography extends from the Pacific coast to the west to the Sierra Nevada mountain range in the east, and from the Douglas-fir and redwood forests in the northwest to the Mojave desert in the southeast.

name: california
sentence: The central valley, a large agricultural area, dominates the centre of the State.

name: california
sentence: Although California is well known for its warm Mediterranean climate and monsoon season, the large size of the state translates into climates that vary from the humid temperate tropical forest in the north to the arid desert in the interior, as well as snowy alpine pasture in the mountains.

name: california
sentence: All these factors lead to a huge demand for water; in total, California is the largest water user in North America.

name: california
sentence: Over time, drought and forest fires have become more frequent, further increasing water safety in California.

name: california
sentence: What is now California was first established by various Californian indigenous tribes before being explored by a number of Europeans during the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.

name: california
sentence: The Spanish Empire claimed it and colonized it.

name: california
sentence: In 1804 it was included in the province of Alta California, in the vice-royalty of New Spain.

name: california
sentence: The region became part of Mexico in 1821 after its successful war of independence, but was ceded to the United States in 1848 after the war between Mexico and the United States.

name: california
sentence: The western part of the Alta California was then organized and admitted as the 31st state on 9 September 1850.

name: california
sentence: The California Gold Rush, which began in 1848, led to dramatic social and demographic changes, with large-scale emigration from east and abroad with an accompanying economic boom.

name: california
sentence: The Spaniards gave the name of Las Californias to the peninsula of Lower California and Alta California, the region that has become the present state of California.

name: california
sentence: The name probably derived from the mythical island of California in the fictitious history of Queen Calafia, as recorded in a work 1510 The Adventures of Esplandián by Garci Rodríguez de Montalvo.

name: california
sentence: This work was the fifth in a series of popular Spanish chivalry novels that began with Amadis de Gaula.

name: california
sentence: The kingdom of Queen Calafia was considered a distant land rich in gold and pearls, inhabited by beautiful black women who wore gold armor and lived as Amazons, as well as griffins and other strange beasts.

name: california
sentence: In the fictional paradise, Queen Calafia fought alongside Muslims and her name may have been chosen to echo the title of a Muslim leader, the caliph.

name: california
sentence: It is possible that the Californian name was designed to mean that the island was a Caliphate.

name: california
sentence: The abbreviated forms of the state name include CA, Cal, Cali, Calif, Califas and US-CA.

name: california
sentence: Installed by successive waves of arrivals over the last 13,000 years, California was one of the most culturally and linguistically diverse regions in pre-Columbian North America.

name: california
sentence: Various estimates of the Aboriginal population vary from 100,000 to 300,000.

name: california
sentence: The Aboriginal peoples of California included more than 70 distinct ethnic groups of Native Americans, ranging from the large established populations living on the coast to the inner groups.

name: california
sentence: Californian groups were also diverse in their political organization, with bands, tribes, villages, and on the resource-rich coasts, great chiefdoms, such as Chumash, Pomo and Salinan.

name: california
sentence: Trade, marriage and military alliances have fostered many social and economic relationships between the various groups.

name: california
sentence: The first Europeans to explore the Californian coast were members of a Spanish sail expedition led by Portuguese captain Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo; they entered San Diego Bay on 28 September 1542 and reached at least as far north as San Miguel Island.

name: california
sentence: Private and explorer Francis Drake explored and claimed an undefined part of the Californian coast in 1579, disembarking north of the future city of San Francisco.

name: california
sentence: The first Asians to set foot on what would be the United States occurred in 1587 when the Filipino sailors arrived in Spanish ships at Morro Bay.

name: california
sentence: Sebastián Vizcaíno explored and mapped the coast of California in 1602 for New Spain, sailing to Cap Mendocino.

name: california
sentence: Despite explorations on the California field in the 16th century, the idea of Rodríguez of California as an island persisted.

name: california
sentence: Such representations appeared on many European maps in the 18th century.

name: california
sentence: After the Portolà expedition of 1769–70, Spanish missionaries led by Junipero Serra began to set up 21 Californian missions on or near the coast of Alta (Upper) California, from San Diego.

name: california
sentence: During the same period, Spanish military forces built several forts (presidios) and three small towns (pueblos).

name: california
sentence: The San Francisco Mission grew up in the city of San Francisco, and two of the Pueblos grew up in the cities of Los Angeles and San José.

name: california
sentence: Several other small towns and cities have also emerged around the various Spanish missions and pueblos, which remain to date.

name: california
sentence: Spanish colonization began to decimate indigenous people through epidemics of various diseases for which indigenous peoples did not have natural immunity, such as measles and diphtheria.

sentence: The establishment of the Spanish systems of government and social structure, which Spanish settlers had brought with them, had also overshadowed the societies of previous indigenous peoples technologically and culturally.

name: california

sentence: The Russian colonies associated with Fort Ross were distributed between Point Arena and Tomales Bay.

name: california
sentence: The first newly independent Mexican government was very unstable, and in a reflection of this, starting in 1831, California also experienced a series of armed conflicts, both internal and with the Mexican central government.

name: california
sentence: During this turbulent political period, Juan Bautista Alvarado was able to serve as governor from 1836 to 1842.

name: california
sentence: The military action that first brought Alvarado to power temporarily declared California as an independent state, and was assisted by Anglo-American residents of California, including Isaac Graham.

name: california
sentence: In 1840, one hundred of those residents who did not have a passport were arrested, leading to the Graham case, which was resolved in part by the intercession of Royal Navy officials.

name: california
sentence: One of California's largest breeders was John Marsh.

name: california
sentence: After he had not obtained justice from the Mexican courts against squatters on his territory, he decided that California should be part of the United States.

name: california
sentence: Marsh led a campaign of writing letters marrying the Californian climate, the soil, and other reasons to settle there, as well as the best way to follow, which became known as the "Marsh Road".

name: california
sentence: His letters were read, read, passed, and printed in newspapers across the country, and began the first train trains to California.

name: california
sentence: He invited the immigrants to stay on his ranch until they could settle and helped them get their passport.

name: california
sentence: After opening the period of organized emigration to California, Marsh engaged in a military battle between the Mexican General, Manuel Micheltorena, and the governor of California whom he had replaced, Juan Bautista Alvarado.

name: california
sentence: The armies of each gathered at the Battle of Providencia, near Los Angeles.

name: california
sentence: Marsh was forced against his will to join Micheltorena's army.

name: california
sentence: Ignoring his superiors, during the battle, he signalled a parlay on the other side.

name: california
sentence: There were many settlers from the United States who fought on both sides.

name: california
sentence: He convinced these men they had no reason to fight each other.

name: california
sentence: As a result of Marsh's actions, they gave up the fight, Micheltorena was defeated, and Pio Pico, born in California, was returned to the post of governor.

name: california
sentence: This paved the way for the ultimate acquisition of California by the US.

name: california
sentence: In 1846 a group of American settlers inside and around Sonoma rebelled against Mexican domination during the bear flag revolt.

name: california
sentence: Subsequently, the rebels raised the Bear flag (which holds a bear, a star, a red stripe and the words "Republic of California") in Sonoma.

name: california
sentence: The only President of the Republic was William B. Ide, who played a central role during the bear flag revolt.

name: california
sentence: This American settler revolt served as a prelude to the subsequent American military invasion of California and was closely coordinated with neighbouring American military commanders.

name: california
sentence: The Republic of California is short-lived.

name: california
sentence: When Commodore John D. Sloat of the U.S. Navy sailed into Monterey Bay and began the military occupation of California by the United States, Northern California capitulated the U.S. forces in less than a month.

name: california
sentence: After a series of defensive battles in southern California, the Cahuenga Treaty was signed by the Californians on January 13, 1847, thus ensuring American control in California.

name: california
sentence: Following the treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo (2 Feb. 1848), which ended the war, the westernmost part of the annexed Mexican territory of Alta California soon became the American state of California, and the rest of the former territory was further subdivided into new American territories of Arizona, Nevada, Colorado and Utah.

name: california
sentence: The lower even more sparsely populated and arid region of the former Baja California remained a part of Mexico.

sentence: Shortly thereafter, a massive influx of immigration to the region followed, with prospectors and miners arriving by thousands.

sentence: California is the third largest state in the United States, after Alaska and Texas.

sentence: California is often geographically divided into two regions, Southern California, which includes the 10 most southern counties, and Northern California, which includes the 48 most northern counties.

name: california
sentence: It is bordered by Oregon to the north, Nevada to the east and northeast, Arizona to the southeast, the Pacific Ocean to the west, and shares an international border with the Mexican state of Baja California to the south (with which it is part of the California region in North America, alongside Baja California Sur).

name: california
sentence: In the middle of the state is the central valley of California, bounded by the Sierra Nevada to the east, the coastal mountain ranges to the west, the Cascade Range to the north and the Tehachapi Mountains to the south.

sentence: The Central Valley is the heart of California's productive agriculture.

name: california
sentence: Divided in two by the delta of the Sacramento-San Joaquin River, northern part, the Sacramento Valley serves as a watershed of the Sacramento River, while the southern part, the San Joaquin Valley, is the watershed of the San Joaquin River.

name: california
sentence: The Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta is an essential water supply centre for the State.

sentence: Delta water supplies drinking water to nearly 23 million people, nearly two thirds of the population of the state, and water to farmers on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley.

name: california
sentence: Maritime moderation means that the summer temperatures of Los Angeles and San Francisco are the coolest in all major metropolitan areas of the United States and are particularly cool compared to areas on the same latitude within and on the east coast of the North American continent.

name: california

sentence: California is one of the richest and most diverse regions in the world, and includes some of the most threatened ecological communities.

name: california

name: california
sentence: The large number of endemic species in California includes relic species that have died elsewhere, such as the iron wood Catalina (Lyonothamnus floribundus).

name: colorado
sentence: Colorado (other variants) is a state in the western United States that encompasses most of the southern Rocky Mountains as well as the northeastern portion of the Colorado Plateau and the western boundary of the Great Plains.

name: colorado
sentence: It is the 8th largest and 21st most populous U.S. state.

name: colorado
sentence: Colorado's population is estimated at 5,758,736 in 2019, an increase of 14.5% since the 2010 United States Census.

name: colorado
sentence: The area has been inhabited by Native Americans for more than 13,000 years, the Lindenmeier site containing artifacts dating from approximately 9200 B.C. to 1000 B.C.; the eastern edge of the Rocky Mountains has been an important migratory route for the first peoples that have spread throughout the Americas.

name: colorado
sentence: The state was named for the Colorado River, which the first Spanish explorers named the Río Colorado ("Red River") for the red silt that the river carried mountains.

name: colorado
sentence: The territory of Colorado was organized on February 28, 1861, and on August 1, 1876, US President Ulysses S. Grant signed Proclamation 230 admitting Colorado to the Union as the 38th state.

name: colorado
sentence: Colorado is nicknamed the "State of the Centennial" because it became a state a century after the signing of the Declaration of Independence of the United States.

name: colorado
sentence: Colorado is bordered by Wyoming in the north, Nebraska in the northeast, Kansas in the east, Oklahoma in the southeast, New Mexico in the south, Utah in the west and Arizona in the southwest, at the Four Corners.

name: colorado
sentence: Colorado is known for its rich landscape of mountains, forests, high plains, mesas, canyons, plateaus, rivers, and desert lands.

sentence: Colorado is one of the mountain states of the United States and is part of the western and southwestern parts of the United States.

sentence: State residents are known as Coloradans, although the former term "Coloradoan" is sometimes used.

name: colorado
sentence: The main components of the economy include government and defence, mining, agriculture, tourism, and more and more other types of manufacturing.

name: colorado
sentence: With rising temperatures and reduced water availability, Colorado's agricultural, forestry and tourism economies are expected to be strongly affected by climate change.

name: colorado
sentence: Colorado is notable for its diverse geography, which includes alpine mountains, high plains, deserts with huge sand dunes, and deep canyons.

name: colorado
sentence: In 1861, the U.S. Congress defined the boundaries of the new territory of Colorado exclusively by lines of latitude and longitude, ranging from 37°N to 41°N latitude, and from 102°02′48′′W to 109°02′48′′W longitude (25°W to 32°W of the Washington Meridian).

name: colorado
sentence: After 159 years of government investigations, Colorado's borders are now formally defined by 697 bounds and 697 straight lines of demarcation.

name: colorado
sentence: Colorado, Wyoming and Utah are the only states to have their borders defined only by straight boundaries without natural characteristics.

name: colorado
sentence: The southwestern corner of Colorado is the Four Corners Monument at 36°59′56′′N, 109°2′43′′W.

name: colorado

sentence: This area flows east and south-east, either through the Mississippi River or the Rio Grande, in the Gulf of Mexico.
