name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire () is a state in the northeastern United States of America.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is bordered by Massachusetts in the south, Vermont in the west, Maine and the Atlantic Ocean in the east, and the Canadian province of Quebec in the north.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is the 5th smallest by region and the 10th least populated American state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Concord is the capital of the state, while Manchester is the biggest city.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has no general sales tax, or income tax other than interest and dividends.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire primary is the first primary in the U.S. presidential election cycle.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its license plates bear the motto of the State, "Live Free or Die".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state nickname, "The Granite State", refers to its vast granite formations and quarries.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In January 1776 it became the first colony in British North America to establish a government independent of the authority of the Kingdom of Great Britain; it was the first to establish its own state constitution.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Six months later, it became one of the first 13 colonies that signed the United States Declaration of Independence and, in June 1788, it was the ninth state to ratify the United States Constitution, which gave effect to that document.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Historically, New Hampshire was an important centre for the manufacture of textiles, footwear and paper, with Amoskeag Manufacturing Company in Manchester at one time given the largest textile cotton factory in the world.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Many mills were located along various rivers in the state, especially the Merrimack and Connecticut rivers.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Many French Canadians migrated to New Hampshire to work the mills in the late 19th and early 20th centuries; New Hampshire still ranks second among the states by the percentage of people claiming French American ancestry, with 24.5% of the state identifying itself as such.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Manufacturing centres such as Manchester, Nashua and Berlin were hit hard in the 1930s and 1940s as the major manufacturing industries left New England and settled in the southern United States or abroad, reflecting national trends.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 1950s and 1960s, defence contractors moved into many old mills, such as Sanders Associates in Nashua; the population of southern New Hampshire increased from the 1980s as the major highways connecting the area to Greater Boston and established several community bedrooms in the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: With some of the highest ski mountains on the East Coast, New Hampshire's major recreational attractions include skiing, snowmobiles and other winter sports, hiking and mountaineering (Monadnock Mountain in the southwest corner of the state is one of the most climbing mountains in the United States), autumn foliage observation, summer cottages along many lakes and the sea coast, motorsports at the New Hampshire Motor Speedway, and Moto Week, a popular motorcycle rally that took place in Weirs Beach in June in Laconia.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountain National Forest connects the Vermont and Maine portions of the Appalachian Trail and has the automatic Mount Washington Road, where visitors can drive to the top of Mount Washington at 1,917 metres.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state was named after the south of the English county of Hampshire by Captain John Mason.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is one of six states in New England.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is bounded by Quebec, Canada, north and northwest, Maine and the Atlantic Ocean to the east, Massachusetts to the south, and Vermont to the west.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The main regions of New Hampshire are the Northern Grand Woods, the White Mountains, the Lakes Region, the French Riviera, the Merrimack Valley, the Monadnock Region and the Dartmouth-Lake Sunapee Region.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the shortest ocean coast of an American coastal state, with a length of 29 km, sometimes measured at only 33 km.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The range of White Mountains in New Hampshire covers the north-central part of the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The range includes Mount Washington, the highest in the northeastern United States – the site of the highest second wind speed ever recorded – as well as Mount Adams and Mount Jefferson.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: With strong winds of hurricanes every three days on average, more than a hundred deaths recorded among visitors, and visible krumholtz (dwarfs, matt trees like a bonsai carpet), the climate on the upper reaches of Mount Washington inspired the meteorological observatory on the summit to pretend that the region has the "worst time in the world".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountains house the rock formation known as the old mountain man, a profile similar to that of Franconia Notch, until the disintegration of the formation in May 2003.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Even after its loss, the old man remains a lasting symbol for the state, seen on state highway signs, car registration plates, and many governmental and private entities around New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the southwestern corner of New Hampshire, Mount Monadnock gave its name to a class of earth forms – a monadnock – indicating, in geomorphology, any isolated, resistant peak that rises from a less resilient eroded plain.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The major rivers include the Merrimack River (177 km), which crosses the lower half of the north-south state before passing through Massachusetts and reaching the sea at Newburyport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its tributaries include the Contoocook River, the Pemigewasset River, and the Winnipeasukee River.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 660-km Connecticut River, which begins at Connecticut Lakes in New Hampshire and flows south to Connecticut, defines the western boundary with Vermont.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state border is not at the centre of this river, as is usually the case, but at the low line on the Vermont side, that is, the entire river along the Vermont border (guarding areas where water levels have been raised by dam) is located in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Only one city — Pittsburg — shares a land border with the state of Vermont.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Connecticut's "northwest upstream waters" also define the portion of Canada-U.S.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: the border.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Piscataqua River and its various tributaries are the only important ocean port in the state where they discharge into the Atlantic at Portsmouth.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Salmon Falls River and the Piscataqua define the southern part of the border with Maine.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The border of the Piscataqua River was the subject of a border dispute between New Hampshire and Maine in 2001, and New Hampshire claimed dominance over several islands (mainly Seavey Island) including the Portsmouth shipyard.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2002, the United States Supreme Court dismissed the case, leaving property on the island in Maine.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, New Hampshire claimed the sovereignty of the base.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The largest of the lakes in New Hampshire is Lake Winnipesauke, which covers 71 square miles (184 km2) in the central east part of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Lake Umbagog along the Maine border, about 12.3 square miles (31.9 km2) is a second far away.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Lake Squam is the second largest lake entirely located in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the shortest ocean coast in any state in the United States, approximately 46 km long.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The beach of Hampton is a popular summer destination.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: About 11 km offshore are the islands of Shoals, nine small islands (including four in New Hampshire) known as the site of a 19th-century art colony founded by poet Celia Thaxter, and the presumed location of one of the buried treasures of Black Barbe pirate.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is the State that has the highest percentage of forested land in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is found in the biome of broad-leaved and mixed-leaved temperate forests.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Much of the state, particularly the White Mountains, is covered by conifers and deciduous forests in northern New England and Acadia.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The southeast corner of the state and the parts of the Connecticut River along the Vermont border are covered by mixed oaks from the northeast coastal forests.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The many forests of the state are popular among fall leaf drinkers in search of the bright foliage of the many deciduous trees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The northern third of the state is locally referred to as the "Northern Country" or "northern Notches", with reference to the White Mountain crossings as channel traffic.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It contains less than 5 per cent of the population of the State, suffers from relatively high poverty and regularly loses its population as the logging and paper industries decrease.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the tourism industry, particularly visitors to northern New Hampshire for skiing, snowboarding, hiking and mountain biking, has helped offset the economic losses caused by plant closures.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The duration of the winter season is expected to decrease in the New Hampshire ski resorts due to the effects of global warming, which is expected to continue the historical contraction and consolidation of the ski industry and threaten ski businesses and communities dependent on ski tourism.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a humid continental climate (classification of the climate of Köppen Dfa in some areas of the south, Dfb in most of the state and subarctic Dfc in some areas of the north of the highlands), with warm and humid summers and long, cold and snowy winters.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Precipitation is distributed fairly evenly throughout the year.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The climate in the southeast is moderated by the Atlantic Ocean and the average of relatively mild winters (for New Hampshire), while the northern and inner parts have cooler temperatures and lower humidity.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Winters are cold and snowy throughout the state, and particularly severe in northern and mountainous areas.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Average annual snowfall ranges from 60 inches (150 cm) to over 100 inches (250 cm) throughout the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The average of diurnal peaks between the mid-1970s and the lower 1980s (24–28°C) in the state as a whole in July, with nocturnal hollows in the mid-50s to the lower 1960s (13–15°C).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: January temperatures range from an average elevation of 34°F (1°C) on the coast to night temperatures below 0°F (−18°C) in the extreme north and at high altitudes.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Average annual precipitation at the state level is about 40 inches (100 cm) and some variations occur in the White Mountains due to differences in altitude and annual snowfall.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The highest temperature recorded in New Hampshire was 106°F (41°C) at Nashua on July 4, 1911, while the lowest recorded temperature was −47°F (−44°C) at the top of Mount Washington on January 29, 1934.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Mount Washington also saw an unofficial reading of -50°F (−46°C) on January 22, 1885, which, if made official, would link the historic record of New England (also -50°F (−46°C) to Big Black River, Maine, on January 16, 2009, and Bloomfield, Vermont, on December 30, 1933).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Extreme snow is often associated with a nor'easter, such as the 78 Blizzard and the 1993 Blizzard, when several feet accumulated through parts of the state over 24 to 48 hours.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Lighter snowfalls of several inches occur frequently throughout the winter, often associated with an Alberta clipper.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire, on occasion, is affected by hurricanes and tropical storms, although by the time they reach the state, they are often extratropical, with most storms hitting the southern coast of New England moving inside or offshore in the Gulf of Maine.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most storms in New Hampshire occur on average less than 20 days per year and two tornadoes occur each year across the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The map of the hardiness zones of the National Arbor Day Foundation illustrates areas 3, 4, 5 and 6 throughout the state and indicates the transition from a relatively cooler climate to a warmer climate when moving south across New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The hardiness zones of the 1990 USDA plants in New Hampshire range from zone 3b to zone 5b to the south.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The metropolitan areas of the New England area are defined by the U.S. Census Bureau as New England City and Town Areas (NECTAs).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Despite the same language, they had a culture and religion very different from those of other Algonquian peoples.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: English and French explorers visited New Hampshire in 1600–05 and David Thompson settled at Odiorne's Point in 1623.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The first permanent establishment was held at Hilton's Point (now Dover).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 1631, the superior plantation now included Dover, Durham and Stratham; in 1679, it became the "Royal Province."

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Father Rale's war was waged between the settlers and the Wabanaki Confederation throughout New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire was one of thirteen colonies that rebelled against British rule during the American Revolution.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: At the time of the American Revolution, New Hampshire was a divided province.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The economic and social life of the Seacoast region revolves around sawmills, shipyards, commercial warehouses and established urban centres.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Fortune merchants built important houses, provided them with the best luxuries, and invested their capital in land trading and speculation.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: At the other end of the social scale, there developed a permanent class of day labourers, sailors, contract servants and even slaves.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The only battle in New Hampshire was the raid on Fort William and Mary on 14 Dec. 1774 in Portsmouth Harbour, which defeated the rebellion in considerable quantities of powder, light weapons and cannons.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: (General Sullivan, the head of the attack, described him as "remarking powder, small arms, bayonets and canisters, as well as cannons and ammunition") over the course of two nights.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This raid was preceded by a warning to the local patriots the day before, by Paul Revere on December 13, 1774, that the fort was to be reinforced by troops from Boston.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to unverified accounts, gunpowder was then used at the Battle of Bunker Hill, carried there by Major Demerit, one of the many patriots in New Hampshire who stored the powder in their houses until it was transported elsewhere for use in revolutionary activities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: During the attack, British soldiers fired at the rebels with cannons and muskets.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Although there were apparently no casualties, they were among the first shots in the period of the American Revolution, occurring about five months before the battles of Lexington and Concord.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Constitution of the United States was ratified by New Hampshire on 21 June 1788, when New Hampshire became the ninth state to do so.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire was a Jamaican fortress.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Industrialization has taken the form of many textile factories, which in turn have attracted significant flows of immigrants from Quebec (the "French Canadians") and Ireland.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The northern regions of the state produced timber, and the mountains provided tourist attractions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: After 1960, the textile industry collapsed, but the economy bounced back as a centre of high technology and as a service provider.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Beginning in 1952, New Hampshire received national and international attention for its presidential primaries held at the beginning of each presidential election year.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It immediately became the most important test ground for Republican and democratic candidates.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The media gave New Hampshire and Iowa about half of all the attention given to all states in the primary process, magnifying the decision-making powers of the state and encouraging repeated efforts by non-state politicians to change the rules.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that New Hampshire's population was 1,359,711 on July 1, 2019, an increase of 3.28% since the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The population centre of New Hampshire is located in Merrimack County, Pembroke City.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The population centre has moved south of 19 km since 1950, reflecting the fact that the fastest growth of the state has been along its southern border, which is within the Boston Communication Area and other cities in Massachusetts.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The most densely populated areas are generally less than 80 km from the Massachusetts border and are concentrated in two areas: along the Merrimack Valley from Concord to Nashua, and in the sea area along an axis from Rochester to Portsmouth.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Outside these two regions, only one community, the town of Keene, has a population of more than 20,000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The four counties that cover these two regions represent 72 per cent of the population of the State and one (Hillsborough) represents nearly 30 per cent of the population of the State, as well as the two most populated communities, Manchester and Nashua.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The northern part of the State is very sparsely populated: the largest county per region, Coos, covers the northern quarter of the State and has only about 31,000 inhabitants, about one third of whom live in a single community (Berlin).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Trends over the past few decades have been for the population to move south, as many northern communities do not have the economic basis to maintain their population, while southern communities have been absorbed by Greater Boston.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of the 2010 census, the population of New Hampshire was 1,316,470.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The gender composition of the Government is 49.3 per cent for men and 50.7 per cent for women.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: 21.8% of the population were under the age of 18.

sentence: The racial composition of New Hampshire at the time of the 2010 Census was as follows:

sentence: Hispanics or Latinos, regardless of race, accounted for 2.8 per cent of the population in 2010: 0.6 per cent were of Mexican origin, 0.9 per cent were Puerto Rican, 0.1 per cent were Cuban and 1.2 per cent were Hispanic or Latin.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the American Community Survey 2012–2017, the largest ancestry groups in the state were Irish (20.6%), English (16.5%), French (14.0%), Italian (10.4%), German (9.1%), French Canadians (8.9%) and Americans (4.8%).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the highest percentage (22.9%) of residents of French, French-Canadian and Acadian descent from any state in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to estimates from the American Community Survey of the Census Bureau from 2017, 2.1% of the population aged 5 years and older speak Spanish at home, while 1.8% speak French.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In Coos County, 9.6% of the population speak French at home, down from 16% in 2000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Note: The percentages in the table do not add up to 100, because Hispanics are counted both by ethnicity and race, giving a higher overall number.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A Pew survey showed that the religious affiliations of New Hampshire residents were: Protestants 30%, Catholics 26%, LDS (Mormon) 1%, Jews 1%, Jehovah's Witnesses 2% and non-religious 36%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A survey suggests that people in New Hampshire and Vermont are less likely than other Americans to attend weekly service and only 54% say they are "absolutely certain that there is a God" compared to 71% in the rest of the nation.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire and Vermont are also at the lowest levels among states committed to religion.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2012, 23% of New Hampshire residents in a Gallup poll considered themselves to be "very religious", while 52% considered themselves "non-religious".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), the largest denominations are the Catholic Church with 31,028 members, the United Church of Christ with 26,321 members and the United Methodist Church with 18,029 members.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2016, a Gallup Poll found New Hampshire to be the least religious in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Only 20% of New Hampshire respondents considered themselves to be "very religious", while the national average was 40%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates that New Hampshire's total revenue was $86 billion in 2018, ranking 40th in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The median household income in 2017 was 74,801, the fourth highest in the country (including Washington, D.C.).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its agricultural production is dairy products, nurseries, cattle, apples and eggs.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its industrial output is machinery, electrical equipment, rubber and plastic products, and tourism is a major component of the economy.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire experienced a major change in its economic base in the 20th century.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Historically, the base was made up of New England's traditional textiles, footwear manufacturing and small machine shops, taking advantage of low-wage labour from nearby small farms and parts of Quebec.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Today, of the total value of the state's manufacturing dollar, these sectors contribute only 2% for textiles, 2% for leather goods and 9% for machining.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: They have experienced a sharp decline due to obsolete plants and the attractiveness of cheaper wages in the southern United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire now has a broad-based and growing economy, with a government GDP growth rate of 2.2% in 2018.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The government's main economic sectors in 2018, based on its contribution to GDP, are: 15% of real estate and leasing and leasing; 13% of professional business services; 12% of manufacturing; 10% of government and government services; and 9% of health and social services.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state budget for the 2018 fiscal year was $5.97 billion, including $1.79 billion in federal funds.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The tax issue is controversial in New Hampshire, which has a property tax (under municipal control) but no sales tax or income tax.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State has tighter taxes on meals, housing, vehicles, business and investment income, and tolls on state roads.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Energy Information Administration, New Hampshire's energy consumption and per capita energy consumption are among the lowest in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Seabrook Nuclear Generating Station, near Portsmouth, is the largest nuclear reactor in New England, providing 57% of New Hampshire's electricity generation and 27% of its electricity consumption in 2017.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2016 and 2017, New Hampshire obtained more wind power than coal-fired power plants.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Approximately 32% of New Hampshire's electricity consumption came from renewable resources (including nuclear, hydro, wind and other renewable resources).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a net exporter of electricity, exporting 63 trillion UK thermal units (18 TWh).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's residential electricity consumption is low compared to the national average, partly because the demand for air conditioning is low during the generally mild summer months and because few households use electricity as a primary energy source for domestic heating.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Nearly half of New Hampshire's households use fuel oil for winter heating, which is one of the largest shares in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has renewable energy potential such as wind, hydro and wood fuel.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State does not have a general sales tax or personal income tax (the State taxes, at a rate of 5%, income from dividends and interest), and the legislator has shown tax withholding.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Efforts to diversify the general economy of the State are continuing.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The lack of a general tax system in New Hampshire has led local communities in the state to have some of the country's highest property taxes.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the overall tax burden of the State is relatively low; in 2010, New Hampshire ranked 44th among States in terms of the combined average tax burden of States and local authorities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In February 2010, the state unemployment rate was 7.1%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: By October 2010, the unemployment rate had fallen to 5.4 per cent.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The seasonal (preliminary) unemployment rate in April 2019 was 2.4% based on a civilian workforce of 767,500 people, with 749,000 active people.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's workforce is 90 per cent in non-agricultural employment, 18 per cent in trade, transport and public services, 17 per cent in education and health care, 12 per cent in government, 11 per cent in professional and business services, and 10 per cent in recreation and hospitality.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to a 2013 study by Phoenix Marketing International, New Hampshire had the eighth highest percentage of millionaire households in the United States, accounting for 6.48% of all households.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2013, New Hampshire also recorded the lowest poverty rate in the country, at only 8.7 per cent of all residents, according to the Census Bureau.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In March 2018, 86% of New Hampshire's workforce was employed by the private sector, with 53% of these workers employed by companies with fewer than 100 employees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: About 14 per cent of employees in the private sector are employed by companies with more than 1,000 employees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to Community surveys conducted by the NH's Labour Market and Employment Security Information Bureau, the most important private employers in the State are:

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State Government of New Hampshire employs about 6,100 people.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In addition, the United States Department of State employs approximately 1,600 people at the Portsmouth National Visa Centre, which processes visa applications for immigrants from the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Governor of New Hampshire, since 5 January 2017, is Chris Sununu (Republican).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The two American senators from New Hampshire are Jeanne Shaheen and Maggie Hassan (the two Democrats), both of whom are former governors.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The two U.S. representatives of New Hampshire from January 2019 onwards are Chris Pappas and Ann McLane Kuster (the two Democrats).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a state of control over alcoholic beverages, and through the State Alcohol Board, it takes $100 million from the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is the only state in the United States that does not require adults to wear safety belts on their vehicles.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This is one of the three states that do not have a mandatory helmet law.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Constitution of the State of New Hampshire of 1783 is the supreme law of the State, followed by the revised Annotated New Hampshire Statutes and the New Hampshire Code of Administrative Rules.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: These provisions are roughly similar to those of the United States Federal Constitution, the United States Code and the Code of Federal Regulations, respectively.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a bifurcated executive power, composed of the governor and a five-member executive council that votes on government contracts worth more than $5,000 and "advises and consents" to the governor's appointments to important state positions such as department heads, all judge functions and all pardon applications.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire does not have a Lieutenant Governor; the Speaker acts as "interim Governor" whenever the Governor is unable to discharge his or her duties.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The legislative power is called the Tribunal.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is composed of the House of Representatives and the Senator.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There are 400 representatives, making them one of the most important elected bodies in the English-speaking world, and 24 senators.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Legislators receive a nominal salary of $200 per year, the lowest in the United States by far, so that most are indeed volunteers, nearly half of whom are retirees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: (For more details, see the article on the New Hampshire Government.)

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The only court of appeal in the state is the Supreme Court of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Superior Court is the court of general jurisdiction and the only court which provides for jury trials in civil or criminal cases.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Other State courts are the Probation Court, the District Court and the Family Division.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There are 10 counties and 234 cities in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a "Dillon Rule" state, i.e. the state retains all powers not expressly granted to municipalities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Despite this, the legislative branch is strongly in favour of local control, particularly with regard to land-use regulations.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The municipalities of New Hampshire are classified as cities or towns, which differ mainly in the form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most cities usually operate according to the form of government of municipal assemblies, where registered voters in the city act as municipal legislatures, and a selection board acts as the city's executive.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The large cities and the thirteen cities of the state operate either in the form of a council (manager or council) or in the form of a mayor.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There is no difference, from the point of view of state government, between cities and cities outside the form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: All state laws treat all municipalities in the same way.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a small number of unincorporated areas known as grants, locations, purchases or cantons.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: These locations are limited to the lack of self-government, and services are generally provided by neighbouring cities or the county or state if necessary.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2000 census, there were 25 persons left in New Hampshire, with a total population of 173 (in 2000); several were completely depopulated.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: All but two of these areas are located in Coos County.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democratic Party and the Republican Party are the two largest parties in the State.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A plurality of electors are registered as unregistered, and can choose one or the other vote in primary school, and then regain their undeclared status after voting.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The libertarian party had the status of an official party between 1990 and 1996.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There is also a program known as the Free State project to transform New Hampshire into a libertarian fortress by suggesting that libertarians move there to concentrate their power.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The libertarian party regained access to the ballot papers after the 2016 election because the candidate for the post of governor obtained more than 4% of the vote.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of 5 February 2016, there were 88,2959 registered voters, of whom 389,472 (44.1%) had not declared affiliation to a political party, 262,111 (29.7%) were Republicans and 231,376 (26.2%) were Democrats.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is internationally recognized for the primary school in New Hampshire, the first primary in the quadrennial cycle of the US presidential elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The law of the State requires that the Secretary of State organize this election at least a week before any "similar event".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the Iowa caucus preceded the New Hampshire primary.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This first competition, which uses the same procedure as the general election, attracts more attention than in other States, and it has been decisive in the development of the national competition.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: State law allows a city with less than 100 residents to open its polling stations at midnight and close its offices when all registered citizens have voted.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: For example, the communities of Dixville Notch in Coos County and Hart's in Carroll County, among others, chose to implement these provisions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Dixville Notch and Hart's Location are traditionally the first places in New Hampshire and the United States to vote in the primary and presidential elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Appointments for all other partisan offices are decided at separate primary elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In presidential election cycles, this is the second primary election held in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Saint Anselm College in Goffstown has become a popular campaign place for politicians as well as several national presidential debates due to its proximity to Manchester-Boston Regional Airport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the past, New Hampshire had often voted republican.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Between 1856 and 1988, New Hampshire voted six times for the Democratic presidential ticket: Woodrow Wilson (twice), Franklin D. Roosevelt (three times) and Lyndon B. Johnson (once).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: From 1992 onwards, New Hampshire became a state in the national and local elections and, at that time, supported the Democrats in all presidential elections, with the exception of 2000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It was the only state in the country to move from the support of Republican George W. Bush in the 2000 elections to the support of his democratic challenger in the 2004 elections, when John Kerry, a senator from nearby Massachusetts, won the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats dominated the elections in New Hampshire in 2006 and 2008.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2006, the Democrats won the two seats of the Congress (elected Carol Shea-Porter in the first district and Paul Hodes in the second), re-elected Governor John Lynch and won a majority on the Executive Council and in both chambers for the first time since 1911.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats had not held both the legislature and the post of governor since 1874.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Neither senator in the United States was a candidate for a vote in 2006.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2008, the Democrats retained their majorities, their government and their seats in Congress; and former Governor Jeanne Shaheen defeated outgoing Republican John E. Sununu for the American Senator in a retake of the 2002 competition.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 2008 elections allowed women to hold a majority, 13 of the 24 seats, in New Hampshire Senatte, a first for any legislative body in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the mid-term elections of 2010, the Republicans made historic gains in New Hampshire, capturing veto-proof majorities in the state's legislature, taking the five seats on the Executive Council, electing a new US senator, Kelly Ayotte, winning both seats in the US Chamber of Deputies, and reducing the margin of victory of outgoing Governor John Lynch over his 2006 and 2008 victories.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2012 general election, the Democrats took over the House of Representatives of New Hampshire and reduced the Republican majority in the New Hampshire Senate to 13-11.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2012, New Hampshire became the first state in the history of the United States to elect an entirely female federal delegation: Carol Shea-Porter, Congressional District 1 Democratic MP, and Ann McLane Kuster, Congressional District 2 MP, accompanied the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Senators Jeanne Shaheen and Kelly Ayotte in 2013.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In addition, the state elected its second female governor: the Democratic Maggie Hassan.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2014 election, the Republicans took over the House of Representatives of New Hampshire with a majority of 239 to 160 votes and increased their majority in the New Hampshire Senate to 14 of the 24 seats in the Senate.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: At the national level, outgoing senator Jeanne Shaheen beat her Republican challenger, former Massachusetts senator Scott Brown.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire also elected Frank Guinta (R) for its first Congressional district representative and Ann Kuster (D) for its second Congressional district representative.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2016 election, the Republicans held the House of Representatives of New Hampshire with a majority of 220 to 175, and held their 14 seats in New Hampshire Senator.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the gibernatory race, outgoing governor Maggie Hassan was replaced by Republican Chris Sununu, who defeated democratic candidate Colin Van Ostern.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Sununu became the first Republican state governor since Craig Benson, who left his post in 2005 after John Lynch's defeat.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Republicans control the governor's office and the two chambers of the state legislature, a government trifecta in which the Republicans have the full power of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the presidential race, the state voted for the Democratic candidate, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on the Republican candidate, Donald Trump, by a margin of 2,736 votes, or 0.3%, one of the closest results the state has ever seen in a presidential race, while libertarian candidate Gary Johnson obtained 4.12% of the vote.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats have also won a competitive race in the second district of Congress, as well as a race in the Senate.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The delegation of New Hampshire is currently composed exclusively of democrats.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: At the 116th Congress of the United States, it is one of the only eight states with a fully democratic delegation, five of which are in New England (the others are Delaware, Hawaii and New Mexico).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a well-maintained and well-signed network of inter-state highways, U.S. highways and state highways.

sentence: New Hampshire has 25 public airports, three of which are served by regular commercial passenger transport services.

sentence: The busiest airport is Manchester-Boston, Manchester, and Londonderry, which serves the Greater Boston metropolitan area.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Amtrak's Vermonter and Downeester lines provide toll rail passenger service.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Greyhound, Concord Coach, Vermont Translines and Dartmouth Coach all provide interurban connections to and from points in New Hampshire and to long-distance points beyond and between them.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2013, the Boston-based MBTA Commuter Rail service reached only northern Massachusetts.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire Rail Transit Authority is working to expand the Lowell Capital Corridor (Massachusetts) service to Nashua, Concord and Manchester, including the Manchester-Boston Regional Airport; and the Haverhill Coastal Corridor (Massachusetts) service to Plaistow, New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 2007 legislation created the New Hampshire Rail Transit Authority (NHRTA) to oversee the development of suburban trains in the state of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2011, Governor John Lynch vetoed HB 218, a bill passed by Republican legislators, which would have considerably reduced the powers and responsibilities of NHRTA.

sentence: The I-93 corridor study suggested a rail alternative along the Manchester and Lawrence branch lines, which could provide freight and passenger services.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This railway corridor would also have access to Manchester-Boston Regional Airport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Eleven public transport authorities operate local and regional bus services throughout the State, and eight private carriers operate express bus services that connect the national long distance bus network.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire Department of Transportation operates a state-wide match-sharing service, in addition to an independent travel matching program and a guaranteed return program.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The tourist railways include Conway Scenic Railroad, Hobo-Winnipesaukee Railroad and Mount Washington Cog Railway.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's freight lines include Claremont & Concord Railroad (CCRR), Pan Am Railways via Springfield Terminal Railway (ST), New England Central Railroad (NHR, St. Lawrence and Atlantic Railroad (SLR) and New Hampshire Northcoast Corporation (NHN).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The first public secondary schools in the State were the secondary school for boys and the secondary school for girls in Portsmouth, founded in 1827 or 1830 according to the source.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has more than 80 public high schools, many of which serve more than one city.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The largest is Pinkerton Academy in Derry, which is owned by a private not-for-profit organization and serves as a public high school in a number of nearby cities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There are at least 30 private high schools in the State.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire also houses prestigious university-preparatory schools, such as Phillips Exeter Academy, St. Paul's School, Proctor Academy, Brewster Academy and Kimball Union Academy.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2008, the state tied up with Massachusetts as having the highest scores on the SAT and ACT standardized tests given to high school students.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The following sports teams are located in New Hampshire:

sentence: Loudon's New Hampshire Motor Speedway is an oval circuit that has been visited by national motorsport championship series such as NASCAR Cup Series, NASCAR Xfinity Series, NASCAR Camping World Truck Series, NASCAR Wholen Modified Tour, American Canadian Tour (ACT), Champ Car and IndyCar Series.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Other racing sites include Star Speedway and New England Dragway in Epping, Lee Speedway in Lee, Twin State Speedway in Claremont, Monadnock Speedway in Winchester and Canaan Fair Speedway in Canaan.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has two universities competing at NCAA Division I in all college sports: Dartmouth Big Green (Ivy League) and New Hampshire Wildcats (America East Conference), as well as three NCAA Division II teams: Franklin Pierce Ravens, Saint Anselm Hawks and Southern New Hampshire Penmen (Northeast-10 Conference).

name: new_hampshire

sentence: Peterborough Players have been performing every summer in Peterborough since 1933.

sentence: In winter, the ski resorts and snowmobile trails in New Hampshire attract visitors to a vast area.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Funspot, the largest video arcade in the world (now called a museum), is located in Laconia.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's eminent personalities include founding father Nicholas Gilman, Senator Daniel Webster, revolutionary war hero John Stark, publisher Horace Greeley, founder of Christian science religion Mary Baker Eddy, poet Robert Frost, astronaut Alan Shepard, rock musician Ronnie James Dio, author Dan Brown, actor Adam Sandler, inventor Dean Kamen, actors Sarah Silverman and Seth Meyers, restorers Richard and Maurice McDonald, and President Franklin Pierce of the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is a state in the Mid-Atlantic region of the northeastern United States of America.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is bordered to the north and east by New York State, to the east, south-east and south by the Atlantic Ocean, to the west by the Delaware River and Pennsylvania, and to the southwest by Delaware Bay and Delaware State.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the fourth smallest state by region, but the 11th most populous, with 8,882,190 residents in 2019 and an area of 8,722.58 square miles, making it the most populous of the 50 U.S. states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The capital is Trenton, while the largest city is Newark.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All but one of the counties in New Jersey are in the combined statistical areas of New York City or Philadelphia; therefore, the largest metropolitan area of the state is in Greater New York.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was inhabited for the first time by Amerindians for at least 2,800 years, with Lenape as the dominant group at the time of the arrival of Europeans in the early 17th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Dutch and Swedish settlers founded the first European settlements in the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The British then took control of the area, naming it Province of New Jersey – after the largest of the Channel Islands, Jersey – and granting it as a colony to Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley, 1st Baron Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was the scene of several major battles during the American Revolution War.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 19th century, the factories of the "six largest" cities of Camden, Paterson, Newark, Trenton, Jersey City and Elizabeth contributed to the country's industrial revolution.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The central location of New Jersey in the northeastern megalopolis fuelled its rapid growth and suburbanization in the second half of the 20th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: At the turn of the twenty-first century, the state economy became increasingly diverse, while its multicultural population began to return to more urban environments within the state, surpassing the growth of the suburbs since 2008.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2020, New Jersey had the largest number of millionaires per capita in all U.S. states, with 9.76% of households — more than 323,000 out of 3.3 million — meeting the criteria.

name: new_jersey
sentence: According to 2017 data, it was the second poorest U.S. state in the median household income.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's public school system is consistently ranked among the 50 states in the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Approximately 180 million years ago, during the Jurassic period, New Jersey bordered North Africa.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The pressure of the North American-African collision caused the Appalachians.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About 18,000 years ago, the ice age led to glaciers reaching New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As the glaciers retreated, they left Lake Passaic behind, as well as many rivers, marshes and gorges.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Originally, New Jersey was established by Native Americans, with Lenni-Lenape dominant at the time of contact.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Scheyichbi is the name Lenape for the land which is now New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Lenapes were several self-governing groups engaged in corn farming to complete their hunting and harvesting in the area surrounding the Delaware River, Lower Hudson and Western Long Island Strait.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Lenape society was divided into matrilineal clans based on common female ancestors.

name: new_jersey
sentence: These clans were organized into three distinct phratries identified by their animal sign: the turtle, Turkey, and the wolf.

name: new_jersey
sentence: They first met the Dutch at the beginning of the seventeenth century, and their main relationship with Europeans was the fur trade.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch became the first European to claim land in New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Dutch colony of New Netherlands consisted of parts of modern states in the Middle Atlantic.

name: new_jersey

sentence: New Jersey's judiciary is unusual in that it still has separate courts of law and fairness, such as its neighbour Delaware, but unlike most other American states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Superior Court of New Jersey is divided into the Law and Chancery Divisions at trial level; the Law Division hears both criminal and civil cases where the plaintiff's main remedy is damages, while the Chancery Division hears family cases, civil suits where the plaintiff's main remedy is a fair remedy, and trials under consideration.

sentence: The Superior Court also has an Appeals Chamber, which operates as the State Intermediate Court of Appeal.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Second, the 1923 Municipal Director Act, which provided for a non-partisan council, provided for a weak mayor elected by and among the members of the council, and introduced a government structure to manage municipal affairs with a manager appointed for day-to-day administration.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Faulkner Act, passed in 1950 and largely amended in 1981, provides for four basic plans: the mayor-counsel, the council-manager, the small municipality and the mayor-counsel-manager.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Act offers many choices to communities that prefer strong executive and professional management of municipal affairs and provides great flexibility to allow municipalities to choose the characteristics of their government: the number of seats on the council; the seats selected in general, by neighbourhoods or by a combination of the two; staggered or concurrent mandates; and a mayor chosen by the council or directly elected by voters.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is a state in the northeastern United States of America.

sentence: It was one of the thirteen original colonies, forming the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: With a total area of 54,555 square miles (141,300 km2), New York is the 27th largest state.

sentence: Its population of more than 19 million in 2019 makes it the fourth most populous population.

name: new_york
sentence: Sometimes called the State of New York, it's the home of New York City.

sentence: Two thirds of the population of the state live in the New York metropolitan area.

sentence: With an estimated population of 8.34 million in 2019, New York City is the most populated city in the United States and the first gateway to immigration to the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: The metropolitan area of New York is one of the most populous in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: As a world city, New York City is home to the United Nations Headquarters and has been described as the world's largest cultural, financial and media capital, as well as the most economically powerful city in the world.

sentence: The state's four most populated cities are Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers and Syracuse, while the state's capital is Albany.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has a diversified geography.

sentence: The state is bordered by New Jersey and Pennsylvania in the south and Connecticut, Massachusetts and Vermont in the east.

sentence: The state has a maritime border with Rhode Island, east of Long Island, as well as an international border with the Canadian provinces of Quebec to the north and Ontario to the northwest.

sentence: New York was inhabited by tribes of Algonquian and Iroquoian Amerindians for several hundred years when the first Europeans arrived in New York.

sentence: French settlers and Jesuit missionaries came from southern Montreal to trade and proselytize.

sentence: England took over the colony of the Dutch in 1664.

sentence: During the American Revolutionary War (1775-1783), a group of settlers from New York Province attempted to take control of the British colony and subsequently succeeded in establishing independence.
