sentence: According to the American Community Survey, New York also had the largest Greek American population of 148,637 people (0.7% of the state).

name: new_york
sentence: In Buffalo and western New York, the Germans are the greatest ancestors.

name: new_york
sentence: In Northern New York, French Canadians represent the main ethnic group, given the proximity of the region to Quebec.

name: new_york
sentence: Americans of English ancestry are present throughout northern New York State, reflecting the first colonial immigrants and later.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, the most commonly spoken American English dialects in New York, in addition to American general English, were the dialect of the New York area (including New York Latino English and Northern Jersey English), the accent of Western New England around Albany, and the English language of northern interior America in Buffalo and western New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: Up to 800 languages are spoken in New York City, making it the most linguistic city in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, 70.72% (12,788,233) of New York residents aged five and over reported speaking only English at home, while 14.44 % (2,611,903) spoke Spanish, 2.61% (472,955) Chinese (which includes Cantonese and Mandarin), 1.2 % (216,468) Russian, 1.18% (213,785) Italian, 0.79% (142,169) French Creole, 0.75% (135,789) French, 0.67% (121,917) Yiddish, 0.63% (114,574) Korean and Polish were spoken by 0.53% (95,413) of the population over five years of age.

name: new_york
sentence: A total of 29.28 per cent (5295,016) of New York City's population aged five and over reported speaking a language other than English.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the American Community Survey 2017, nearly six million residents speak a language other than English.

name: new_york
sentence: About 1,249,541 New York residents spoke Spanish, 386,290 Chinese, 122,150 Russian, 63,615 Haitian Creoles, 62,219 Bengali and 60,405 Koreans.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2018, 12,756,975 people aged 5 years and older spoke only English and 10,415,395 people aged 18 years and older spoke only English.

name: new_york
sentence: The majority of Spanish-speaking households are not English-speaking.

name: new_york
sentence: It is estimated that 2.7 million households with residents aged 5 years and older spoke Spanish.

name: new_york
sentence: Chinese, Slavic and French languages were the most important languages spoken by households in 2018.

name: new_york
sentence: The majority of New York's religious population is Christian (60%), followed by irreligious (27%), Judaism (7 %), Islam (2 %), Buddhism and Hinduism (1% each) and other denominations (0.5%).

name: new_york
sentence: Before the 1800s Protestant sects dominated New York's religious life, although religion did not play as important a role in New Zealand's public life as in New England, with its Puritan population.

name: new_york
sentence: Historically, New York served as the foundation for new Christian denominations in the second great awakening.

name: new_york
sentence: Non-Western Christian traditions and non-Christian religions did not grow for much of the State's history because immigration was mainly from Western Europe (which was then dominated by Western Christianity and favoured by quotas in the Federal Immigration Act).

name: new_york
sentence: The Immigration and Nationality Act 1965 abolished quotas, allowing the growth of other religious groups.

name: new_york
sentence: The Catholic Church is New York's largest Christian denomination (31%).

name: new_york
sentence: The largest Roman Catholic diocese is the Archdiocese of the Latin Church in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The largest Catholic diocese in the east is the Ruthenian Catholic Eparchy of Passaic of the Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church.

name: new_york
sentence: The United Methodist Church is the largest main Protestant denomination and the second most important on the whole, followed by the Episcopal Church in the United States and other continuing Anglican organizations.

name: new_york
sentence: The following major denominations were the Presbyterian Church (USA), the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America and the American Baptist Church.

name: new_york
sentence: The main Protestants together account for 11% of the state's Christians.

name: new_york
sentence: In evangelical Protestantism Baptists, non-denominational Protestants and Pentecostals were the largest groups.

name: new_york
sentence: The National Baptist Convention (USA) and the Progressive National Baptist Convention were the largest Protestant churches in the black history of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: About 10% of New York Christians are Protestant evangelicals.

name: new_york
sentence: Eastern Orthodox and Eastern Orthodox made up 1% of the religious population along with Jehovah's Witnesses and other Christians.

name: new_york
sentence: Non-Christian religions represented 12% of the religious population.

name: new_york
sentence: Judaism is the second most important religion since 2014.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, 588,500 men practised Orthodox Judaism.

name: new_york
sentence: A little over 392,953 professed Islam.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is home to the oldest fire temple of Zoroastrian in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Less than 1% of New York's population practice New Age and contemporary paganism.

name: new_york
sentence: Amerindian religions are also a significant minority.

name: new_york
sentence: Irreligious is a growing community in the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: At the state level, 17% do nothing in particular and 5% are atheistic and agnostic.

name: new_york
sentence: Approximately 3.8 per cent of the adult population in the state identifies as lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender.

name: new_york
sentence: This represents a total of 570,388 LGBT adults.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, the number of same-sex households was about 48,932.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the fifth state to allow same-sex marriages, after New Hampshire.

name: new_york
sentence: Michael Bloomberg, Mayor of New York, said that "same-sex marriages in New York generated approximately $259 million in economic impact and $16 million in municipal revenue" in the first year after the passage of the Marriage Equality Act.

name: new_york
sentence: Same-sex marriages in New York were legalized on 24 June 2011 and were allowed to commence 30 days thereafter.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is also home to the largest transgender population in the United States, estimated at 25,000 in 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: The annual New York Pride March (or gay pride parade) crosses 5th Avenue in Manhattan, ending at Greenwich Village, and rivals the Sao Paulo Gay Pride Parade as the largest pride parade in the world, attracting tens of thousands of participants and millions of spectators on the sidewalks every June.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stonewall riots were a series of spontaneous and violent protests by members of the gay community against a police raid that took place in the early morning of June 28, 1969 at Stonewall Inn, Greenwich Village, Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: They are generally considered the most important event leading to the gay liberation movement and the modern struggle for LGBT rights.

name: new_york
sentence: In June 2017, plans were announced for the first official LGBT monument commissioned by the State of New York, unlike the Stonewall National Monument, commissioned by the U.S. federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: The State Monument should be built in Hudson River Park in Manhattan, near the Hudson River wharves, which have been important historical symbols of New York's central role as a meeting place and refuge for LGBT communities.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, the state of New York also planned to host the largest international celebration of LGBT pride in 2019, known as Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019, to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall riots.

name: new_york
sentence: In New York, the 2019 Stonewall 50–WorldPride NYC events produced by Heritage of Pride were enhanced through a partnership with the LGBT division of the I LOVE NY program and included a welcome centre during the weeks surrounding the Stonewall 50 / WorldPride events, which was open to all.

name: new_york
sentence: Other commemorative, cultural and educational arts programs to mark the 50th anniversary of the rebellion at Stonewall Inn took place throughout the city and around the world; Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019 was the largest celebration of LGBT pride in history, attracting approximately five million people.

name: new_york
sentence: Brooklyn Liberation March, the largest event on transgender rights in LGBTQ history, took place on June 14, 2020, from Grand Army Plaza to Fort Greene, Brooklyn, and focused on supporting the lives of black transgenderers, attracting between 15,000 and 20,000 participants.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's gross national product in 2018 was $1.7 trillion.

name: new_york
sentence: If the state of New York were an independent nation, it would be the 11th largest economy in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: However, in 2013, the multi-state metropolitan statistical area, centred on the city of New York, produced a gross metropolitan product (GMP) of nearly $1.4 trillion, while in 2012, the corresponding combined statistical area produced a GMP of more than $1.7 trillion, both of which ranked first in the country with a wide margin and behind the GDP of only nine countries.

name: new_york
sentence: Anchored by Wall Street in the Financial District of Lower Manhattan, New York City has been called both the most economically powerful city and the largest financial centre in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: Lower Manhattan is the third largest business district in the United States and is home to the New York Stock Exchange at Wall Street and NASDAQ at 165 Broadway, representing respectively the largest and second largest stock exchanges in the world, as measured by both the average volume of daily transactions and the total market capitalization of their listed companies in 2013.

name: new_york
sentence: The investment bank charges on Wall Street amounted to approximately $40 billion in 2012, while in 2013, the senior management of New York banks managing the risk management and compliance functions earned up to $324,000 per year.

name: new_york
sentence: During the 2013–14 fiscal year, the Wall Street securities industry generated 19% of New York's tax revenues.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City remains the world's largest trading centre in public capital and debt markets, partly driven by the size and financial development of the U.S. economy.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also a leader in the management of hedge funds

name: new_york
sentence: Several investment banks and investment managers headquartered in Manhattan are major participants in other global financial centres.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also the main commercial banking centre in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the largest media conglomerates in the world are also based in the city.

name: new_york
sentence: Manhattan had about 520 million square feet (48.1 million square feet) of office space in 2013, making it the largest office market in the United States, while Midtown Manhattan is the largest business district in the country.

name: new_york
sentence: Silicon Alley, centered in New York, has become a metanym of the sphere encompassing the high-tech and entrepreneurship ecosystem of the New York metropolitan area; in 2015, Silicon Alley generated more than $7.3 billion in venture capital investments.

name: new_york
sentence: High-tech industries, including digital media, biotechnology, software development, game design and other areas of information technology, are growing, supported by New York's position at the terminus of several transatlantic fibre optic lines, its intellectual capital, as well as its open-air wireless connectivity.

name: new_york
sentence: In December 2014, the State of New York announced a $50 million venture capital fund to encourage companies working in biotechnology and advanced materials; according to Governor Andrew Cuomo, seed money would help entrepreneurs market their research.

name: new_york
sentence: On December 19, 2011, then Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his choice of Cornell University and Technion-Israel Institute of Technology to build a $2 billion college of applied science on Roosevelt Island in Manhattan to transform New York into the world's first technological capital.

name: new_york
sentence: Albany, Saratoga County, Rensselaer County, and the Hudson Valley, collectively recognized as the Eastern New York Technology Valley, have experienced significant growth in high-tech computer hardware, with major advances in nanotechnology, digital electronics design, and the manufacture of microchip integrated circuits dependent on water and electricity, including companies such as IBM and its Thomas J. Watson Research Center, as well as the three foreign companies, GlobalFoundries, Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor.

name: new_york
sentence: The region's high-tech ecosystem is supported by technology-based academic institutions, including the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and SUNY Polytechnic Institute.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2015, Tech Valley, which straddles both sides of the Adirondack Northway and New York Thruway, generated more than $163 million in venture capital investments.

name: new_york
sentence: The Rochester region is important in the field of photographic processing and imaging as well as in the incubation of an increasingly diverse high-tech sphere encompassing STEM domains, as well as the results of private start-up companies working with major academic institutions, including the University of Rochester and Cornell University.

name: new_york
sentence: Westchester County developed a growing biotechnology sector in the 21st century, with more than $1 billion in private investment expected from 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: Creative industries, which generate and disseminate knowledge and information, such as new media, digital media, film and television production, advertising, fashion, design and architecture, account for an increasing share of employment, with the City of New York having a significant competitive advantage in these industries.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2014, the State of New York offered tax incentives of up to $420 million per year for the production of films within the state, the most generous tax rebate among the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also attracted more visual effects jobs by further increasing its tax credit to a maximum of 35% for post-film production in Upstate New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The filmed entertainment industry grew in New York, contributing nearly $9 billion to the New York economy in 2015.

name: new_york
sentence: I Love New York is a slogan, logo and state song that form the basis of an advertising campaign and has been used since 1977 to promote tourism in New York State, including New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: The brand's logo belongs to the New York State Empire State Development.

name: new_york
sentence: The Broadway League reported that Broadway's programming sold approximately $1.27 billion in tickets for the 2013–14 season, up 11.4% from $1.39 billion for the 2012–13 season.

name: new_york
sentence: The participation in 2013–14 was $12.21 million, an increase of 5.5% over the $11.57 million in the 2012–13 season.

name: new_york
sentence: New York exports a wide variety of products such as prepared foods, computers and electronics, cut diamonds and other products.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2007, the Government exported a total of $71.1 billion in goods, with Canada ($15 billion), Switzerland ($5.9 billion), Israel ($4.9 billion) and Hong Kong ($3.4 billion) the five largest foreign export markets.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's largest imports are oil, gold, aluminum, natural gas, electricity, rough diamonds and softwood lumber.

name: new_york
sentence: The state also has a large manufacturing sector that includes clothing printing and production, primarily in New York; and furs, railway equipment, automotive parts and bus line vehicles, concentrated in Upstate areas.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the third largest producer of grapes in the country and the second largest producer of wine in volume, behind California.

name: new_york
sentence: The hills of South Finger Lakes, the Hudson Valley, the Northern Long Island fork and the southern shore of Lake Erie are the main wine-growing and wine-growing areas of New York, with many vineyards.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2012, New York had 320 wineries and 37,000 hectares of vines, generating full-time jobs for nearly 25,000 people and annual wages above $1.1 billion, and producing $4.8 billion in direct economic impact of New York grapes, grape juice and wine and grape products.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's agricultural industry is one of the largest producers overall, ranking among the top five countries for agricultural products, including maple syrup, apples, cherries, cabbage, dairy products, onions and potatoes.

name: new_york
sentence: The State is the largest cabbage producer in the United States

name: new_york
sentence: The state owns about a quarter of its agricultural land and produced $3.4 billion in agricultural products in 2001.

name: new_york
sentence: The southern shore of Lake Ontario provides the right mix of soils and microclimates for many apple orchards, cherries, plums, pears and peaches.

name: new_york
sentence: Apples are also cultivated in the Hudson Valley and near Lake Champlain.

name: new_york
sentence: A commercial medium-sized saltwater fishery is located along the Atlantic side of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: The main catch is clams, lobsters, squid and plaice.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, New York State consumed 156,370 gigawatt hours (GWh) of electric energy.

name: new_york
sentence: Lower-state areas (Hudson Valley, New York and Long Island) consumed 66% of this amount.

name: new_york
sentence: The outermost regions generated 50% of this amount.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, the maximum load was 29 699 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: The capacity of resources in 2017 was 42,839 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: The NYISO Market Monitor described the overall average electricity price as a range (a single value was not provided) from $25 per MWh to $53 per MWh for 2017.

name: new_york
sentence: At the post-secondary level, the State's public university system is the State University of New York (SUNY).

name: new_york
sentence: The SUNY system consists of 64 community colleges, technical colleges, undergraduate colleges and doctoral institutions, including several universities.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's flagship university is Buffalo University, which was founded by U.S. President Billard Fillmore.

name: new_york
sentence: Along with Buffalo University, Binghamton University is also ranked high in the rankings of the best public universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City has its own City University of New York (CUNY), which is funded by the city.

name: new_york
sentence: Columbia University, Cornell University and New York University are among the largest institutions of higher education in New York, all world-renowned private universities and members of the Association of American Universities, the first group of research universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Other large private universities include Syracuse University and Fordham University.

name: new_york
sentence: The smallest private institutions of higher education are Rockefeller University, Mercy College, the New York Institute of Technology, the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Yeshiva University and Hofstra University.

name: new_york
sentence: There are also a multitude of graduate schools in New York State, including schools of medicine, law and engineering.

name: new_york
sentence: West Point, the U.S. Army Service Academy, is located just south of Newburgh, on the west bank of the Hudson River.

name: new_york
sentence: The Federal Merchant Marine Academy is located at Kings Point on Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: A number of private, selective liberal arts establishments are located in New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: They include Bard College, Barnard College, Colgate University, Hamilton College, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Marist College, Sarah Lawrence College, Skidmore College, Union College and Vassar College.

name: new_york
sentence: Two of these schools, Barnard and Vassar, are members of the Seven Sisters elite, all originally women's schools with links to the Ivy League.

name: new_york
sentence: Barnard is affiliated with Columbia University, its neighbour in Manhattan, and Vassar became a co-educator in 1969 after declining a merger offer with Yale University.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also houses what is widely regarded as the best art school in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The Juilliard School, located in Manhattan's Upper West Side, is one of the world's leading schools of music and dance.

name: new_york
sentence: The Eastman School of Music, a professional school at the University of Rochester, has been ranked first among American music schools by US News & World Report for five consecutive years.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State University accredits and establishes standards for primary, middle and secondary education in the State, while the New York State Department of Education supervises public schools and monitors their standard examinations.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York Department of Education operates the New York public school system.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1894, reflecting general racial discrimination, the State passed a law enabling communities to establish separate schools for children of African-American descent.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1900, the State passed another law requiring integrated schools.

name: new_york
sentence: In fiscal year 2013, New York spent more money on public education per student than any other state, according to United States Census Bureau statistics.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has one of the largest and oldest transport infrastructure in the country.

name: new_york
sentence: The engineering problems posed by the complex terrain of the State and the unique infrastructure problems of the city of New York, caused by urban congestion, had to be overcome on a permanent basis.

name: new_york
sentence: The population expansion of the state followed the trail of the first waterways, first the Hudson River and the Mohawk River, then the Erie Canal.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 19th century, railways were built along the river valleys, followed by the New York State Thruway in the 20th century.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Department of Transport (NYSDOT) is the Department of the Government of New York responsible for the establishment and operation of roads, railways, public transport systems, ports, waterways and air facilities in New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: NYSDOT's head office is located at 50 Wolf Road, Colonie, Albany County.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York and New Jersey Port Authority (PANYNJ) is a joint venture between the States of New York and New Jersey and authorized by the American Congress, established in 1921 through an inter-State pact, which oversees much of the regional transportation infrastructure, including bridges, tunnels, airports and seaports, within the geographic jurisdiction of the Port of New York and New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: This 1500 square mile port area (3,900 km2) is generally covered within 25 miles (40 km) of the National Monument of the Statue of Liberty.

name: new_york
sentence: The Port Authority's headquarters are located at the 4 World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition to the well-known New York Metro system, which is confined to the city of New York, four suburban rail networks enter and exit the city: the Long Island Railway, the Metro-North Railway, the Trans-Hudson Port Authority and five of the New Jersey Transit rail lines.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Department of Transportation (NYCDOT) is the New York City government agency responsible for the management of much of New York's transportation infrastructure.

name: new_york
sentence: Other cities in New York have urban and regional public transportation.

name: new_york
sentence: In Buffalo, the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority manages Buffalo Metro Rail's light rail network; in Rochester, Rochester Metro operated from 1927 to 1956, but became obsolete as the state and the federal government invested in highways.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Motor Vehicle Department (NYSDMV or DMV) is the government agency responsible for the registration and inspection of motor vehicles and other motor vehicles, as well as the licensing of drivers in New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2008, NYSDMV had 11,284,546 driving licences and 10,697,644 vehicle registrations in force.

name: new_york
sentence: All gasoline vehicles registered in New York State must undergo an emission inspection every 12 months to ensure that environmental quality controls prevent air pollution.

name: new_york
sentence: Diesel-powered vehicles with a gross mass of more than 8,500 pounds that are registered in most of the counties of Downstate New York are subject to an annual emission inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: All vehicles registered in New York State must undergo an annual safety inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: Portions of the transportation system are intermodal, allowing passengers to easily move from one mode of transport to another.

name: new_york
sentence: One of the most notable examples is AirTrain JFK, which allows rail travellers to travel directly to the John F. Kennedy International Airport terminals and to the New York Underground Metro.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York Government embodies the Government structure of the State of New York established by the Constitution of the State of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: It consists of three branches: executive, legislative and judicial.

name: new_york
sentence: The Governor is the head of State administration and is assisted by the Lieutenant Governor.

name: new_york
sentence: Both are elected on the same note.

name: new_york
sentence: Other elected officials include the Attorney General and the Controller.

name: new_york
sentence: The Secretary of State, former elected member, is currently appointed by the Governor.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Legislature is bicameral and consists of the New York State Senator and the New York State Assembly.

name: new_york
sentence: The Assembly consists of 150 members, while the Senate varies in its membership, which currently has 63 members.

name: new_york
sentence: The legislature has the power to make laws, subject to the Governor's power to veto a bill.

name: new_york
sentence: However, the right of veto may be exceeded by the legislator if there is a two-thirds majority in favour of exceeding in each chamber.

name: new_york
sentence: Permanent laws of a general character are codified in the unified laws of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The highest court of appeal in the unified justice system is the Court of Appeal, while the first court of first instance is the County Court (or the Supreme Court in New York).

name: new_york
sentence: The Supreme Court also acts as an intermediate court of appeal for many cases, and the local courts deal with a variety of other issues, including small disputes, contraventions and local zoning issues, and are the starting point for all criminal cases.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Courts are the largest system of local courts.

name: new_york
sentence: The State is divided into counties, cities, towns and villages, all of which are municipal corporations vis-à-vis their own governments, as well as various corporations that serve for single purposes that are also local governments, such as school districts, fire districts and public utility corporations of New York State, often known as development authorities or corporations.

name: new_york
sentence: Each municipal corporation has different home government powers, as provided for in the New York Constitution.

name: new_york
sentence: The State also has 10 Indian reserves.

name: new_york
sentence: There have been several movements concerning the secession of the State of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Proposals include a State of Long Island, consisting of everything on the island outside New York; a State called Niagara, the counties of western New York State; the counties of northern New York State called Upstate New York; making New York City a State; a proposal for a new County of Peconic in eastern Long Island; and for the borough of Staten Island to leave New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The death penalty was reintroduced in 1995 under the Pataki administration, but the law was declared unconstitutional in 2004, when the New York Court of Appeal ruled in People v. LaValle that it violated the Constitution of the State.

name: new_york
sentence: The remaining death penalty was commuted by the court to life imprisonment in 2007, in People v. John Taylor, and death row was dissolved in 2008, under an order made by Governor David Paterson.

name: new_york
sentence: No executions have occurred in New York since 1963.

name: new_york
sentence: Legislative efforts to amend the law had failed, and the death penalty was no longer required at the state level, although certain crimes falling within the federal government's jurisdiction were punishable by the federal death penalty.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is represented by Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: There are twenty-seven congress districts, the third largest number of congress districts in the country, equal to Florida and behind California's 53 and 36.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2019, 21 districts are represented by members of the Democratic Party, and 6 are represented by Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Representation was reduced from 29 in 2013 due to the slowdown in the overall population growth of the state compared to the overall national population growth.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has 29 votes in the national presidential elections, down from its 47-vote summit from 1933 to 1953.

name: new_york
sentence: The government has a significant imbalance in payments with the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the New York State Comptroller's Office, New York received 91 cents of services for every dollar it sent to the United States federal government in fiscal year 2013; New York ranked 46th in the federal balance of payments to the state on a per capita basis.

name: new_york
sentence: In April 2016, the Democrats represented a plurality of voters in New York State, representing more than twice as many registered voters as any other affiliation or absence of a political party.

name: new_york
sentence: Since the second half of the 20th century, New York has generally supported Democratic Party candidates in national elections.

name: new_york
sentence: Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama won New York State by more than 25 percentage points in 2012 and 2008.

name: new_york
sentence: New York, as well as other major cities in the state, including Albany, Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers and Syracuse, are important democratic strongholds, with liberal politics.

name: new_york
sentence: However, New York's rural areas are generally more conservative than cities and tend to favour Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Suburban, densely populated areas, such as Westchester County and Long Island, have crossed major parties since the 1980s, but most often they support the Democrats.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the largest source of political fundraising in the United States for the two main parties.

name: new_york
sentence: Four of the country's top five zip codes for political contributions are in Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: The top postal code, 10021 on the Upper East Side, generated the most money for George W. Bush and Al Gore's 2000 presidential campaigns.

name: new_york
sentence: The State of New York has the distinction of being the State of origin of the two main parties appointed in three presidential elections.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1904 presidential election saw former New York governor and outgoing president Theodore Roosevelt face Alton B. Parker, Chief Justice of the New York Court of Appeal.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1944 presidential election had Franklin D. Roosevelt, following in the footsteps of his cousin Theodore as former governor of New York and outgoing president for the re-election against the current governor of New York Thomas E. Dewey.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 2016 presidential election, the former U.S. Senator of New York Hillary Clinton, resident of Chappaqua, was the Democratic Party candidate.

name: new_york
sentence: The Republican Party candidate was the businessman Donald Trump, a Manhattan resident and a Queens native.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is an important centre for international diplomacy.

name: new_york

name: north_carolina

sentence: The colony's population more than quadrupled from 52,000 in 1740 to 270,000 in 1780 with high immigration from Virginia, Maryland and Pennsylvania, as well as immigrants from abroad.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Differences in settlement patterns in eastern and western North Carolina, or Tidewater and the highlands, have affected the political, economic and social life of the state from the 18th to the 20th century.

sentence: The Tidewater, located in eastern North Carolina, has been established mainly by immigrants from rural England and Scottish Highlands.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Arriving from the middle to the end of the 18th century, Scots-Irish of what is now Northern Ireland were the largest group of non-English immigrants before the Revolution; the majority of English-contracted servants were the largest group of immigrants before the Revolution.

sentence: During the American Revolutionary War, British Scots and the Eastern Highlands of North Carolina tended to remain loyal to the British Crown due to long-standing commercial and personal ties with Britain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the collapse of Confederation in 1865, North Carolina, together with the rest of the former Confederate states, was placed under the direct control of the American army and was relieved of its constitutional government and its representation in the United States Congress in what is now known as the era of reconstruction.

name: north_carolina

name: north_carolina

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has three major geographic areas: the Atlantic coastal plain, which occupies the eastern part of the state, the central Piedmont region, and the western mountainous region, which is part of the Appalachians.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain consists of more specifically defined areas such as the outer shores, a chain of sandy and narrow islands separated from the mainland by sounds or inlets, including the Albemarle Strait and Pamlico Strait, the tidal waters region, the home of the venous flyer and the inland coastal plain, where long-leaved pines are native.

sentence: The Piedmont region of central North Carolina is the most populated region of the state, which contains the six largest cities in the state by population.

sentence: It consists of a gently sloping countryside often broken by hills or low mountain ridges.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Small isolated and deeply eroded mountain ranges and peaks are located in Piedmont, including the Sauratown Mountains, Pilot Mountain, Uwharrie Mountains, Crowder's Mountain, King's Pinnacle Mountains, Brossy Mountains and the South Mountains.

sentence: Elevation above sea level is the main cause of temperature change throughout the state, the mountainous region being the coldest all year round.

sentence: The climate is also influenced by the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf Stream, especially in the coastal plain.

sentence: The Atlantic Ocean has less influence on the climate of the Piedmont region, which has warmer summers and colder winters than along the coast, although the average daily maximum is still below 90°F (32°C) in most locations.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina experiences severe weather both in summer and winter, with the threat of hurricanes, tropical storms, heavy rains and floods.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is a state of the Midwest of the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It bears the names of the indigenous tribes Lakota and Dakota Sioux, which constitute a large part of the population and historically dominate the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the nineteenth largest in the region, the fourth least populated, and the fourth least populated among the 50 States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its capital is Bismarck, and its largest town is Fargo.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was admitted to the Union on 2 November 1889, together with its neighbouring state, South Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They were the 39th and 40th States admitted to the union.

name: north_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison changed the state documents before signing them so that no one would know who became a state first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For convenience, both states are numbered alphabetically.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, the natural resources of North Dakota played a major role in its economic performance, particularly with the extraction of oil from the Bakken Formation, located under the north-western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This has led to population growth and a reduction in unemployment, which has led North Dakota to the second lowest unemployment rate in the country (after Hawaii).

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is home to the highest man-made structure in the Western Hemisphere, the KVLY-TV mast.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located in the U.S. High Midwest.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is located in the middle of the North American continent and borders Canada to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The geographic centre of North America is close to the city of Center.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck is the capital of North Dakota and Fargo is the largest city in the country.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Land is the most valuable resource in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This is the foundation of the state's great agricultural wealth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota also has enormous mineral resources.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These mineral resources include billions of tonnes of lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, North Dakota has large oil reserves.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Oil was discovered in the state in 1951 and quickly became one of the most precious mineral resources in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 2000s, the emergence of hydraulic fracturing technologies enabled mining companies to extract huge amounts of oil from the formation of Bakken shale rocks in the western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota economy is based more heavily on agriculture than most other states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many North Dakota plants manufacture agricultural products or farm equipment.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many state merchants are also dependent on agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Farms and ranches cover almost all parts of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They extend from the flat valley of the Red River to the east, through the hilly plains, to the rugged Badlands to the west.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The main crop, wheat, is grown in almost every county.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota harvests more than 90 per cent of canola and flaxseed from the nation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is also the leading national producer of barley and sunflower seeds and a leader in the production of beans, honey, lentils, oats, peas and sugar beets.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Few white settlers came to the North Dakota area before the 1870s because the railways had not yet entered the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 1870s, the North Pacific Railway began crossing Dakota territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Large-scale agriculture also started in the 1870s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Eastern societies and some families have established huge wheat farms covering vast areas in the Red River Valley.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The farms made huge profits as they were called Bonanza Farms.

name: north_dakota
sentence: White settlers, attracted by the success of the bonanza farms, flocked to North Dakota, rapidly increasing the territory's population.

name: north_dakota
sentence: By 1870, there were 2,405 people in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: By 1890, the population had increased to 190,983 inhabitants.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has been named for the Sioux who once lived in the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Sioux were called Dakota or Lakota, meaning allies or friends.

name: north_dakota
sentence: One of the nicknames of North Dakota is the state of the Garden of Peace.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This nickname pays tribute to the International Garden of Peace, which is located on the state border with Manitoba, in Canada.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is also called the state of Flickr because of the many land squirrels (Richardson land squirrels) that live in the central part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located in the U.S. region known as Great Plains.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state shares the Northern Red River with Minnesota to the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is located to the south, Montana to the west, and the Canadian provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located near the centre of North America, with a stone marker in Rugby, North Dakota, which marks the "Geographic Centre of the North American Continent."

name: north_dakota
sentence: With an area of 70,762 square miles (183,273 km2) of which 178,712 square kilometres are land, North Dakota is the 19th largest state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The western half of the state consists of the hilly Great Plains and the northern portion of the Badlands, which are west of the Missouri River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The highest point of the state, White Butte at 306 feet (1,069 m), and Theodore Roosevelt National Park are in the Badlands.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The region is rich in fossil fuels, including natural gas, crude oil and lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River forms Sakakawea Lake, the third largest artificial lake in the United States, behind the Garrison Dam.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The central area of the state is divided between the Drift Prairie and the Missouri Plateau.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The eastern part of the state consists of the flat valley of the Red River, the bottom of glacial lake Agassiz.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its fertile soil, drained by the meander of the Red River flowing north into Lake Winnipeg, supports an important agricultural industry.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Lake Devils, the largest natural lake in the state, is also to the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The majority of the state is covered by grasslands

name: north_dakota
sentence: Natural trees are usually found in North Dakota where there is good drainage, such as the ravines and valley near Pembina Gorge and Killdeer Mountains, Turtle Mountains, the hills around Devil Lake, in the McHenry County dune region in central North Dakota, and along the slopes of the Sheyenne Valley and Sheyenne Delta.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This diverse land supports almost 2,000 species of plants.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has a continental climate, with hot summers and cold winters.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Temperature differences are significant due to its remote interior position and being at the centre of the Northern Hemisphere, with approximately equal distances with the North Pole and the equator.

name: north_dakota
sentence: American Aboriginal peoples have been living in what is now North Dakota for thousands of years before the arrival of Europeans.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The known tribes included the Mandan people (about the 11th century), while the first Hidatsa group arrived a few hundred years later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Both gathered in villages on the tributaries of the Missouri River in what was to become the western centre of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Crow Indians travelled to the western plains to visit and trade with the related Hidatas after the split between them, probably in the 17th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Later came the divisions of the Dakota people — Lakota, Santee, and Yanktonai.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Assiniboine and the Crees of the Plains undertake journeys southward to the Indians of the village, either for trade or for war.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Shoshone Indians of Wyoming and Montana today may have carried out attacks on Indian enemies as far east as the Missouri.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A group of Cheyennes lived in a village of houses on the lower Sheyenne River (site Biesterfeldt) for decades in the 18th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As a result of the attacks by the Cree, Assiniboine and Chippewas armed with firearms, they left the area around 1780 and crossed Missouri some time later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A band of the few Indians of Sotaio lived east of Missouri and met the uprooted Cheyennes before the end of the century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They soon followed the Cheyennes across Missouri and lived among them south of Cannonball River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Finally, the Cheyennes and the Sutaio became a tribe and turned into buffalo hunters mounted with ranges mainly outside North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Before the middle of the 19th century, the Arikara entered the future southern state and joined the Mandan and Hidatsa.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Over time, a number of Indians have signed treaties with the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many treaties defined the territory of a particular tribe (see map).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The first European to reach the region was the French-Canadian merchant Pierre Gaultier, Sieur de La Vérendrye, who led a part of exploration and commerce in the villages of Mandan in 1738.

name: north_dakota
sentence: From 1762 to 1802, this region is part of the Spanish Louisiana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: American Europeans only settled in the Dakota territory until the end of the 19th century, when railways opened the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the advantage of land concession, they vigorously market their properties, exalting the region as the ideal for agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: On February 22, 1889, Congress passed an omnibus bill for North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington, entitled The Enabling Act of 1889 under the administration of President Grover Cleveland.

name: north_dakota
sentence: His successor, Benjamin Harrison, signed the proclamations which officially admitted North Dakota and South Dakota to the Union on November 2, 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The rivalry between the two new states presented a dilemma that had to be recognized first of all.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Harrison ordered Secretary of State James G. Blaine to mix the papers and obscure him, which he had signed first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The real order was not recorded, so no one knows which Dakotas were admitted first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, since North Dakota appears alphabetically in front of South Dakota, its proclamation was first published in the At Large Statutes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The carelessness among wheat producers, particularly among Norwegian immigrants, led to a populist political movement centered in the non-partisan League ("NPL") around the First World War.

name: north_dakota
sentence: NPL presented candidates on the Republican ticket (but merged with the Democratic Party after the Second World War).

name: north_dakota
sentence: He tried to isolate North Dakota from the power of banks and out-of-state corporations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition to founding the Bank of North Dakota and North Dakota Mill and Elevator (both are still in place), NPL established a state-owned railway line (later sold to Soo Line Railroad).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Anti-corporation laws virtually prohibited a company or bank from owning title to land delimited as agricultural land.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These laws, still in force today, after being confirmed by the state and federal courts, make it almost impossible to seize agricultural land, since even after the seizure, the title to property cannot be held by a bank or a mortgage company.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, the North Dakota Bank, with powers similar to those of a federal reserve branch bank, exercised its power to limit the issuance of sub-prime mortgages and their guarantee in the form of derivative instruments, thus preventing the collapse of housing prices in the state following the 2008 financial crisis.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The original Capitol of the state of North Dakota at Bismarck burned on the ground on December 28, 1930.

sentence: Western North Dakota experienced a boom in oil exploration in the late 1970s and early 1980s, with higher oil prices making development profitable.

sentence: For decades, the annual North Dakota murder rate and violent crime rate were consistently the lowest in the United States.

sentence: However, in recent years, although still below the national average, crime has increased significantly.

sentence: In 2016, the violent crime rate was three times higher than in 2004, and the increase occurred primarily in the late 2000s, coinciding with the oil boom era.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Workers in the oil boom cities were accused of much of the increase.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the North Dakota population was 762,062 as of 1 July 2019, an increase of 13.30 per cent over the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This makes North Dakota the State of the United States with the highest percentage of population growth since 2011.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is the fourth least populous state in the country; only Alaska, Vermont and Wyoming have fewer residents.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With less than 2,000 people in 1870, the population of North Dakota increased to nearly 680,000 in 1930.

sentence: Growth has then slowed and the population has fluctuated slightly over the past seven decades, reaching 617,761 at the 1970 census, compared to 642,200 at the 2000 census.

sentence: With the exception of Amerindians, the North Dakota population has a lower percentage of minorities than the country as a whole.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the second half of the 19th century and until the beginning of the 20th century, North Dakota, with much of the Midwest, experienced a massive influx of newcomers from the eastern United States and immigrants from Europe.

sentence: North Dakota is a popular destination known to immigrant farmers and workers in general and their families, mainly Norway, Iceland, Sweden, Germany and the United Kingdom.

sentence: But a period of higher rainfall ended, and many migrants failed in arid conditions.

sentence: Many family plots were too small to be successful.

sentence: Between the 1930s and the late 20th century, the North Dakota population gradually declined, interrupted by a few brief increases.

sentence: Young adults with university degrees were particularly likely to leave the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the advance of the process of mechanization of agricultural practices, and the environmental conditions requiring more important land to succeed in agriculture, subsistence farming has proved to be too risky for families.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many people moved to urban areas to find a job.

sentence: Since the end of the 20th century, one of the main causes of migration from North Dakota has been the lack of qualified jobs for university graduates.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The expansion of economic development programmes has been advocated to create skilled and high-tech jobs, but the effectiveness of these programmes has been discussed.

sentence: During the first decade of the twenty-first century, the population increased largely as a result of employment in the oil industry related to the development of tight oil fields (shale oil).

sentence: Elsewhere, the Amerindian population has increased, with some reserves attracting people to return from urban areas.

sentence: North Dakota is one of the highest places for refugee resettlement proportionately.

sentence: According to the U.S. Refugee Resettlement Office, in 2013-2014, "more than 68 refugees" per 100,000 North Dakota were settled in the state.

sentence: Fargo Mayor Mahoney said that acceptance of the largest number of refugees per capita should be celebrated given the benefits they bring to the State.

sentence: In 2015, Lutheran Social Services of North Dakota, the only government relocation agency, received federal funding of $458,090 to improve refugee services.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has the largest number of churches per capita.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, North Dakota has the highest percentage of church population in any state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to a 2001 survey, 35 per cent of the North Dakota population was Lutheran and 30 per cent Catholic.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The other religious groups represented were Methodists (7%), Baptists (6%), God's Assemblies (3%), Presbyterians (1.27%), and Jehovah's Witnesses (1%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Christians with or without denominational affiliations, including other Protestants and the Church of Jesus Christ of the Saints of the Last Days (LDS Church), totaled 3%, bringing the total Christian population to 86%.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There were approximately 920 Muslims and 730 Jews in the state in 2000.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Three per cent of respondents responded "without religion" to the survey and 6 per cent refused to respond.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The largest church bodies by the number of adherents in 2010 were the Roman Catholic Church with 167,349; the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America with 163,209; and the Lutheran Church - Synod of Missouri with 22,003.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2010, 94.86% (584,496) of North Dakotas over 5 years of age spoke English as their primary language.

name: north_dakota

name: north_dakota
sentence: 1.39% (8,593) spoke German, 1.37% (8,432) spoke Spanish and 0.30% (1,847) spoke Norwegian.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other spoken languages include Serbo-Croatian (0.19 per cent), Chinese and Japanese (0.15 per cent) and Amerindian languages and French (0.13 per cent).

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2000, 2.5% of the population spoke German in addition to English, reflecting immigration in the early 20th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, North Dakota has an increasing population of Amerindians, representing 5.44% of the population in 2010.

name: north_dakota
sentence: At the beginning of the 19th century, the territory was dominated by the Siwan people, whose territory extended west of the Great Lakes region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The word "Dakota" is a Sioux word (Lakota/Dakota) meaning "allies" or "friends".

name: north_dakota
sentence: The major historical tribal nations of or around North Dakota are Lakota and Dakota ("The Sioux Great Nation" or "Oceti Sakowin", i.e. the seven lights of the council), Blackfoot, Cheyenne, Chippewa (known as Ojibwe in Canada) and Mandan.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Federally recognized tribes have Indian reserves in the State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Social gatherings known as "powwows" (or wacipis in Lakota/Dakota) continue to be an important component of Amerindian culture and are held regularly throughout the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the history of the Amerindians, powwows were held, usually in spring, to rejoice at the beginning of the new life and the end of the winter cold.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These events brought together Amerindian tribes to sing and dance and allowed them to meet old friends and acquaintances, as well as to make new ones.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many pow-wows also have religious significance for some tribes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Today, Pow-wows are still part of the Native culture and are frequented by both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In North Dakota, the United Tribes International Powwow, held each month in September in the capital of Bismarck, is one of the largest powwows in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A pow wow is an opportunity for Native American parades and dancers in regalia, with many dance styles presented.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is traditional for male dancers to wear regalia decorated with pearls, feathers and eagle feathers; male grass dancers wear coloured fringes and fanciful male dancers wear vividly coloured feathers.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The dancers dance much more subtly than the male dancers.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fantasy dancers wear fabric, beaded moccasins and jewelry, while the jingle dancer wears a dress made of metal cones.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Intertribal dances during the pow-wow allow everyone (even the spectators) to participate in the dance.

name: north_dakota

sentence: Although less than 10 per cent of the population is employed in the agricultural sector, it remains an important part of the state economy.

sentence: With industrial agriculture, it ranks 9th for the value of crops and 18th for the total value of agricultural products sold.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Larger farms produce the most crops.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The proportion of people employed in agriculture is relatively high in the state: in 2008, only 2 to 3 per cent of the population of the United States was directly employed in agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has about 90% of its land on farms with 27.5 million acres (111,000 km2) of cultivated land, the third largest amount of land in the country.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Between 2002 and 2007, the total number of cultivated land increased by about 1 million acres (4,000 km2) and North Dakota was the only state to have experienced an increase.

name: north_dakota
sentence: During the same period, 1,800,000 acres (7,300 km2) were allocated to soybean and monoculture maize production, the largest change in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Farmers are concerned about too many monocultures because they put the economy at risk by insect or crop diseases that affect a large crop.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, this development has adversely affected wildlife and bird habitats, as well as ecosystem balance.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state is the largest producer in the U.S. of many grain grains, including barley (36% of the U.S. crop), durum (58%), hard red spring wheat (48%), oats (17%) and combined wheat of all types (15%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the second largest producer of buckwheat (20%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2007, maize became the largest crop produced by the state, although it accounted for only 2% of total US production.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Corn Belt extends to North Dakota, but is more on the edge of the area than in its centre.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Corn yields are high in the southeastern part of the State and lower in other parts of the State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Most cereals are grown for livestock feed.The state is the leading producer of many oilseeds, including 92% of canola cultivation in the United States, 94% of flax seeds, 53% of sunflower seeds, 18% of safflower seeds and 62% of mustard seeds.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Canola is suitable for cold winters and matures rapidly.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The by-product is a high protein feed.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soybeans are also an increasing crop, with an additional 400,000 acres (1,600 km2) planted between 2002 and 2007.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soybean is an important crop in the eastern part of the State, and cultivation is common in the south-eastern part of the State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soybeans were not grown at all in North Dakota in the 1940s, but have become particularly common since 1998.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In North Dakota, soybeans are expected to mature rapidly because of the relatively short growing season.

sentence: The government is also the largest producer of honey, peas and dried edible beans, lentils and the third largest potato producer.

sentence: Lignite coal reserves in western North Dakota are used to produce about 90% of the electricity consumed, and electricity is also exported to neighbouring states.

sentence: The oil was discovered near Tioga in 1951, producing 53 million barrels (8,400,000 m3) of oil per year in 1984.

sentence: Recoverable oil reserves have increased dramatically recently.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Bakken Formation's oil reserves may contain up to 400 billion barrels (6.4×1010 m3) of oil, 25 times more than the reserves of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A report published in April 2008 by the US Geological Survey estimates that the oil recoverable by current technology in Bakken's formation is two orders of magnitude less, in the range of 3 billion barrels (480×10^6 m3) to 4.3 billion barrels (680×10^6 m3), with an average of 3.65 billion barrels (580×10^6 m3).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The north-western part of the state is the centre of the North Dakota oil boom.

sentence: The communities of Williston, Tioga, Stanley and Minot-Burlington are experiencing rapid growth that places a strain on housing and local services.

sentence: In 2012, the State was the second largest oil producer in the United States, with an average of 575,490 barrels per day.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Great Plains region, which includes the State of North Dakota, has been called "Saudi Arabia's Wind Energy".

sentence: Wind energy development in North Dakota has been cost-effective because the state has large rural areas and the wind speed is rarely less than 10 mph.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is considered the least visited state, in part because it does not have a significant tourist attraction.

sentence: Nevertheless, tourism is the third largest industry in North Dakota, contributing more than $3 billion annually to the government economy.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Outdoor attractions such as the 144-mile Maah Daah Hey Trail and activities like fishing and hunting attract visitors.

sentence: Transportation in North Dakota is overseen by the North Dakota Department of Transportation.

sentence: The main interstate highways are Interstate 29 and Interstate 94, with I-29 and I-94 meeting in Fargo, with I-29 facing north to south along the eastern boundary of the state, and I-94 bisecting the east to west state between Minnesota and Montana.

sentence: A unique feature of the North Dakota interstate highway network is almost entirely paved with concrete, not black roof, due to extreme weather conditions.
