name: north_dakota
sentence: The main airports in North Dakota are Fargo Hector International Airport (FAR), Grand Forks International Airport (GFK), Bismarck Municipal Airport (BIS), Minot International Airport (MOT) and Williston Basin International Airport (XWA).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Empire Builder of Amtrak crosses North Dakota, making stops at Fargo (2:13 am westbound, 3:35 am eastbound), Grand Forks (4:52 am westbound, 12:57 am eastbound), Minot (about 9 am westbound and around 21:30 pm eastbound), and four other stations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the descendant of the famous line of the same name run by the Great Northern Railway, which was built by the tycoon James J. Hill and ran from St. Paul to Seattle.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The long distance bus service is provided by Greyhound and Jefferson Lines.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public transit in North Dakota includes daily fixed-way bus systems in Fargo, Bismarck-Mandan, Grand Forks and Minot, public transit services in 57 communities, and multi-count rural public transit systems.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As with the U.S. federal government, the political power in the state government of North Dakota is divided into three branches: executive, legislative and judicial.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Constitution of North Dakota and the North Dakota Century Code form the official law of the State

name: north_dakota
sentence: The executive is headed by the elected governor.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The current governor is Doug Burgum, a Republican who took office on December 15, 2016, after his predecessor, Jack Dalrymple, did not seek re-election.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The current Lieutenant Governor of North Dakota is Brent Sanford, who is also the Speaker of the Senator.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The positions of governor and lieutenant governor have four-year terms, which are then for election in 2024.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Governor has a cabinet made up of officials appointed from various government agencies, known as commissioners.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The other elected constitutional posts are the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, the Auditor of State and the Treasurer of State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota Legislative Assembly is a bicameral body composed of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The State has 47 districts, each with one senator and two representatives.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Senators and their representatives are elected for a four-year term.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state's legal code is called the North Dakota Century Code.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota justice system consists of four levels.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Municipal courts serve cities and most cases start in district courts, which are courts of general jurisdiction.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are 42 district court judges in seven judicial districts.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Appeals from the courts of first instance and challenges to certain government decisions are heard by the North Dakota Court of Appeal, composed of three judges.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota Supreme Court hears all appeals from district courts and the Court of Appeal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Historically, North Dakota was populated by the Mandan, Hidatsa, Lakota and Ojibwe, followed by the Sanish and Métis.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Today, five tribes recognized by the federal government within the boundaries of North Dakota have independent and sovereign relations with the federal government and territorial reserves:

name: north_dakota
sentence: The U.S. Senators of North Dakota are John Hoeven (R) and Kevin Cramer (R).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The State has a large congressional district represented by representative Kelly Armstrong (R).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Federal court cases are heard by the United States District Court for the North Dakota District, based in Bismarck, Fargo, Grand Forks and Minot.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The appeals are heard by the Court of Appeal for the eighth electoral district, established in St. Louis, Missouri.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The major political parties in North Dakota are the Democratic Democratic Party and the Republican Party.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Since 2007, the Constitutional Party and the Libertarian Party have also been organized parties in the State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: At the state level, the government has been held by the Republican Party since 1992, at the same time as the majority of deputies and state officials.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Dem-NPL's protests were strong in the 2000 governor's race and in the 2006 general election, but the League has not seen a major breakthrough since the administration of former state governor George Sinner.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Republican Party's presidential candidate generally holds the state; in 2004, George W. Bush won with 62.9% of the vote.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of all the candidates for the democratic presidency since 1892, only Grover Cleveland (1892, one of the three votes), Woodrow Wilson (1912 and 1916), Franklin D. Roosevelt (1932 and 1936) and Lyndon B. Johnson (1964) received votes from the North Dakota Electoral College.

name: north_dakota
sentence: On the other hand, Dem-NPL's candidates for the seats of Senator and MP for North Dakota won all elections between 1982 and 2008, and the federal government delegation was fully democratic from 1987 to 2011.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, the present two United States of America

name: north_dakota
sentence: Senators John Hoeven and Kevin Cramer are Republicans, as is the only member of the House, Kelly Armstrong.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The income tax structure of North Dakota is slightly progressive; the five bands of government income tax rates are 1.1%, 2.04%, 2.27%, 2.64% and 2.90% in 2017.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2005, North Dakota ranked 22nd in terms of per capita taxes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota sales tax is 5% for most items.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The State authorizes municipalities to introduce local sales taxes and special local taxes, such as the 1.75% additional sales tax in Grand Forks.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Excise taxes are levied on the purchase price or the market value of aircraft registered in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Crown imposes a user tax on goods purchased elsewhere but used in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Property owners in North Dakota pay property taxes to their county, municipality, school district and special tax districts.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Tax Foundation classifies North Dakota as the state with the 20th most favourable tax climate for businesses in the nation.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The day of tax freedom arrives on April 1, 10 days earlier than the national day of tax freedom.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2006, North Dakota was the country where the number of returns filed by taxpayers with adjusted gross income of more than $1 million was the lowest, or only 333.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of the 762,062 people in North Dakota, 56.54 per cent live in one of the 15 most populated cities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fargo is the largest city in North Dakota and is the economic hub of the region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck, in south-central North Dakota, along the shores of Missouri, has been the capital of North Dakota since 1883, first as the capital of Dakota territory, then as the capital of the state since 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Minot is a town in northern North Dakota, home to North Dakota State Fair and Norsk Høstfest.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A few miles west of Bismarck, on the west side of the Missouri River, the city of Mandan was named in honour of the Mandan Indians who lived in the area at the time of the Lewis and Clark expedition.

name: north_dakota
sentence: New Salem is the site of the biggest statue of a holstein cow in the world.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Grand Forks Lake and Devils Lake are located in picturesque areas of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: West Fargo, North Dakota's fifth largest city, is one of the fastest growing cities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: and has been recognized as a playful city USA by KaBOOM!

name: north_dakota
sentence: Williston is near the confluence of the Missouri River and the Yellowstone River near Montana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Medora in North Dakota Badlands hosts the Medora Musical every summer and is the gateway to Theodore Roosevelt National Park.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fort Yates, along the Missouri River on the Rock Indian Permanent Reserve, claims to host Hunkpa Lakota Sitting Bull's last resting place (Mobridge, South Dakota also claims his grave).

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are 11 government colleges and universities, five tribal community colleges and four private schools.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The most important institutions are North Dakota State University and North Dakota University.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The higher education system consists of the following establishments:

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota University System (public institutions):

name: north_dakota
sentence: Tribal Establishments:

name: north_dakota
sentence: "The Flickr State" is one of the nicknames of North Dakota and is derived from Richardson's terrestrial squirrel (Spermophilus richardson ii), a very common animal in the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The ground squirrel constantly wilts its tail in a distinctive manner.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1953, legislation to make land squirrels the emblem of the state was passed by the state parliament.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The State has 10 daily newspapers, the most important being the Fargo-Moorhead Forum.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other weekly and monthly publications (most of which are entirely supported by advertising) are also available.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The most important of these is the other weekly High Plains Reader.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state's oldest radio station, WDAY-AM, was launched on May 23, 1922.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The three main radio markets in North Dakota are concentrated around Fargo, Bismarck and Grand Forks, although stations broadcast in all regions of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Several new stations were built at Williston in the early 2010s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has 34 AM and 88 FM radio stations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: KFGO in Fargo has the largest audience.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Television broadcasting in North Dakota began on April 3, 1953, when KCJB-TV (now KXMC-TV) began operations at Minot.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's television media markets are Fargo-Grand Forks (117th largest in the country), including half of the eastern state, and Minot-Bismarck (152nd), which constitute the western half of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are currently 31 full-power television stations in 10 networks, with 17 digital sub-channels.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public broadcasting in North Dakota is provided by Prairie Public, with national television and radio networks affiliated to PBS and NPR.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Public television stations open for community programming are available on the cable networks of Bismarck, Dickinson, Fargo and Jamestown.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is a state in the eastern Midwest region of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Of the fifty states, it is the 34th largest per area, and with a population of nearly 11.7 million, is the seventh most populated and the tenth most densely populated.

name: ohio
sentence: The state capital and the largest city is Columbus, with the Columbus metro area, the Grand Cincinnati and the Grand Cleveland being the largest metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bordered by Lake Erie to the north, Pennsylvania to the east, Virginia west to the southeast, Kentucky to the southwest, Indiana to the west and Michigan to the northwest.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is historically known as "Buckeye State" after its Ohio buckeyes, and Ohions are also known as "Buckeyes".

name: ohio
sentence: The state derives its name from the Ohio River, whose name comes in turn from the word Senatorca ohi=yo', meaning "good river," "great river," or "great river."

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was born from the lands west of Appalachia that were contested from colonial times to the Indian wars of the late 18th century.

name: ohio
sentence: It was separated from the Northwest Territory, which was the first border of the new United States, and became the 17th State admitted to the Union on March 1, 1803, and the first under the North-West Ordinance.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was the first free post-colonial state admitted to union, and became one of the first and most influential industrial power stations in the 20th century; although it evolved into an information- and service-based economy in the 21st century, Ohio remains an industrial state, ranking seventh in GDP in 2019, with the third largest manufacturing sector and second largest automotive production.

name: ohio
sentence: The government of Ohio is composed of the executive, led by the governor, of the legislature, composed of the Bicameral General Assembly of Ohio and the judiciary, led by the Supreme Court of the State.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has 16 seats in the House of Representatives of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: The state is known for its status as both an oscillating state and a gazebo in the national elections.

name: ohio
sentence: Eight presidents of the United States came from Ohio, the most from any state, which led him to receive the moniker "Mother of the Presidents".

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's geographic location has proven to be an asset for economic growth and expansion.

name: ohio
sentence: Because Ohio connects the Northeast to the Midwest, many goods and business traffic cross its borders along its well-developed highways.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has the country's 10th largest road network and is less than a day's drive of 50% of the North American population and 70% of North America's manufacturing capacity.

name: ohio
sentence: To the north, Lake Erie gives Ohio 312 miles (502 km) of coastline, allowing many cargo ports.

name: ohio
sentence: The southern Ohio border is defined by the Ohio River (the boundary being at the lower limit of 1792 on the north side of the river), and much of the northern boundary is defined by Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's neighbours are Pennsylvania in the east, Michigan in the northwest, Lake Erie in the north, Indiana in the west, Kentucky in the south, and West Virginia in the southeast.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's boundaries are defined in the enabling legislation of 1802 as follows:

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bounded by the Ohio River, but most of the river itself belongs to Kentucky and West Virginia.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1980, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that, based on the wording of Virginia's cessation of territory (which at the time included what is now Kentucky and West Virginia), the Ohio-Kentucky border (and, consequently, West Virginia) is the north low water mark of the river as it existed in 1792.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio only has this portion of the river between the 1792 low water mark and the current high water mark.

name: ohio
sentence: The border with Michigan also changed, following the Toledo War, to a slightly northeasterly angle to the north shore of the mouth of the Maumee River.

name: ohio
sentence: Much of Ohio has glacial till plains, with an exceptionally flat area in the northwest known as Great Black Swamp.

name: ohio
sentence: This glazed region of the north-west and central state is bordered first to the east and south-east by a belt known as the glazed Allegheny plateau, then another belt known as the unglazed Allegheny plateau.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of Ohio is of low relief, but the unglazed Allegheny plateau has rugged hills and forests.

name: ohio
sentence: The rugged southeastern quadrant of Ohio, which extends into an arc-shaped arc along the Ohio River from the Panhandle of West Virginia to the periphery of Cincinnati, forms a distinct socio-economic unit.

name: ohio
sentence: Geologically similar to parts of West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania, coal mining in that area, reliance on small pockets of former manufacturing facilities, and the distinctive regional dialect establish this section of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1965, the United States Congress passed the Appalachian Regional Development Act, which attempts to "respond to the persistent poverty and growing economic desperation of the Appalachian region".

name: ohio
sentence: This Act defines 29 counties in Ohio as part of Appalachia.

name: ohio
sentence: While one-third of Ohio's land mass is in the Appalachian region defined by the federal government, only 12.8% of Ohio's people live there (1.476 million people).

name: ohio
sentence: The important rivers of the state are the Cuyahoga River, the Great Miami River, the Maumee River, the Muskingum River and the Scioto River.

name: ohio
sentence: The rivers in the northern part of the state flow through Lake Erie and the St. Lawrence River into the northern Atlantic Ocean, and the rivers in the southern part of the state flow through the Ohio River and the Mississippi River into the Gulf of Mexico.

name: ohio
sentence: The worst weather disaster in Ohio's history occurred along the Great Miami River in 1913.

name: ohio
sentence: Known as the Greater Dayton flood, the entire Miami River watershed has flooded, including the business district of downtown Dayton.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result, the Miami Conservancy District was established as the first major floodplain engineering project in Ohio and the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Great Lake St. Marys, in the western central part of the state, was built as a water supply for canals at the time of canal construction from 1820 to 1850.

name: ohio
sentence: For many years, this stretch of water, over 52 km2, was the largest artificial lake in the world.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio canal construction projects were not the economic fiasco that similar efforts were made in other states.

name: ohio
sentence: Some cities, such as Dayton, owe their industrial emergence to their location on the canals, and until 1910, the inland canals carried a large portion of the state's bulk cargo.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio climate is a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa/Dfb climate classification) in most of the state, except in the extreme southern counties of the Ohio Bluegrass region, which are on the northern periphery of the subtropical humid climate (Cfa) and the U.S. Upland South region.

name: ohio
sentence: Summers are usually warm and humid throughout the state, while winters generally vary from cold to cold.

name: ohio
sentence: Rainfall in Ohio is moderate throughout the year.

name: ohio
sentence: Violent weather is not uncommon in the state, although there are generally fewer reports of tornadoes in Ohio than in states in what is known as the Tornado Alley.

name: ohio
sentence: Lake-effect snowstorms are also not uncommon on the southeast shore of Lake Erie, which is located in an area known as the snow belt.

name: ohio
sentence: Although mostly not in a subtropical climate, warmer-climate flora and fauna reach Ohio well.

name: ohio
sentence: For example, some trees whose range is further south, such as Blackjack Oak, Quercus marilandica, are northerly of Ohio, just north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: Also referring to this climate transition from subtropical to continental climate, several plants such as southern magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora), Albizia julibrissin (mimosa), Crape Myrtle and even occasionally Needle Palm are robust landscaping materials regularly used as street, courtyard and garden plantations in the Ohio Bluegrass area; but these same plants will simply not thrive in many of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: This interesting change can be observed during a trip across Ohio on Interstate 75 from Cincinnati to Toledo; the traveller observing this varying state can even catch a glimpse of Cincinnati's common lizard, one of the few examples of permanent "subtropical" wildlife in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Due to the floods that caused serious road damage, Governor Mike DeWine declared a state of emergency in 37 counties in Ohio in 2019.

name: ohio
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 113°F (45°C), near Gallipolis, on July 21, 1934.

name: ohio
sentence: The lowest recorded temperature was −39 °F (−39 °C) at Milligan on 10 February 1899 during the Great Blizzard of 1899.

name: ohio
sentence: Although few people have registered as notable to the average resident, more than 200 earthquakes of magnitude of 2.0 or more have occurred in Ohio since 1776.

name: ohio
sentence: The seismic zone of western Ohio and part of the seismic zone of the southern Great Lakes are located in the state, and there are numerous faults below the surface.

name: ohio
sentence: The most important known earthquake in Ohio's history was the Anna earthquake (Shelby County), which occurred on March 9, 1937.

name: ohio
sentence: It was centred in western Ohio, had a magnitude of 5.4 and was VIII-intensity.

name: ohio
sentence: Other major earthquakes in Ohio include: one of magnitude 4.8 near Lima on September 19, 1884; one of magnitude 4.2 near Portsmouth on May 17, 1901; and one of 5.0 in LeRoy Township in Lake County on January 31, 1986, which continued to trigger 13 replicas of magnitude 0.5 to 2.4 for two months.

name: ohio
sentence: Significant earthquakes in Ohio in the 21st century included an earthquake on December 31, 2011, approximately 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) northwest of Youngstown, and an earthquake on June 10, 2019, about 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) northwest of Eastlake under Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Columbus is the capital of Ohio, located near the geographic center of the state and well known for Ohio State University.

name: ohio
sentence: However, other Ohio cities are economic and cultural centres in metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Akron, Canton, Cleveland, Mansfield and Youngstown are in the northeast, known for the major industrial companies Goodyear Tire and Rubber and Timken, the top-ranked colleges Case Western Reserve University and Kent State University, the Cleveland Clinic, and cultural attractions such as the Cleveland Art Museum, Big Five Group Cleveland Orchestra, Playhouse Square, the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

name: ohio
sentence: Lima and Toledo are the major cities in Northwest Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Northwestern Ohio is known for its glass industry and is home to Owens Corning and Owens-Illinois, two Fortune 500 companies.

name: ohio
sentence: Dayton and Springfield are located in the Miami Valley, where the University of Dayton, the Dayton Ballet and the large base of the Wright-Patterson Air Force are located.

name: ohio
sentence: Cincinnati anchors southwest Ohio and is the largest economy in the state.

name: ohio
sentence: It houses the University of Miami and the University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati Union Terminal, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, and various Fortune 500 companies including Procter & Gamble, Kroger, Macy's, Inc., and the fifth third bank.

name: ohio
sentence: Steubenville is the only metropolitan town in Appalachian Ohio, home to Hocking Hills State Park.

name: ohio
sentence: The Cincinnati metropolitan area extends as far as Kentucky and Indiana, the Steubenville metropolitan area extends as far as West Virginia, the Toledo metropolitan area extends as far as Michigan and the Youngstown metropolitan area extends as far as Pennsylvania.

name: ohio
sentence: Other metropolitan areas that are home to Ohio cities include:

name: ohio
sentence: The cities of Ohio that serve as centres of micropolitan regions in the United States include:

name: ohio
sentence: Archaeological evidence of spear points of the Folsom and Clovis types indicates that the Ohio Valley was inhabited by nomads as early as 13,000 B.C.

name: ohio
sentence: These first nomads disappeared from Ohio by 1000 BC.

name: ohio
sentence: Between 1,000 and 800 BC, Adena's sedentary culture emerged.

name: ohio
sentence: The Adenas were able to establish "semi-permanent" villages because they domesticated plants, including sunflowers, and "wheat squash and possibly corn"; with hunting and gathering, this crop supported more established and complex villages.

name: ohio
sentence: The most notable remaining of the Adena culture is the Great Snake Mound, located in Adams County, Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Around 100 BC, Adena evolved to the Hopewells, who were also mound builders.

name: ohio
sentence: Their complex, large and technologically sophisticated works of earth can be found in Marietta, Newark and Circleville, today.

name: ohio
sentence: They were also a prolific commercial company, with their commercial network covering one third of the continent.

name: ohio
sentence: Hopewell disappeared from Ohio Valley about 600 AD.

name: ohio
sentence: Mississippi culture has grown as Hopewell culture declines.

name: ohio
sentence: Many peoples speaking the Siwan of the plains and the east coast claim them as ancestors and say that they lived throughout the Ohio region until about the 13th century.

name: ohio
sentence: There were three other contemporary cultures with Mississippians: the ancient Fort people, the Whittlesey Focus people and Monongahela culture.

name: ohio
sentence: These three cultures disappeared in the seventeenth century.

name: ohio
sentence: Their origin is not known.

name: ohio
sentence: The Shawnes may have absorbed the people of Old Fort.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also possible that the Monongahela did not hold land in Ohio during the colonial era.

name: ohio
sentence: The Mississippi culture was close to the people of the Old Fort and exchanged a lot with them.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio Valley Indians were strongly affected by the aggressive tactics of the Iroquois Confederation, based in central and western New York.

name: ohio
sentence: After the mid-17th century beaver wars, the Iroquois claimed much of Ohio as a hunting ground and, more importantly, as a beaver trap.

name: ohio
sentence: After the devastation of epidemics and war in the mid-17th century, which largely emptied the Ohio country of indigenous peoples in the mid-17th century to the end of the 17th century, the land gradually became repopulated by the mainly Algonquian.

name: ohio
sentence: Many of these Ohio nations were multi-ethnic (sometimes multi-lingual) societies born from the devastation caused by disease, war and subsequent social instability.

name: ohio
sentence: They survived agriculture (maize, sunflowers, beans, etc.)

name: ohio
sentence: supplemented by seasonal hunting.

name: ohio
sentence: In the 18th century, they were part of a larger global economy created by the European entry into the fur trade.

name: ohio
sentence: The Aboriginal nations living in Ohio during the historical period included the Iroquoians, the Algonquians, and the Siwans.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio country was also the site of Indian massacres, such as the Yellow Creek massacre, the Gnadenhutten massacre and the Pontiac School of Rebellion massacre.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of the Aboriginal people who remained in Ohio were gradually bought and persuaded to leave, or ordered by law, in the early 19th century with the Indian Abduction Act of 1830.

name: ohio
sentence: During the 18th century, the French established a trading post system to control the fur trade in the region.

name: ohio
sentence: As early as 1754, France and Britain fought the French and Indian wars.

name: ohio
sentence: Thanks to the Treaty of Paris, the French gave control of Ohio and the rest of the Old North West to Great Britain.

name: ohio
sentence: In the Treaty of Paris in 1783, Britain ceded to the United States all the claims of the Ohio country.

name: ohio
sentence: The United States created the Northwest Territory under the North-West Order of 1787.

name: ohio
sentence: Slavery is not permitted in the new territory.

name: ohio
sentence: The settlement began with the founding of Marietta by the Ohio Company of Associates, which had been formed by a group of U.S. Revolutionary War veterans.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result of the Ohio Company, the Miami Company (also known as the "Symma Purchase") claimed the southwest section, and the Connecticut Land Company surveyed and established the Connecticut Western Reserve in present-day northeast Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Territorial surveyors from Fort Steuben began to survey approximately at the same time an area in eastern Ohio called the Seven Ranges.

name: ohio
sentence: The former Northwest Territory originally included areas previously known as Ohio Country and Illinois Country.

name: ohio
sentence: As Ohio was preparing to become a state, the Indiana Territory was created, which reduced the Northwest Territory to about the present size of Ohio, plus half of the lower Michigan Peninsula and the eastern tip of the upper peninsula, as well as a portion of the southeast Indiana called "The Gore".

name: ohio
sentence: The coalition of Amerindian tribes, known as the Western Confederation, was forced to cede a vast territory, including much of present-day Ohio, in the Treaty of Greenville in 1795.

name: ohio
sentence: Under the North-West Ordinance, areas could be defined and admitted as States when their population reaches 60,000.

name: ohio
sentence: Although the population of Ohio was only 45,000 in December 1801, Congress determined that it was growing rapidly and that it had already begun the course of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: With regard to the natives of Leni Lenape, the Congress decided that 10,000 acres on the Muskingum River in the present state of Ohio would be "separated and their property would be devolved to the Moravian Brothers [...] or to a Society of the said Brothers for civilizing the Indians and encouraging Christianity."

name: ohio
sentence: Rufus Putnam served extensively in the French and Indian War and the American Revolutionary War.

name: ohio
sentence: He was one of the most respected men of the early years of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1776 Putnam created a method of construction of portable fortifications that allowed the Continental Army to drive the British out of Boston.

name: ohio
sentence: George Washington was so impressed that he turned Putnam into his chief engineer.

name: ohio
sentence: After the war, Putnam and Manasseh Cutler contributed to the creation of the Northwest Ordinance, which opened the Northwest Territory for settlement.

name: ohio
sentence: This land was used to compensate for what was owed to the veterans of the revolutionary war.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also on Putnam's recommendation that the lands be surveyed and arranged in six-square-mile townships.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam organized and led the first group of veterans to the Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: They settled in Marietta, Ohio, where they built a large fort called Campus Martius.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam and Cutler insisted that the Northwest Territory be a free territory, no slavery.

name: ohio
sentence: They were both from Puritan New England, and the Puritans firmly believed that slavery was morally evil.

name: ohio
sentence: The Northwest Territory doubled the size of the United States, and it was extremely important to consider it as slavery-free in the decades that followed.

name: ohio
sentence: It covered what became Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin, and part of Minnesota.

name: ohio
sentence: Had these States been slave states and their electoral votes been attributed to Abraham Lincoln's main competitor, Lincoln would not have been elected president.

name: ohio
sentence: The Civil War wouldn't have been fought.

name: ohio
sentence: Even if there had been a civil war, the north would probably have lost.

name: ohio
sentence: In the Puritan tradition, Putnam played an important role in the establishment of education in the Northwest Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: Considerable areas have been set aside for schools.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam had been one of the principal benefactors of the founding of the Leicester Academy in Massachusetts, and in 1798 he also created the plan for the construction of the Muskingum Academy (now Marietta College) in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1780, the directors of the Ohio Company appointed him superintendent of all of his settlement affairs north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1796 he was commanded by President George Washington as surveyor general of the United States Lands.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1788 he was a judge in the First Court of the Northwest Territory.

sentence: The people of Oklahoma have less than average life expectancy than many other states.

sentence: The port ships more than two million tons of goods per year and is a designated area for foreign trade.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma is a constitutional republic with a government inspired by the U.S. federal government, with executive, legislative and judicial powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The state has 77 counties with jurisdiction over most of the functions of local government in each area, five districts of Congress, and a voting base with plurality in the Republican Party.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The representatives of the State are elected by a pluralist vote in the State of Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has the death penalty as a legal penalty, and the state (between 1976 and mid-2011) has had the highest per capita execution rate in the nation.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Legislative Assembly of Oklahoma is composed of the Senator and the House of Representatives.

name: oklahoma
sentence: As a legislative branch of the state government, it is responsible for collecting and distributing the funds necessary for the administration of the government.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The honourable senator has 48 members for a four-year term, while the House has 101 members for a two-year term.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The State has a statutory term limit that limits any person to twelve cumulative years of service between the two legislative powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The judiciary of Oklahoma consists of the Supreme Court of Oklahoma, the Criminal Appeal Court of Oklahoma and 77 District Courts, each serving a single county.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The judiciary of Oklahoma also comprises two independent courts: an indictment court and the Oklahoma court on the judiciary.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has two courts of last resort: the State Supreme Court hears civil cases, and the State Criminal Court of Appeal hears criminal cases (this split system exists only in Oklahoma and nearby Texas).

name: oklahoma
sentence: The judges of these two courts, as well as the Court of Civil Appeal, are appointed by the Governor on the recommendation of the State Judicial Nominations Commission and are subject to a non-partisan loyalty vote according to a rotational schedule of six years.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The executive is composed of the governor, his staff and other elected officials.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The chief head of government, the Governor, is the head of the Oklahoma Executive, who is the commander-in-chief of the Oklahoma National Guard when he is not called for federal use and who reserves the power of veto to bills passed by the Legislative Assembly.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The executive branch's responsibilities include the submission of the budget, the enforcement of State laws and the preservation of peace within the State.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The State is divided into 77 counties, each governed by a three-member council of elected commissioners, a tax assessor, a clerk, a clerk, a treasurer and a sheriff.

name: oklahoma
sentence: While each municipality operates as a separate and independent local government with executive, legislative and judicial powers, county governments retain jurisdiction over incorporated cities and unincorporated areas within their borders, but they have executive but no legislative or judicial powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: County and municipal governments collect taxes, employ a separate police force, organize elections and manage emergency response services in their jurisdictions.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Other local government services include school districts, technology centre districts, community colleges districts, rural fire departments, rural water districts and other special-purpose districts.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Thirty-nine Amerindian tribal governments are based in Oklahoma, each with limited powers in the designated areas.

name: oklahoma
sentence: While typical Indian reserves in most of the United States are not present in Oklahoma, tribal governments hold land granted during the time of Indian territory, but with limited jurisdiction and no control over State governing bodies such as municipalities and counties.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tribal governments are recognized by the United States as quasi-sovereign entities with executive, judicial and legislative powers over tribal members and functions, but are subject to the power of the United States Congress to revoke or refuse certain powers.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Tribal governments are required to submit a constitution and any subsequent amendments to the U.S. Congress for approval.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma has 11 sub-state districts, including the two major Governing Councils, INCOG in Tulsa (Council of Indian Governments) and ACOG (Association of Central Oklahoma Governments).

name: oklahoma
sentence: During the first half century of the state, Oklahoma was considered a democratic bastion, being carried by the Republican Party in only two presidential elections (1920 and 1928).

name: oklahoma
sentence: After the 1948 elections, the state firmly republican.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Although the registered Republicans were a minority in the state until 2015, Oklahoma was carried by Republican presidential candidates in all but one election since 1952: Lyndon B. Johnson's 1964 victory shaken.

name: oklahoma
sentence: All Oklahoma counties have been won by Republican candidates in presidential elections since 2004.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In general, the Republicans are the strongest in the suburbs of Oklahoma City and Tulsa, as well as in the Panhandle.

name: oklahoma
sentence: The Democrats are the strongest in the eastern part of the state and Little Dixie, as well as in the most African-American and internal parts of Oklahoma City and Tulsa.

name: oklahoma
sentence: With a population of 8.6% of Amerindians in the state, it is also interesting to note that most Amerindian constituencies vote Democratic in margins exceeded only by African Americans.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Following the 2000 census, the delegation of Oklahoma to the United States House of Representatives increased from six to five representatives, each serving a district of Congress.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In the current Congress, the Republicans make up the entire delegation of Oklahoma.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Oklahoma had 598 places incorporated in 2010, including four cities with more than 100,000 inhabitants and 43 with more than 10,000.

name: oklahoma
sentence: Two of the 50 largest cities in the United States are Oklahoma, Oklahoma City and Tulsa, and 65% of Oklahomans live in their metropolitan areas, or spheres of economic and social influence defined by the United States Census Bureau as a metropolitan area of statistics.

sentence: Oklahoma City, the capital of the state and the largest city, had the largest metropolitan area of the state in 2010, with 1,252,987 people, and the metropolitan area of Tulsa had 937,478 residents.

sentence: Between 2000 and 2010, Blanchard (172.4 per cent), Elgin (78.2 per cent), Jenks (77.0%), Piedmont (56.7%), Bixby (56.6%) and Owasso (56.3%) were the main growing cities.

name: oklahoma
sentence: In descending order of population, the largest cities in Oklahoma in 2010 were: Oklahoma City (579,999, +14.6%), Tulsa (391,906, -0.3%), Norman (110,925, +15.9%), Broken Arrow (98,850, +32.0%), Lawton (96,867 +4.4%), Edmond (81,405, +19.2%), Moore (55,081, +33.9%), Midwest City (54,371, +0.5 %), Enid (49,379 +5.0 %), and Stillwater (45,688, +17.0%).

name: oklahoma

name: oklahoma
sentence: Under the Oklahoma Act, municipalities are divided into two categories: cities, defined as having more than 1,000 inhabitants, and cities, with fewer than 1,000 inhabitants.

name: oregon
sentence: Most of Oregon has a generally mild climate, although there are significant variations given the variety of landscapes throughout the state.

sentence: The western region of the state (west of the Cascade Range) has an oceanic climate, populated by dense mixed forests with persistent leaves.

name: oregon
sentence: The western Oregon climate is heavily influenced by the Pacific Ocean; the western third of Oregon is very humid in winter, moderately to very humid in spring and fall, and dry in summer.

name: oregon

name: oregon
sentence: The northeastern part of Oregon has a steppe climate, and its high altitude regions have a subarctic climate.

name: oregon
sentence: Like Western Europe, Oregon and the Pacific Northwest in general are considered warm for their latitude, and the condition has much milder winters at a given altitude than comparable latitudes elsewhere in North America, such as Upper Midwest, Ontario, Quebec, and New England.

sentence: While most of Oregon receives significant snowfalls, the Willamette Valley, home to 60 per cent of the population, has much milder winters for its latitude and generally sees only slight snowfall.

sentence: A Pew survey of the religious self-identification of Rhode Island residents showed the following distribution of affiliations: Roman Catholics 42%, Protestants 30%, Jews 1%, Jehovah's Witnesses 2%, Buddhism 1%, Mormonism 1%, Hinduism 1% and non-religious 20%.

sentence: Lincoln was elected President on November 6, 1860.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Three days later, the House of State Representatives adopted the resolution calling for the election of Abraham Lincoln as President of the United States, an act of hostility, and within a few weeks South Carolina became the first state to separate.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On April 12, 1861, the Confederate batteries began to bomb the Union Fort Sumter in the port of Charleston, and the American Civil War began.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In November of that year, the Union attacked Port Royal Sound and soon occupied Beaufort County and the surrounding maritime islands.

name: south_carolina
sentence: During the rest of the war, the area served as a base for the Union and as a gathering point for other operations.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The whites have abandoned their plantations, leaving behind about ten thousand slaves.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Several northern charities have partnered with the federal government to help them manage cotton farms themselves as part of the Port Royal experience.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The workers were paid by the book collected and thus became the first slaves freed by the Union's forces to earn wages.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Even though the state was not a major battlefield, the war ruined the economy.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Under conscription, all white men aged 18 to 35 (later 45) were written for the confederate service.

name: south_carolina
sentence: More than 60,000 people have served and the state has lost nearly a third of the male white population of combat age.

name: south_carolina
sentence: At the end of the war in early 1865, the troops of General William Tecumseh Sherman passed through the devastating plantations of the state and most of Columbia.

name: south_carolina
sentence: After the war, South Carolina was restored to the United States during the reconstruction.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the framework of the Presidential Reconstruction (1865–66), freed men (former slaves) were granted limited rights.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Under the radical reconstruction (1867-1877), a Republican coalition of liberators, upholsterers and scalawags was in control, supported by the forces of the Union Army.

name: south_carolina
sentence: They have established public education, social welfare institutions and the domestic system for counties, developing democracy.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In Texas vs. White (1869), the Supreme Court ruled that the secession orders (including that of South Carolina) were invalid, and therefore these states had never left the Union.

name: south_carolina
sentence: However, South Carolina did not resume its representation in Congress before that date.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Until the presidential election of 1868, the legislature of South Carolina, not the voters, chose the state voters for the presidential election.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was the last state to have chosen its voters in this way.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On 19 Oct. 1871 President Ulysse S. Grant suspended habeas corpus in nine counties of South Carolina under the Ku Klux Klan Act.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Directed by Grant's attorney general, Amos T. Akerman, hundreds of Klansmen were arrested while 2,000 Klansmen fled the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This was done to suppress Klan's violence against African American and white voters in the South.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the mid and late 1870s, white democrats used paramilitary groups such as the Red Shirts to intimidate and terrorize black voters.

name: south_carolina
sentence: They regained political control of the state under conservative white "Redemptors" and pro-business Bourbon democrats.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1877, the federal government withdrew its troops as part of the 1877 compromise, which put an end to reconstruction.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State became a home of racial and economic tensions during the populist and agrarian movements of the 1890s.

name: south_carolina
sentence: A biracial republican-populist coalition temporarily took over the power of the white democrats.

name: south_carolina
sentence: To prevent this from happening again, the Democrats obtained the adoption of a new constitution in 1895 that effectively deprived almost all blacks and many poor whites by new requirements in terms of voting taxes, residence and literacy tests that significantly reduced the electoral roll.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1896, only 5,500 black voters were registered, although they constituted the majority of the population of the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The 1900 census showed the extent of exclusion: the 782,509 African-Americans accounted for more than 58% of the population of the state, but they were essentially without political representation in Jim Crow society.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The 1895 constitution overturned the local representative government, reducing the role of the counties to the agents of the government of the State, effectively governed by the General Assembly, through the legislative delegations of each county.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Because each county had a senator, that person had considerable power.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The counties did not have a representative government until the adoption of the internal regime in 1975.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Governor Pitchfork Ben Tillman, a populist, led the effort to deny the right to vote to the poor blacks and whites, although he controlled the politics of the democratic state from the 1890s to 1910 with a base among the poor white peasants.

name: south_carolina
sentence: During the constitutional assembly of 1895, he supported another man's proposal that the State should adopt a rule of one drop, as well as prohibiting marriage between whites and anyone of known African descent.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Some members of the Convention have realized that prominent white families with some African descent may be affected by such legislation.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In terms similar to a debate in Virginia in 1853 on a similar proposal (which was abandoned), George Dionysius Tillman stated in the opposition:

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state has postponed this law by a single drop for years.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Virginian legislators passed a law of one drop in 1924, forgetting that their state had many people of mixed ancestry among those who identified themselves as white.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the early 20th century, South Carolina developed a thriving textile industry.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state has also converted its cotton agricultural base into more profitable crops; attracted large military bases through its powerful delegation to the Democratic Congress, a part of the South following the abandonment of black voting rights at the turn of the century; and created tourism industries.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the early 20th century, millions of African Americans left South Carolina and other southern states for jobs, opportunities and relative freedom in American cities outside the former Confederate states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In total, between 1910 and 1970, 6.5 million blacks left the South in the Great Migration.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1930 South Carolina had a white majority population for the first time since 1708.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of the many states that initially rejected the nineteenth amendment (1920) giving women the right to vote.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The South Carolina Legislative Assembly subsequently ratified the amendment on July 1, 1969.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The struggle of the civil rights movement took place in South Carolina as in other southern states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: However, South Carolina experienced a much less violent movement than other southern states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This quiet transition from a Jim Crow company occurred because the white and black leaders of the state were willing to accept the slow change rather than being totally reluctant to accept the change at all.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Other Southern Carolinians, such as Senator Strom Thurmond, on the other hand, were among the most radical and effective opponents of social equality and integration.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2015, South Carolina had one of the lowest percentages among all states of women in the state legislature, at 13.5% (only Louisiana, Oklahoma and Wyoming had a lower percentage; the national average was 24.3%; the highest percentage was in Colorado at 41%).

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2011, South Carolina ranked first in the country in the number of women killed by men.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As the 21st century progresses, South Carolina has attracted new businesses with a 5% corporate income tax rate, no state property tax, no local income tax, no inventory tax, no sales tax on manufacturing equipment, industrial energy or materials for finished products, no wholesale tax and no unit global income tax.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of the first states to stop paying for "early" baby deliveries, under Medicaid and private insurance.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The term "early elective" is defined as an induction of work or a Caesarean section between 37 and 39 weeks that is not medically based.

name: south_carolina
sentence: This change is intended to promote baby health and reduce unnecessary costs for South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On November 20, 2014, South Carolina became the 35th state to legalize same-sex marriages, when a federal court ordered the change.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has numerous sites for visual and performing arts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Gibbes Museum of Art in Charleston, the Greenville County Museum of Art, the Columbia Museum of Art, the Spartanburg Art Museum and the South Carolina State Museum in Columbia, among others, provide access to the State's visual arts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also many historic sites and museums scattered throughout the state, paying tribute to many events and periods in the history of the state, from Amerindian housing to today.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina also has art rooms, including the Peace Center in Greenville, the Koger Center for the Arts in Columbia and the Newberry Opera House, among others, to attract local, national and international talent to South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Several major venues can host major events, including Colonial Life Arena in Columbia, Bon Secours Wellness Arena in Greenville and North Charleston Coliseum.

name: south_carolina
sentence: One of the country's leading arts festivals, the Spoleto Festival USA, is held annually in Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also countless local festivals across the state highlighting numerous cultural traditions, historical events and folklore.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the South Carolina Arts Commission, the creative industries generate $9.2 billion a year and support more than 78,000 jobs in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: A 2009 government-wide survey by the University of South Carolina's Institute for Public Service and Policy Research found that 67% of residents had participated in the arts in some form in the past year and that, on average, citizens had participated in the arts 14 times in the previous year.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), in 2010, the largest religion was Christianity, the largest denominations of which were the Southern Baptist Convention with 913,763 adherents, the Methodist Church united with 274,111 adherents and the Roman Catholic Church with 181,743 adherents.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The fourth largest is the African Methodist Episcopal Church with 564 congregations and 121,000 members, and the fifth largest is the Presbyterian Church (USA) with 320 congregations and nearly 100,000 members.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2010, South Carolina was the U.S. state with the highest per capita proportion of citizens following the Bahá'í faith, with 17,559 adherents, making Bahá'í the second religion of the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Although no major professional sports team is based in South Carolina, the Carolina Panthers have training facilities in the state and played their first home game season at Clemson Memorial Stadium, but they are now playing at the Bank of America Stadium in North Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Panthers consider themselves "the Carolines team" and refrain from naming themselves after Charlotte or one or the other of the Carolinas.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state also houses numerous professional teams of minor leagues.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The College's teams represent their unique institutions in South Carolina, and are the main options for football, basketball and baseball in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also a high-end destination for golf and water sports.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also home to one of NASCAR's first runways and its first paved access route, Darlington Raceway, northwest of Florence.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina's GDP in 2019 was $249.9 billion, making the state the 26th largest GDP in the United States.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis, South Carolina's gross domestic product (GDP) amounted to $97 billion in 1997 and $153 billion in 2007.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Its real per capita gross domestic product (GDP) in 2000 dollars was $26,772 in 1997 and $28,894 in 2007, representing 85% of per capita real GDP of $31,619 for the United States in 1997 and 76% of $38,020 for the United States in 2007.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The government's 2012 debt was calculated by source as $22.9 billion, or $7,800 per taxpayer.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Industrial outputs include textile products, chemicals, paper products, machinery, automobiles, automotive products and tourism.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Government's main agricultural products are tobacco, poultry, cotton, cattle, dairy products, soybeans, hay, rice and pork.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, as of March 2012, South Carolina had 1,852,700 non-agricultural jobs, of which 12 per cent were in manufacturing, 11.5 per cent in recreation and hospitality, 19 per cent in trade, transport and public services, and 11.8 per cent in education and health services.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The services sector accounts for 83.7% of South Carolina's economy.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Many large corporations have moved their locations to South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Boeing opened an aircraft manufacturing plant in Charleston in 2011, which is one of the last two assembly sites at the 787 Dreamliner.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is a state of the right to work and many companies use recruitment agencies to temporarily fill jobs.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Domtar in Rock Hill is the only Fortune 500 company based in South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Fortune 1000 list includes SCANA, Sonoco Products and ScanSource.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is also benefiting from foreign investment.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are 1,950 foreign companies operating in South Carolina and employing almost 135,000 people.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Foreign direct investment (FDI) contributed $1.06 billion to the government economy in 2010.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Since 1994, BMW has had a production plant in Spartanburg County, near Greer, and since 1996, the Zapp Group has been operating in Summerville, near Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are 36 television stations (including PBS affiliates) serving South Carolina with terrestrial access and some on-line streaming.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Markets in which the stations are located include Columbia, Florence, Allendale, Myrtle Beach, Greenville, Charleston, Conway, Beaufort, Hardeeville, Spartanburg, Greenwood, Anderson and Sumter.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State has the fourth largest state system in the country, consisting of 11 interstates, numbered highways, state highways and secondary roads, with a total area of approximately 41,500 miles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On secondary roads, South Carolina uses a numbering system to follow all non-interstate and primary roads maintained by the South Carolina Department of Transportation.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Secondary roads are numbered by the number of the county followed by a single number for the particular route.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Amtrak Passenger Train operates four passenger routes in South Carolina: Crescent, Palmetto, Silver Meteor and Silver Star.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Crescent Road serves the cities of Upstate, the silver star serves the cities of Midlands and the Palmetto and Silver Meteor routes serve the cities of Lower Countries.

name: south_carolina
sentence: FreightCSX Transportation and Norfolk Southern are the only Class I railway companies in South Carolina, as other government freight companies are short lines.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are seven major airports in South Carolina, all of which act as regional airport centers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The busiest passenger volume is the Charleston International Airport.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Just across the border in North Carolina, Charlotte/Douglas International Airport is the 30th busiest airport in the world, in terms of passengers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2010, South Carolina was one of three states that did not agree to use competitive international standards in math and languages.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2014, the South Carolina Supreme Court ruled that the state had not provided "minimally adequate" education to children in all parts of the state, as required by the state constitution.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has 1,144 K-12 schools in 85 school districts, with 712,244 enrolled in the fall of 2009.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the 2008-2009 school year, South Carolina spent $9,450 per student, placing it 31st in the country for expenditures per student.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2015, the national average TSS was 1490 and South Carolina was 1442, 48 points lower than the national average.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina is the only state that has and operates a state-wide school bus system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As of December 2016, the State had a fleet of 5,582 buses whose average vehicle in service was 15 years old (the national average is six) having travelled 236 000 miles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Half of the state's school buses are over the age of 15 and some of them would be up to the age of 30.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2017 in the draft budget, Education Superintendent Molly Spearman asked the state lease to purchase 1,000 buses to replace the most decrepit vehicles.

name: south_carolina
sentence: An additional 175 buses could be purchased immediately as part of the Crown Treasurer's Master Lease Program.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On January 5, 2017, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency granted South Carolina more than $1.1 million to replace 57 school buses with new cleaner models as part of its Diesel Emissions Reduction Act.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has a variety of institutions, ranging from large publicly funded research universities to small colleges that cultivate liberal arts, religious or military traditions.

name: south_carolina
sentence: For all health care, South Carolina is ranked 33rd out of 50 states, according to the Commonwealth Fund, a private health foundation working to improve the health care system.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Kaiser Family Foundation, the State teenage birth rate was 53 births per 1,000 adolescents, compared with the national average of 41.9 births.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State infant mortality rate was 9.4 deaths per 1,000 births, compared to a national average of 6.9 deaths.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There were 2.6 physicians per 1,000 persons compared to the national average of 3.2 physicians.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Per capita health expenditure was $5,114 in the State, compared to a national average of $5,283.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There were 26 per cent of children and 13 per cent of the elderly living in poverty in the state, compared to 23 per cent and 13 per cent, respectively, in the United States, and 34 per cent of children were overweight or obese, compared to the national average of 32 per cent.
