name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is a state in the Midwestern region of the United States of America.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It bears the names of the indigenous tribes Lakota and Dakota Sioux, which constitute a large part of the population and historically dominate the territory.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is the seventeenth largest by region, but the fifth least populated, and the fifth least densely populated in the 50 United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As a southern part of the former Dakota Territory, South Dakota became a state on 2 November 1889, simultaneously with North Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This is either the 39th or the 40th State admitted to the Union.

name: south_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison changed the state documents before signing them so that no one would know who became a state first.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Pierre is the capital of the state and Sioux Falls, with a population of about 187,200, is the largest city in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is bounded by the States of North Dakota (north), Minnesota (east), Iowa (southeast), Nebraska (south), Wyoming (west) and Montana (northwest).

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state is divided by the Missouri River, which divides South Dakota into two geographically and socially distinct halves, known to residents as the East River and the West River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The eastern South Dakota is home to most of the state's population, and the fertile soil of the region is used to cultivate a variety of crops.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the west of Missouri, livestock is the main agricultural activity, and the economy depends more on tourism and defence spending.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Most of the Amerindian reserves are located in West River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills, a group of low mountains covered with sacred pines in the Sioux, are located in the southwestern part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mount Rushmore, an important tourist destination, is here.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a temperate continental climate, four distinct seasons, and moderate precipitation in the east to semi-arids in the west.

name: south_dakota
sentence: State ecology has species typical of a North American prairie biome.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Human beings lived in the region for several millennia, with Sioux becoming dominant in the early 19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: At the end of the 19th century, Euro-American colonization intensified after a gold rush into the black hills and the construction of eastern railways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A number of Indian wars were unleashed by miners and crowded settlers, culminating in the massacre of the injured knee in 1890.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Key events of the 20th century include the Dust Bowl and the Great Depression, the increase in federal spending in the 1940s and 1950s on agriculture and defence, and the industrialization of agriculture that reduced family farming.

name: south_dakota
sentence: While several democrats have represented South Dakota for multiple terms in both chambers of Congress, the state government is largely controlled by the Republican Party, whose candidates have carried South Dakota to each of the last 13 presidential elections.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Historically dominated by an agricultural economy and rural lifestyle, South Dakota has recently sought to diversify its economy into regions to attract and retain residents.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The history and rural character of South Dakota continues to have a strong impact on the culture of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota, located in the north central United States, is considered to be part of the Midwest by the United States Census Bureau and is also part of the Great Plains region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Western South Dakota culture, economy and geography have more in common with the West than the Midwest.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a total area of 77 116 square miles (199730 km2), making the State the 17th largest in the Union.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Elk Peak, formerly Harney Peak, with an altitude of 7,242 feet (2,207 m), is the highest point in the state, while the shore of Big Stone Lake is the lowest, with an altitude of 966 feet (294 m).

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is bordered north by North Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The geographic center of the United States is 27 km west of Castle Rock in Butte County.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The North American continental pole of inaccessibility is located between Allen and Kyle, 1024 mi (1,648 km) from the nearest coast.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River is the largest and longest river in the U.S.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Cheyenne, James, Big Sioux and White rivers are also the main rivers of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The eastern South Dakota has many natural lakes, mostly created by periods of glaciation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In addition, the Missouri River dams create four large reservoirs: Oahe Lake, Sharpe Lake, Francis Case Lake, Lewis Lake, and Clark Lake.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota can generally be divided into three regions: Eastern South Dakota, Western South Dakota, and Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Missouri serves as a limit to the geographical, social and political differences between eastern and western South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The geography of the Black Hills, long considered sacred by the Amerindians, differs from its environment to the extent that it can be considered distinct from the rest of Southwestern Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sometimes the black hills are combined with the rest of western South Dakota, and people often refer to the two resulting areas, divided by the Missouri River, such as the West River and the East River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In eastern South Dakota, precipitation and topography are generally higher than in the western part of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Smaller geographic areas include the Prairie Coteau, the Dissolved Till Plains and the James River Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Prairie Coteau is a plateau located east of the Minnesota River valley and west of the James River basin.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Further to the west, the James River basin is mainly low, flat and heavily eroded land, following the flow of the James River by South Dakota from north to south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Till Plains Dissected, an area of hilly hills and fertile soils that spans much of Iowa and Nebraska, extends into the southeast corner of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The layers deposited during the Pleistocene period, about two million years ago, cover most of eastern South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is the youngest layers of rock and sediment in the state, the product of successive periods of glaciation that have deposited a large amount of rock and soil, known as till, on the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Great Plains cover most of the two thirds of western South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the west of Missouri, the landscape becomes more arid and rugged, consisting of hilly hills, plains, ravines and flat, steep hills called mounds.

name: south_dakota
sentence: To the south, east of the Black Hills, is the Badlands of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The erosion of the Black Hills, marine skeletons that fell to the bottom of a vast shallow sea that once covered the area, and volcanic material all contribute to the geology of this region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills lie in southwestern South Dakota and extend to Wyoming.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This range of low mountains covers 6,000 m2 (16 000 km2), with peaks increasing from 2,000 to 4,000 feet (600 to 1,200 m) above their bases.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Black Hills are the location of Black Elk Peak (7,242 ft or 2,207 m above sea level), the highest point in South Dakota, and also the highest point in the United States east of the Rocky Mountains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The two billion-year-old Precambrian formations, the oldest rocks in the state, form the central nucleus of the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Paleozoic formations form the outer ring of the Black Hills

name: south_dakota
sentence: This area features rocks such as limestone, which were deposited here when the area formed the shore of an ancient inland sea.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Much of South Dakota (with the exception of the Black Hills region) is dominated by temperate prairie biome.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although grasses and crops cover most of this area, deciduous trees such as cottonwood, elms and willows are common near rivers and in shelter belts.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The state bird, the roundneck pheasant, adapted well to the region after being introduced from China.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Increasing populations of bald eagles spread throughout the state, especially near the Missouri River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Prairie rivers and lakes are home to populations of goldeneye, carp, pike, bass and other species.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River also contains the prehistoric spatula.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Due to higher elevations and precipitation levels, the Black Hills ecology differs significantly from that of the plains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The mountains are thickly covered with different types of pines, including ponderosa and lodgepole pines, as well as spruce.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Hills mammals include deer, elk (wapiti), sheep, mountain goats, pine martens, and mountain lions, while streams and lakes contain several species of trout.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has a continental climate with four distinct seasons, from cold and dry winter to warm and semi-wet summers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: During summers, the average high state temperature is often close to 90°F (32°C), although it cools to close to 60°F (16°C) at night.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is not uncommon for South Dakota to have severe warm and dry periods in summer with temperatures rising above 100°F (38°C) several times a year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Winters are cold, with high January temperatures on average below freezing, and low temperatures on average below 10°F (−12°C) in most states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 120°F (49°C) at Usta on 15 July 2006, and the lowest recorded temperature was −58°F (−50°C) at McIntosh on 17 February 1936.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Average annual precipitation in South Dakota ranges from semi-arid conditions in the northwestern part of the state (approximately 15 inches or 380 mm) to semi-wet conditions around the southeastern part of the state (approximately 25 inches or 640 mm), although a small lead-centered area in the black hills has the highest precipitation at nearly 30 inches (760 mm) per year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The summers of South Dakota lead to frequent, sometimes severe, thunderstorms with violent winds, thunders and hail.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The eastern part of the State is often considered to be part of the Tornado gangway, and South Dakota suffers an average of 30 tornadoes a year.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Severe blizzards and ice storms often occur in the winter.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has several sites managed by the National Parks Service.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two national parks were established in the state, both in its southwest region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Wind Cave National Park, founded in 1903 in the Black Hills, has a vast network of caves and a large herd of bison.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Badlands National Park was established in 1978 and is home to a brightly coloured, eroded landscape surrounded by semi-arid grasslands.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Mont-Rushmore National Memorial in the Black Hills was established in 1925.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The sculpture of four American presidents was carved on the mountain by the sculptor Gutzon Borglum.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other areas managed by the National Parks Service include the Jewel Cave National Monument near Custer, the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail, Minuteman Missile National Historic Site, which includes a decommissioned nuclear missile silo and a separate missile control zone several kilometres away, and the Missouri National Recreational River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Crazy Horse Memorial is a large mountainside sculpture near Mount Rushmore under construction from private funds.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Mammouth site near Hot Springs is another private attraction on the Black Hills.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This is a paleontological excavation that works and has one of the highest concentrations of mammoth remains in the world.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Humans have lived in what South Dakota is today for thousands of years.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The first inhabitants were Paleoindian hunter-gatherers, and disappeared from the area around 5000 BC.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Between 500 and 800 AD, a semi-nomadic people known as Mound Builders lived in the centre and east of South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 14th century, the Crow Creek massacre took place, in which hundreds of men, women and children were killed near the Missouri River.

name: south_dakota
sentence: By 1500, the Arikara (or Ree) had settled in much of the Missouri valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: European contact with the region began in 1743 when the LaVérendrye brothers explored the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The LaVérendrye group buried a plaque near the site of modern Pierre, claiming the region for France as part of the Great Louisiana.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1762, the entire region was part of the Spanish Louisiana until 1802.

name: south_dakota
sentence: By the early 19th century, the Sioux had largely replaced the Arikara as a dominant group in the region.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1803 the United States purchased the territory of Louisiana, a region that included most of Napoleon Bonaparte's South Dakota, and President Thomas Jefferson organized a group commonly known as the "Lewis and Clark Expedition" to explore the area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1817, an American fur trade post was established at the present Fort Peter, which began to settle continuously in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1855, the American army purchased Fort Pierre but abandoned it in 1857 in favour of Fort Randall in the south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: At that time, American and European settlement grew rapidly and, in 1858, the Yankton Sioux signed the Treaty of 1858, giving the United States most of the present South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Speculators founded two of the largest cities today in South Dakota: Sioux Falls in 1856 and Yankton in 1859.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1861 the territory of Dakota was established by the Government of the United States (originally North Dakota, South Dakota, and parts of Montana and Wyoming).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Colonization of the region, mainly by residents of the eastern United States and western and northern Europe, increased rapidly, especially after the completion of an eastern rail link to Yankton in 1873.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1874 gold was discovered in the Black Hills during a military expedition led by George A. Custer and miners and explorers began illegally entering the land promised to the Lakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Custer expedition took place despite the fact that the Sioux had received the entire western half of the present South Dakota (West River) in 1868 by the treaty of Laramie under the Great Sioux Reserve.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Sioux refused to grant mining rights or land in the Black Hills, and the war broke out after the United States did not stop white miners and settlers from entering the area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Eventually, the United States won and broke the Sioux Great Reserve into five reserves, settling the Lakota there.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1980, the Supreme Court and Congress ordered compensation, but the Lakota still refused to accept it, insisting on the restitution of their land.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A growing population and political concerns (the accession of two states meant the arrival of four new senators for the Republican Party) caused the division of Dakota territory into two, and President Benjamin Harrison signed proclamations that officially admitted South Dakota and North Dakota to union on November 2, 1889.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Harrison had the papers tight to obscure which was signed first and the order was not registered.

name: south_dakota
sentence: On 29 December 1890, the massacre of the injured knee occurred on the Pine Ridge Indian Reserve.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Considered the last major armed conflict between the United States and the Lakota Sioux Nation, the massacre resulted in the death of at least 146 Sioux, many of whom were women and children.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 31 American soldiers were also killed during the conflict.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 1930s, several economic and climate conditions combined with disastrous results for South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Lack of precipitation, extremely high temperatures and inappropriate cultivation techniques produced what was known as the Dust Bowl in South Dakota and several other plains states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The fertile soil was blown into massive dust storms, and several crops were completely destroyed.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The experiences of the Dust Bowl, coupled with the seizure of local banks and the general economic effects of the Great Depression, have led to the departure of many Dakotas from the south of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The population of South Dakota declined by more than 7 per cent between 1930 and 1940.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Economic stability returned with the entry of the United States into the Second World War in 1941, when demand for state agricultural and industrial products increased as the nation mobilized for the war.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1944, the Pick–Sloan Plan was adopted by the U.S. Congress as part of the 1944 Flood Control Act, resulting in the construction of six major dams on the Missouri River, four of which are at least partially located in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Flood control, hydropower and recreational activities such as boating and fishing are provided by dams and reservoirs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Over the past few decades, South Dakota has moved from an agricultural-dominated state to a more diversified state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The tourism industry has grown considerably since the completion of the interstate system in the 1960s, with the Black Hills becoming an increasingly important destination.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The financial services industry also began to grow in the state, with Citibank transferring its credit card transactions from New York to Sioux Falls in 1981, a move that was followed by several other financial companies.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota was the first State to eliminate interest ceilings.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2007, the recently closed Homestake Gold Mine site near Lead was selected as the site for a new underground research facility, the Deep Underground Science and Engineering Laboratory.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Despite the increase in the population of the State and recent economic development, many rural areas have struggled over the past 50 years with the decline of the local population and the emigration of educated young adults to the major cities of South Dakota, such as Rapid City or Sioux Falls, or to other states.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Mechanization and consolidation of agriculture have greatly contributed to the reduction in the number of small family farms and the resulting economic and demographic difficulties for rural cities.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, the state is often in the lead for its way of life, and Gallup's 2018 Well-Being Index named South Dakota the happiest and healthier state in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the South Dakota population was 884,659 as of July 1, 2019, an 8.66 per cent increase over the 2010 U.S. Census, while only North Dakota, Alaska, Vermont and Wyoming have fewer residents.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2019, South Dakota had an estimated population of 884,659, an increase of 70,479, or 8.66%, since 2010.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 7.3% of the population of South Dakota was under 5 years of age, 24% under 18 years of age and 14.3% at least 65 years of age.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Women accounted for approximately 50.2 per cent of the population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: According to the 2000 census, South Dakota was the fifth lowest in the nation in terms of population and population density.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Of South Dakota's inhabitants, 65.7 per cent were born in South Dakota, 31.4 per cent were born in another U.S. state, 0.6 per cent were born in Puerto Rico, the U.S. islands or abroad to U.S. parents, and 2.3 per cent were born in another country.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The South Dakota population centre is located in Buffalo County, in the unincorporated county seat of Gann Valley.

name: south_dakota
sentence: According to the 2010 Census, the racial composition of the population was as follows:

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ethnically, 2.7% of the population of South Dakota was of Hispanic, Latin or Spanish origin (they can be of any race).

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2011, 25.4% of South Dakota's population were minorities, meaning that they had at least one non-Hispanic white parent.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2000, the five largest ancestry groups in South Dakota were German (40.7%), Norwegian (15.3%), Irish (10.4%), Native American (8.3%), and English (7.1%).

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Germans are the largest ancestry group in most parts of the state, especially in the East River (east of Missouri), although there are also large Scandinavian populations in some counties.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has the largest population of Hutterites, a community group of Anabaptists who emigrated in 1874 from Europe, mostly from German-speaking regions.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Indians, largely Lakota, Dakota and Nakota (Sioux), are predominant in several counties and account for 20% of the West River population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The seven major Indian reserves of the state occupy a very small area compared to the former Sioux Great Reserve of West River, which the federal government had formerly allocated to the Sioux tribes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has the third largest proportion of Indians in any state, behind Alaska and New Mexico.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Five of the State's counties are within the boundaries of sovereign Indian reserves.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Due to the limitations of climate and land and the isolation of urban areas with higher employment opportunities, the standard of living on many South Dakota reserves is often well below the national average; Ziebach County ranked as the poorest of the nation in 2009.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The unemployment rate in Fort Thompson, Crow Creek Reserve, is 70 per cent, and 21 per cent of households do not have basic plumbing or kitchen equipment.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A 1995 study by the U.S. Census Bureau found that 58% of households on the Pine Ridge Indian Reserve did not have telephones.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The isolation of reserves also impedes their ability to generate income from gambling casinos, an avenue that has proved profitable for many tribes closer to urban centres.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 1995, the legislature passed a law to make English the "common language" of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since 2019, "the language of the Grand Sioux Nation, consisting of three dialects, Dakota, Lakota and Nakota" is an official language.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 2000 census, 1.90 per cent of the population aged 5 years or older speak German at home, 1.51 per cent speak Lakota or Dakota and 1.43 per cent speak Spanish.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2010, 93.46% (692,504) of South Dakota residents aged 5 years and older spoke English as their primary language.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 6.54 per cent of the population speak a language other than English.

name: south_dakota
sentence: 2.06 % (15,292) of the population speak Spanish, 1.39% (10,282) speak Dakota and 1.37% (10,140) speak German.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other languages spoken include Vietnamese (0.16 per cent), Chinese (0.12 per cent) and Russian (0.10 per cent).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Over the past few decades, the population of many rural areas has declined in South Dakota, as in other states of the Great Plains.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The change was described as a "rural leak" as family farming declined.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The young people settled in the cities to find another job.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This trend has continued in recent years, with 30 counties in South Dakota losing their population between the 1990 census and the 2000 census.

name: south_dakota
sentence: During this period, nine counties suffered a population loss of more than 10 per cent, with Harding County in the northwest corner of the state losing nearly 19 per cent of its population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Low birth rates and lack of young immigrants have led to an increase in the median age of many of these counties.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 24 counties, at least 20% of the population is over the age of 65, compared with a national rate of 12.8%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, the effect of rural leakage was not equally widespread in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although most rural counties and small towns have lost their population, the Sioux Falls region, the largest counties along Interstate 29, the Black Hills and many Indian reserves have all increased in population.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As reserves exercised more sovereignty, some Sioux returned from urban areas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Lincoln County near Sioux Falls was the fastest growing seventh (in percent) county in the United States in 2010.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Growth in these areas has compensated for losses in the rest of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The total population of South Dakota continues to increase steadily, although at a slower rate than the national average.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The largest denominations by membership in 2010 were the Roman Catholic Church with 148,883 members, the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America (ELCA) with 112,649 members, and the United Methodist Church (UMC) with 36,020 members.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (ELCA and UMC are specific denominations in the broader terms "Lutheran" and "methodist", respectively.

name: south_dakota
sentence: )The results of a 2001 survey, in which South Dakotas were invited to identify their religion, include:

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota's gross national product in current dollars was $39.8 billion in 2010, the fifth lowest state output in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Per capita personal income was $38,865 in 2010, ranking 25th in the United States, and 12.5 per cent of the population was below the poverty line in 2008.The list of the CNBC's Top States for Business for 2010 recognized South Dakota as the seventh best state of the nation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In July 2011, the state's unemployment rate was 4.7%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The service sector is the largest economic contributor to South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: This sector includes the retail, financial and health care sectors.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Citibank, which was the largest bank holding company in the United States at one time, established domestic banking operations in South Dakota in 1981 to take advantage of favourable banking rules.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Public spending is another important segment of the state economy, accounting for more than 10 per cent of gross national product.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ellsworth Air Force Base, near Rapid City, is the second largest single employer in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Agriculture has always been a key component of the South Dakota economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Although other industries have experienced rapid growth in recent decades, agricultural production remains very important for the state economy, especially in rural areas.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The five most valuable agricultural products in South Dakota are cattle, corn, soybeans, wheat and pigs.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Agriculture-related industries such as meat packaging and ethanol production also have a considerable economic impact on the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is the sixth-largest ethanol-producing state in the nation.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Tourism is another important sector of South Dakota's economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Many travel to see the attractions of the state, particularly those of the Black Hills area, such as the historic Deadwood, Rushmore Mount, and neighbouring national and state parks.

name: south_dakota
sentence: One of the most important tourism events in the state is the annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The five-day event attracted more than 739,000 participants in 2015; given the state has a total population of 850,000.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2006, tourism provided some 33,000 government jobs and contributed more than $2 billion to the South Dakota economy.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has 83,609 miles (134,556 km) of highways, roads and streets, and 679 miles (1,093 km) of interstate highways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Two major interstates cross South Dakota: Interstate 90, which crosses the southern half of the State to the east and west, and Interstate 29, which extends north and south in the eastern part of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Corridor I-29 has generally higher population and economic growth rates than eastern South Dakota regions more distant from the interstate.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Also in the state are the shorter Interstate 190, a spur in the centre of Rapid City, and 229, a loop around the south and east of Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Several major U.S. roads cross the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: U.S. roads 12, 14, 16, 18 and 212 run east and west, while U.S. roads 81, 83, 85 and 281 run north and south.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota and Montana are the only states that share a land boundary that is not crossed by an asphalt road.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota contains two national gateways.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Peter Norbeck National Scenic Byway is located in the Black Hills, while the Native American Scenic Byway runs along the Missouri River in the northern centre of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other scenic passages include Badlands Loop Scenic Byway, the Spearfish Canyon Scenic Byway and the Wildlife Loop Road Scenic Byway.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since the mid-19th century, railways have played an important role in transport in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Some 7,110 kilometres of railway were built in South Dakota in the late 19th century and early 20th century, but only 2,960 kilometres are active.

name: south_dakota
sentence: BNSF Railway is the largest railway in South Dakota; Rapid City, Pierre and Eastern Railroad (formerly Dakota, Minnesota, and East) is the other major carrier in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other Crown carriers include Dakota Southern Railway, Dakota and Iowa Railroad, Ellis and Eastern Railroad, Sunfloor Railroad, Canadian Pacific Railway and Sisseton Milbank Railroad.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rail transportation in the state is mainly freight, but there are two historic railways for passengers: the Black Hills Central and the Prairie Village, Herman and Milwaukee.

name: south_dakota
sentence: However, South Dakota is one of two adjacent states that lack Amtrak service.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (South Dakota is the only contiguous state that has never had Amtrak—Wyoming was served by the San Francisco Zephyr and Pioneer.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: The main commercial airports in South Dakota in terms of passenger traffic are the Sioux Falls Regional Airport and the Rapid City Regional Airport.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Delta Air Lines, Frontier Airlines and Allegiant Airlines, as well as the suburban airlines that use the affiliate brand with the major airlines, serve the two largest airports.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Several other government cities also have commercial air services: Aberdeen Regional Airport, Pierre Regional Airport and Watertown Regional Airport, some of which are subsidized by the Essential Air Service program.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Like other American states, the structure of the South Dakota government follows the same separation of powers as the federal government, with executive, legislative and judicial powers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The structure of the state government is defined in the Constitution of South Dakota, the highest law of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Constitution may be amended by a majority vote of both Houses of Parliament or by the initiative of the electorate.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Governor of South Dakota is the executive of the Government of the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The present governor is Kristi Noem, a Republican.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Constitution of the State gives the Governor the power to sign laws or bills on the veto adopted by the legislature of the State, to act as commander-in-chief of the National Guard of South Dakota, to appoint a cabinet and to commute criminal penalties or to pardon persons convicted of crimes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Governor is appointed for a term of four years and may not serve more than two consecutive terms.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The legislative power of the State is composed of two bodies, the 35-member Senate and the 70-member House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is divided into 35 legislative districts, with voters electing two representatives and one senator per district.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The legislature meets for an annual session which begins on the second Tuesday in January and lasts 30 days.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The judiciary is composed of several levels.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The State Supreme Court, composed of four judges and one chief justice, is the highest court in the State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Below the Supreme Court are the circuit courts.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Below the district courts are the courts of first instance, which deal with criminal and civil cases of lesser importance.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2005, South Dakota had the lowest national tax rate in the United States.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Crown does not collect personal or corporate income tax, estate tax, or taxes on intangible personal property.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The government's sales tax rate is 4.5%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Various localities have local levies, so in some areas the rate is 6%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The government's sales tax does not apply to Indian sales on Indian reserves, but many reserves have a pact with the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: On-reserve businesses collect the tax and government refunds from Indian tribes the percentage of sales tax collected in relation to the ratio of the Indian population to the total population in the affected county or area.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Ad valorem property taxes are local taxes and are an important source of financing for school systems, counties, municipalities and other local governments.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The Special Tax Division of South Dakota regulates certain taxes, including cigarette and alcohol taxes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is represented at the federal level by Senator John Thune, Senator Mike Rounds and Representative Dusty Johnson.

name: south_dakota
sentence: All three of them are Republicans.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is one of the seven states with only one seat in the United States House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the United States presidential elections, South Dakota received three out of 538 votes in the Electoral College.

name: south_dakota
sentence: As in all other states with the exception of the neighbouring Maine and Nebraska, South Dakota's electoral votes are granted in a win-win-all system.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota politics is generally dominated by the Republican Party.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Since the creation of the state, the Republicans have won state electoral votes in all but five presidential elections: 1896, 1912 (by the Progressive Party of Theodore Roosevelt), 1932, 1936 and 1964.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (Democratic George McGovern, from South Dakota, did not bear his original status in 1972.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: Only Alaska has been transported fewer times by a democrat.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Moreover, a democrat has not won the post of governor since 1974.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2016, the Republicans hold a 15% registration advantage over the Democrats and hold large majorities in the Chamber of State and the Senator of State.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Despite the general republican and conservative tendencies of the state, Democrats have been successful in various state-wide elections, including those involving representatives of the South Dakota Congress in Washington.

name: south_dakota
sentence: American Indians have become more active in state and county electoral politics.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In the 2002 election, the American Indian vote brought Tim Johnson as a democratic candidate by a margin of 532 votes.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Until his election defeat in 2004, Senator Tom Daschle was the Senators' minority leader (and briefly his majority leader during the democratic control of Senators in 2001–2002).

name: south_dakota
sentence: Other prominent South Dakota Democrats include former presidential candidates, George McGovern and Hubert Humphrey.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2016, South Dakota voted for Republican candidate Donald Trump compared to democratic candidate Hillary Clinton with a margin of 30%.

name: south_dakota
sentence: In 2018, Republican MP Kristi Noem defeated Democrat Billie Sutton in the Liberal election by a small margin, and Republican Dusty Johnson defeated Democrat Tim Bjorkman for sitting in the United States House of Representatives.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Contemporary political issues in South Dakota include the costs and benefits of the state lottery, the relatively low ranking of South Dakota in education spending (especially teachers' compensation — recently, the state sales tax has been increased from 4% to 4.5% to finance an increase in teachers' remuneration), and recent legislative and electoral attempts to ban abortion in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A bill supported by the Republicans passed in March 2019 requires that all public schools display "In God we trust" in a prominent place.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota culture reflects the American, rural, western and European roots of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: A number of annual events celebrating the state's ethnic and historical heritage are held around the state, such as Days of '76 in Deadwood, Czech Days in Tabor, and the annual festivities of St. Patrick and Cinco de Mayo in Sioux Falls.

name: south_dakota
sentence: The different tribes hold many annual pow wows on their reserves throughout the state, to which non-indigenous Americans are sometimes invited.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Custer State Park holds an annual Buffalo Roundup, where horse volunteers gather the park's herd of approximately 1,500 bison.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Black Elk (Lakota) was a medical and heyokha man whose life spanned the transition to reservations.

name: south_dakota
sentence: His stories of the Indian War movement and 19th-century phantom dance, as well as his deep thoughts on personal visions and Amerindian religion, form the basis of the book Black Elk Speaks, first published in 1932.

name: south_dakota
sentence: (In several editions a first annotated edition was published in 2008.)

name: south_dakota
sentence: Paul Goble, an award-winning author and illustrator of children's books, was based in the Black Hills in 1977.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Laura Ingalls Wilder, whose semi-autobiographical books are based on her experiences as a child and young adult at the border, is one of the best known writers in South Dakota.

name: south_dakota
sentence: She took her life from a house near De Smet to found five of her novels: By the Shores of Silver Lake, The Long Winter, Little Town on the Prairie, This Happy Golden Years and The First Four Years.

name: south_dakota
sentence: They gained a renewed popularity in the United States when Little House on the Prairie was adapted and produced as a television series in 1974.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Wilder's daughter, Rose Wilder Lane, who became a well-known writer in her own right, was born near De Smet in 1886.

name: south_dakota
sentence: South Dakota has also produced a number of notable artists.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Harvey Dunn grew up on a house near Manchester at the end of the 19th century.

name: south_dakota
sentence: While Dunn worked most of his career as a commercial illustrator, his most famous works showed various scenes of border life; he finished these near the end of his career.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Oscar Howe (Crow) was born on Crow Creek Indian Reserve and won fame for his watercolor paintings.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Howe was one of the first Amerindian painters to adopt techniques and styles strongly influenced by the mid-20th century abstraction movement, rather than relying on traditional Amerindian styles.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Terry Redlin, a native of Watertown, is an accomplished painter of rural scenes and wildlife.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Many of his works are on display at the Redlin Art Center in Watertown.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Sioux Falls is the largest city in South Dakota, with a population of 153,888 inhabitants in 2010, and a metropolitan area of 238,122 inhabitants.The city, founded in 1856, is located in the southeast corner of the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Retailing, finance and health care became more important in Sioux Falls, where the economy was originally focused on agro-industry and careers.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City, with a population of 67,956 and a metropolitan area of 124,766 inhabitants, is the second largest city in the state.

name: south_dakota
sentence: It is located at the east end of the Black Hills and was founded in 1876.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Rapid City's economy is largely based on tourism and defence spending, due to the proximity to many tourist attractions in the Black Hills and Ellsworth Air Force Base.

name: south_dakota
sentence: Aberdeen (26,091), Brookings (22,056), Watertown (21,482), Mitchell (15,254), Yankton (14,454), Pierre (13,646), Huron (12,592), and Vermillion (10,571).

name: south_dakota

sentence: The present Texas Constitution was adopted in 1876.

sentence: The State Bill of Rights is much larger than its federal bill of rights and contains Texas-specific provisions.

name: texas
sentence: Texas has a plural executive branch system limiting the power of the governor, which is a weak executive compared to other states.

name: texas
sentence: With the exception of the Secretary of State, electors elect leaders independently, so candidates are directly accountable to the public and not to the Governor.

name: texas
sentence: This electoral system led to the division of certain executive powers between the parties and reduced the governor's ability to implement a program.

sentence: When Republican President George W. Bush was Governor of Texas, the state had a democratic lieutenant governor, Bob Bullock.

sentence: Executive positions include the Governor, the Lieutenant Governor, the Comptroller of Public Accounts, the Land Commissioner, the Attorney General, the Commissioner of Agriculture, the Texas Railway Commission, the State Council of Education and the Secretary of State.

name: texas
sentence: The Texas bicameral legislature consists of the House of Representatives, with 150 members, and a senator, with 31 members.

sentence: The Speaker of the House leads the House, and the Lieutenant Governor, the senator.

sentence: The legislature meets in ordinary session every two years for just over a hundred days, but the governor may request extraordinary sessions as often as desired (notably, the legislature cannot meet).

sentence: Texas's judicial power is one of the most complex in the United States, with many layers and overlapping jurisdictions.

sentence: The party has also attracted some minorities, but many have continued to vote for democratic candidates.

name: utah
sentence: Utah (YOO-tah, (listening) YOO-taw) is a state in the United States of America.

name: utah
sentence: It is bounded by Colorado to the east, Wyoming to the northeast, Idaho to the north, Arizona to the south and Nevada to the west.

name: utah
sentence: It also touches a corner of New Mexico in the south-east.

name: utah
sentence: Of the fifty American states, Utah is the 13th largest by region; with a population of more than three million, it is the 30th most populous and the 11th least dense.

name: utah
sentence: Urban development is concentrated mainly in two areas: the Wasatch Front in the north-central part of the state, which is home to about two thirds of the population and includes the capital, Salt Lake City; and Washington County in the south, which has more than 170,000 inhabitants.

name: utah
sentence: Most of the western Utah is located in the Great Basin.

name: utah
sentence: The territory of modern Utah has been inhabited by various indigenous groups for thousands of years, including the former Puebloans, Navajo and the Ute.

name: utah
sentence: The Spaniards were the first Europeans to arrive in the middle of the 16th century, although the region's difficult geography and climate made it a peripheral part of New Spain and later Mexico.

name: utah
sentence: Although it was part of Mexico, many early Utah settlers were American, especially Mormons fleeing the marginalization and persecution of the United States.

name: utah
sentence: After the war between Mexico and America, it is part of Utah territory, which includes what is now Colorado and Nevada.

name: utah
sentence: Disputes between the dominant Mormon community and the federal government delayed the admission of Utah as a state; it was only after the ban on polygamy that it was admitted as 45th in 1896.

name: utah
sentence: Just over half of all Uthahs are Mormons, the vast majority of whom are members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Last-Day Saints (LDS Church), which has its world headquarters in Salt Lake City.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is the only state where the majority of the population belongs to a single Church.

name: utah
sentence: The LDS Church greatly influences Utahn's culture, politics and daily life, although, since the 1990s, the state has become more religiously and secularly diverse.

name: utah
sentence: The State has a very diverse economy, with important sectors such as transportation, education, information and research technologies, government services, mining, and an important tourist destination for outdoor recreation.

name: utah
sentence: In 2013, the U.S. Census Bureau estimated that Utah had the largest population of all states.

name: utah
sentence: Between 2000 and 2005, St. George was the fastest growing metropolitan area in the United States.

name: utah
sentence: Utah also has the highest median income and the lowest income inequality of all US states.

name: utah
sentence: A 2012 Gallup National Survey revealed that Utah was generally the "best future life" based on 13 forward-looking measures, including various measures of the economy, lifestyle and health-related perspectives.

name: utah
sentence: It is said that the name Utah derives from the name of the Ute tribe, which means "people of the mountains."

name: utah
sentence: However, no such word actually exists in the Utes language, and the Utes refer to themselves as Noochee.

name: utah
sentence: The meaning of Utes as "the mountain people" has been attributed to neighbouring Pueblo Indians, as well as to the word Apache Yuttahih, which means "the one who is higher" or "those who are higher".

name: utah
sentence: Thousands of years before the arrival of European explorers, the Puebloans Ancestral and the Fremont people lived in what is now called Utah, some of which spoke the languages of the Uto-Aztecan group.

name: utah
sentence: The ancestral Pueblo built their houses by excavations in the mountains, and the Fremont built straw houses before disappearing from the area around the 15th century.

name: utah
sentence: Another group of Native Americans, Navajo, settled in the area around the 18th century.

name: utah
sentence: In the middle of the 18th century, other Uto-Aztecan tribes, including the Goshute, the Paiute, the Shoshone and the Ute people, also settled in the area.

name: utah
sentence: The five groups were present when the first European explorers arrived.

name: utah
sentence: The southern region of Utah was explored by the Spaniards in 1540, under the direction of Francisco Vázquez de Coronado, while seeking the legendary Cíbola.

name: utah
sentence: A group led by two Catholic priests – sometimes called the Domínguez-Escalante expedition – left Santa Fe in 1776 in the hope of finding a route to the Californian coast.

name: utah
sentence: The expedition travelled as far north as Lake Utah and met with the natives.

name: utah
sentence: The Spaniards made further explorations in the area, but were not interested in colonizing the region because of its desert character.

name: utah
sentence: In 1821, when Mexico gained its independence from Spain, the region became known as part of its Alta California territory.

name: utah
sentence: In the early 19th century, European trappers and fur traders explored certain areas of Utah from Canada and the United States.

name: utah
sentence: The town of Provo, Utah, was named in honour of Étienne Provost, who visited the region in 1825.

name: utah
sentence: The city of Ogden, Utah, is named after Peter Skene Ogden, a Canadian explorer who traded furs in the Weber Valley.

name: utah
sentence: Because of the high salinity of his waters, He thought he had found the Pacific Ocean; he later learned that this body of water was a giant salt lake.

name: utah
sentence: After the discovery of the lake, hundreds of American and Canadian traders and trappers established trading posts in the region.

name: utah
sentence: In the 1830s, thousands of migrants from the eastern U.S. to the western U.S. began to stop in the area of Great Salt Lake, then known as Lake Youta.

name: utah
sentence: After the death of Joseph Smith in 1844, Brigham Young, as president of the Quorum of Twelve, became the effective leader of the LDS church in Nauvoo, Illinois.

name: utah
sentence: In order to cope with the growing conflicts between his people and his neighbours, Young agreed with Illinois Governor Thomas Ford in October 1845 that the Mormons would depart by the following year.

name: utah
sentence: Young and the first band of Mormon pioneers arrived in the Salt Lake Valley on July 24, 1847.

name: utah
sentence: Over the next 22 years, more than 70,000 pioneers have crossed the plains and settled in Utah.

sentence: During the early years, Brigham Young and the thousands of first settlers in Salt Lake City fought to survive.

name: utah
sentence: The arid desert land was judged by the Mormons to be desirable as a place where they could practice their religion without harassment.

sentence: During the winter of 1847, settlers buried thirty-six Amerindians in a grave after a measles outbreak.

name: utah
sentence: Among the most important settlements in Utah are St. George, Logan and Manti (where the settlers completed the first three Utah temples, each having started after but completed several years before the larger and better-known Salt Lake City temple was completed in 1893), as well as Parowan, Cedar City, Bluff, Moab, Vernal, Fillmore (which served as the territorial capital between 1850 and 1856), Nephi, Levan, Spanish Fork, Springville, Provo Bench (now Orem), Pleasant Grove, American Fork, Lehi, Sandy, Murray, Jordan, Centerville, Farmington, Huntsville, Kaysville, Grantsville, Tooele, Roy, Brigham City and many other smaller towns and settlements.

sentence: When the so-called rebellion ended, Alfred Cumming would take the place of Brigham Young as territorial governor.

sentence: In September 1857, about 120 American settlers of the Baker-Fancher ferry train, en route to California from Arkansas, were murdered by Utah Territorial Militia and some Paiute Native Americans in the Mountain Meadows massacre.

sentence: Before the troops led by Albert Sidney Johnston entered the territory, Brigham Young ordered all residents of Salt Lake City to evacuate south to the Utah Valley and sent the Nauvoo Legion to delay the government's advance.

sentence: Beginning in 1865, the Black Hawk War in Utah turned into the most deadly conflict in the territory's history.

sentence: When Utah again requested to become a state, it was accepted.

sentence: One of the conditions for granting Utah State status was that a prohibition on polygamy should be included in the constitution of the State.

sentence: State status was formally granted on 4 January 1896.

name: utah
sentence: From the beginning of the 20th century, with the establishment of national parks such as Bryce Canyon National Park and Zion National Park, Utah became known for its natural beauty.

name: utah
sentence: Southern Utah has become a popular filming place for arid and robust scenes presented in the popular mid-western century genre.

name: utah
sentence: In such films, most American residents recognize natural monuments such as Delicate Arch and the "Mittens" of Monument Valley.

name: utah
sentence: During the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s, the construction of the interstate road network facilitated access to picturesque areas in the south.

name: utah
sentence: Since the creation of the Alta ski resort in 1939 and the development of several ski resorts in the state mountains, Utah skiing has become internationally recognized.

name: utah
sentence: The dry and powdery snow of the Wasatch chain is considered to be one of the best skiers in the world (the state license plate once claimed "the greatest snow on earth").

name: utah
sentence: Salt Lake City won the 2002 Olympic Winter Games Award, which greatly boosted the economy.

name: utah
sentence: Ski resorts have gained popularity and many of the Olympic sites built along the Wasatch Front continue to be used for sporting events.

name: utah
sentence: The preparation of the Olympic Games stimulated the development of the light rail system in the Salt Lake Valley, known as TRAX, and the reconstruction of the highway system around the city.

name: utah
sentence: In 1957 Utah established the Utah State Parks Commission with four parks.

name: utah
sentence: Today, Utah's state parks manage 43 parks and several undeveloped areas totalling more than 95,000 acres (380 km2) of land and more than 1,000,000 acres (4,000 km2) of water.

name: utah
sentence: Utah State Parks are scattered throughout Utah, from Bear Lake State Park on the Utah/Idaho border to Edge of the Cedars State Park Museum in the heart of the Four Corners area and everywhere in between.

name: utah
sentence: Utah State Parks also house the State Off-Road Vehicle Office, the State Office of Recreational Navigation and the Trails Program.

name: utah
sentence: By the end of the 20th century, the state grew rapidly.

name: utah
sentence: In the 1970s growth was phenomenal in the suburbs of the Wasatch Front.

name: utah
sentence: Sandy was one of the fastest growing cities in the country at the time.

name: utah
sentence: Today, many parts of Utah continue to grow upwards.

name: utah
sentence: North Davis, south and west of Salt Lake, summit, east of Tooele, Utah, Wasatch and Washington counties are all growing very rapidly.

name: utah
sentence: Transport management and urbanization are important policy issues, as development consumes agricultural land and wild areas, and transportation is one of the main reasons for poor air quality in Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is known for its natural diversity and contains elements ranging from arid deserts with sand dunes to flourishing pine forests in mountain valleys.

name: utah
sentence: It is a rugged and geographically diverse state with the convergence of three distinct geological regions: the Rocky Mountains, the Great Basin and the Colorado Plateau.

name: utah
sentence: Utah covers an area of 84,899 m2 (119,890 km2).

name: utah
sentence: It is bordered by Idaho to the north, Wyoming to the north and east, Colorado to the east, only one point by New Mexico to the south-east, Arizona to the south and Nevada to the west.

name: utah
sentence: Only three U.S. states (Utah, Colorado and Wyoming) have exclusively latitude and longitude lines as their boundaries.

name: utah
sentence: One of the defining features of Utah is its variety of terrain.

name: utah
sentence: In the middle of the northern third of the state is the Wasatch chain, which reaches heights of almost 12,000 feet (3,700 m) above sea level.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is home to world-renowned ski resorts made popular by light, soft snow and winter storms that regularly accumulate up to three feet of it all night.

name: utah
sentence: In the northeast section of the state, from east to west, are the Uinta Mountains, which reach heights of more than 13,000 feet (4,000 m).

name: utah
sentence: The highest point of the state, Kings Peak, at 13.528 feet (4.123 m), is in the Uinta Mountains.

name: utah
sentence: At the western base of the Wasatch Range is the Wasatch Front, a series of valleys and basins that house the most populous parts of the state.

name: utah
sentence: It extends approximately from the city of Brigham at the north end to Nephi at the south end.

name: utah
sentence: About 75 per cent of the population of the state lives in this corridor, and population growth is rapid.

name: utah
sentence: Western Utah is primarily an arid desert with a basin and a range topography.

name: utah
sentence: Small mountain ranges and rugged terrain punctuate the landscape.

name: utah
sentence: The Bonneville Salt Flats are an exception, being relatively flat following the formation of the bed of the old Lake Bonneville.

name: utah
sentence: Great Salt Lake, Lake Utah, Lake Sevier and Rush Lake are all remnants of this old freshwater lake that once covered most of the Eastern Great Basin.

name: utah
sentence: To the west of Great Salt Lake, which extends to the Nevada border, is the arid desert of Great Salt Lake.

name: utah
sentence: An exception to this aridity is the snake valley, which is (relatively) lush due to the large springs and wetlands fed by groundwater from snowmelt in the Snake Range, the Deep Creek Range and other high mountains west of the snake valley.

name: utah
sentence: Great Basin National Park is located just above the Nevada State Line in the south of the Snake Range.

name: utah
sentence: One of the most impressive but least visited attractions in western Utah is Notch Peak, the highest limestone cliff in North America, west of Delta.

name: utah
sentence: Most of the picturesque landscapes of the south and south-east (including the Colorado Plateau region) are sandstone, particularly Kayenta sandstone and Navajo sandstone.

name: utah
sentence: The Colorado River and its tributaries flow through the sandstone, creating some of the most striking and wildest lands in the world (the area around the confluence of the Colorado and Green rivers was the last to be mapped in the lower 48 United States).

name: utah
sentence: Wind and rain have also carved soft sandstone over the millions of years.

name: utah
sentence: Canyons, gulls, arches, pinnacles, buttocks, bluffs and mesas are common in south-central and southeast Utah.

name: utah
sentence: This land is the central feature of protected state and federal national parks such as Arches, Bryce Canyon, Canyonlands, Capitol Reef and Zion, Cedar Breaks, Grand Staircase-Escalante, Hovenweep, and Natural Bridges National Monuments, Glen Canyon National Recreation Area (popular tourist destination site, Powell Lake), Dead Horse Point and Goblin Valley State Parks, and Monument Valley.

name: utah
sentence: The Navajo Nation also extends to the southeast of Utah.

name: utah
sentence: The southeastern Utah is also punctuated by distant mountain ranges, but raised La Sal, Abajo and Henry.

name: utah
sentence: Eastern Utah (northern quarter) is a high-altitude area covered mainly by plateaus and basins, in particular the Tavaputs plateau and the San Rafael swell, which remain largely inaccessible, and the Uinta basin, where the majority of the eastern Utah population lives.

name: utah
sentence: Savings are dominated by mining, oil shale, oil, natural gas drilling, livestock and recreation.

name: utah
sentence: Much of eastern Utah is part of the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reserve.

name: utah
sentence: The most popular destination in northeastern Utah is Dinosaur National Monument near Vernal.

name: utah
sentence: Southwestern Utah is the lowest and warmest place in Utah.

name: utah
sentence: It is known as Dixie de l'Utah because the first settlers were able to grow cotton.

name: utah
sentence: Beaverdam Wash in the extreme southwest of Utah is the lowest point in the state at 2,000 feet (610 m).

name: utah
sentence: The northernmost part of the Mojave Desert is also in this region.

name: utah
sentence: Dixie quickly became a popular destination for leisure and retirement, and the population was growing rapidly.

name: utah
sentence: Although the Wasatch Mountains end at Mount Nebo near Nephi, a complex series of mountain ranges extend south of the south end of the chain in the spine of Utah.

name: utah
sentence: Just north of Dixie and east of Cedar City is the state's highest ski resort, Brian Head.

name: utah
sentence: Like most western and southwestern states, the federal government owns much of the land in Utah.

name: utah
sentence: More than 70 percent of the land is either land BLM, Utah State Trustland, or US National Forest, USA National Park, US National Monument, National Recreation Area or US Wilderness Area.

name: utah
sentence: Utah is the only state in which each county contains national forests.

name: utah
sentence: Utah has a dry, semi-arid climate in the desert, although its many mountains have a wide variety of climates, the highest points in the Uinta mountains being above the wood line.

name: utah
sentence: Dry weather is a result of the state location in the rain shadow of Sierra Nevada, California.

name: utah
sentence: Half of the state is in the rain shadow of the Wasatch Mountains.

name: utah
sentence: The main source of precipitation for the state is the Pacific Ocean, usually on the path to major Pacific storms from October to May.

name: utah
sentence: In the summer, the state, especially the south and east of Utah, is on the path to monsoon moisture from the Gulf of California.

name: utah
sentence: Most lowland areas receive less than 12 inches (305 mm) of precipitation per year, although corridor I-15, including the densely populated Wasatch Front, receives approximately 15 inches (381 mm).

name: utah
sentence: The Great Salt Lake Desert is the driest area of the state, with less than 5 inches (127 mm).

name: utah
sentence: Snowfall is common in all valleys except in southern valleys.

name: utah
sentence: Although St. George receives only about 3 inches (76 mm) per year, Salt Lake City sees about 60 inches (1,524 mm), increased by snow from the Great Salt Lake effect, increasing total snowfall to the south, southeast and east of the lake.

name: utah
sentence: Some areas of the Wasatch range on the lake effect trail receive up to 500 inches (12,700 mm) per year.

name: utah
sentence: This micro-climate of increased snowfall from Great Salt Lake covers the whole vicinity of the lake.

name: utah
sentence: The cotton canyons adjacent to Salt Lake City are located in the right position to receive more precipitation from the lake.

name: utah
sentence: The ever-deep snowpowder led the Utah ski industry to adopt the slogan "The biggest snow on earth" in the 1980s.

name: utah
sentence: In winter, temperature inversions are a common phenomenon in the lower Utah basins and valleys, resulting in thick fog and fog that can last weeks at a time, especially in the Uintah basin.

name: utah
sentence: Although at other times of the year its air quality is good, winter reversals give Salt Lake City one of the worst winter pollution in the country.

name: utah
sentence: Previous studies have shown a widespread decline in snow quantity above Utah, accompanied by a decrease in the snow-precipitation ratio, while anecdotal claims have been made that the measured changes in Utah snow quantity are misleading and do not reflect actual changes.

name: utah
sentence: A 2012 study found that the proportion of winter precipitation (January to March) that falls as snow has decreased by nine percent over the last half century, a combined result of a significant increase in precipitation and a slight decrease in snowfall.

name: utah
sentence: Meanwhile, the depth of snow observed across Utah decreased and was accompanied by a steady decrease in snow cover and surface albedo.

name: utah
sentence: Weather systems likely to produce precipitation in Utah have decreased in number, with those producing snowfall decreasing at a significantly higher rate.

name: utah
sentence: Utah's temperatures are extreme, with cold temperatures in winter due to its altitude, and very hot summers on a state-wide scale (with the exception of mountain areas and high mountain valleys).

name: utah
sentence: Utah is usually protected from large cold air explosions by mountains to the north and east of the state, although large arctic explosions may occasionally reach the state.

name: utah
sentence: January mean high temperatures range from about 30°F (−1°C) in some northern valleys to almost 55°F (13°C) in St. George.

name: utah
sentence: Temperatures below 0°F (−18°C) should be expected occasionally in most parts of the state in most years, although some regions often see it (for example, the city of Randolph has an average of about fifty days a year with such low temperatures).

name: utah
sentence: In July, average heights range from 85 to 100°F (29 to 38°C).

name: utah
sentence: However, low humidity and high elevation usually result in large temperature variations, resulting in cool nights on most summer days.

sentence: Washington, officially the State of Washington, is a state in the northwestern Pacific region of the United States.

name: washington
sentence: Named for George Washington, the first American president, the state was formed from the western part of Washington territory, which was ceded by the British Empire in 1846, in accordance with the Oregon Treaty in the settlement of the Oregon border dispute.

name: washington
sentence: The state, bordered to the west by the Pacific Ocean, Oregon to the south, Idaho to the east, and the Canadian province of British Columbia to the north, was admitted to the Union as the 42nd state in 1889.

sentence: Olympia is the capital of the State.

name: washington
sentence: Washington is often referred to as Washington State to distinguish it from the nation's capital, Washington, D.C.

name: washington

sentence: The rest of the state consists of deep temperate rainforests to the west; mountain ranges to the west, the centre, the north-east and the extreme south-east; and a semi-arid basin region to the east, the centre and the south, ceded to intensive agriculture.

sentence: Washington is the second most populated state on the west and west coasts of the United States, after California.

sentence: Livestock and livestock products contribute significantly to overall agricultural revenues, and commercial salmon, halibut and groundfish fisheries make a significant contribution to the government economy.

sentence: More to the east, the climate becomes less arid, with annual precipitation increasing as we go east as much as 21.2 inches (540 mm) at Pullman, near the Washington-Idaho border.

sentence: As described above, the climate in Washington varies considerably from west to east.

name: washington
sentence: A Mediterranean climate prevails in western Washington and a much drier semi-arid climate prevails east of the Cascade chain.

name: washington
sentence: The main factors that determine Washington's climate are the large semi-permanent high-pressure and low-pressure systems of the northern Pacific Ocean, the continental air masses of North America, and the Olympic and Cascade Mountains.

name: washington
sentence: In the spring and summer, a high-pressure anticyclone system dominates the northern Pacific Ocean, causing a clockwise spiral of air.

name: washington
sentence: For Washington, this means that the prevailing northwestern winds bring relatively fresh air and a predictable drought season.

name: washington
sentence: In the fall and winter, a system of low-pressure cyclones takes over in the northern Pacific Ocean.

name: washington
sentence: The inward spiral air in the opposite direction of the clockwise makes the prevailing winds of Washington come from the southwest, and brings relatively warm and humid air masses and a likely wet season.

name: washington
sentence: The term "Pineapple Express" is commonly used to describe the events of the atmospheric river, where repeated storm systems are led by this persistent cyclone in the tropical and quasi-tropical regions of the Pacific in the northwest Pacific.

name: washington
sentence: Although the west of Washington has a marine climate similar to many coastal cities in Europe, there are exceptions such as the events of "Big Snow" in 1880, 1881, 1893 and 1916, and the winters of "Deep Freezing" in 1883–84, 1915–1916, 1949–1950 and 1955–1956, among others.

name: washington
sentence: During these events, western Washington experienced up to 1,800 metres of snow, temperatures below 18 °C, three months of snow on the ground, and frozen lakes and rivers for weeks.

name: washington
sentence: The lowest officially recorded temperature in Seattle is 0°F (−18°C) set on January 31, 1950, but low-lying areas at about three hours from Seattle recorded lows as cold as −48°F (−44°C).

name: washington
sentence: Southern oscillation greatly influences weather during the cold season.

name: washington
sentence: During the El Niño phase, the jet enters the United States further south by California, so late fall and winter are drier than normal with less snow.

name: washington
sentence: The La Niña phase reinforces the jet across the Pacific Northwest, so Washington has more rain and snow than the average.

name: washington
sentence: In 2006, the University of Washington's Climate Impacts Group published The Impacts of Climate Change in Washington's Economy, a preliminary assessment of the risks and opportunities presented, considering the possibility of rising global temperatures and their effects on Washington's state.

name: washington
sentence: In Washington, rainfall varies considerably from east to west.

sentence: The western part of the Olympic Peninsula receives up to 160 inches (4,100 mm) of precipitation each year, making it the wettest area in the 48 neighbouring states and a temperate rainforest.

name: washington
sentence: Weeks can pass without a clear day.

sentence: The west slopes of the Cascade Range receive some of the largest annual snowfalls (in some areas more than 200 inches or 5,100 millimetres of water equivalent) in the country.

sentence: In the area of the rain shadow east of the Cascades, the annual precipitation is only 6 inches (150 mm).

sentence: The Olympic mountains and waterfalls aggravate this climate pattern by causing an orographical uplift of blowing air masses inside the Pacific Ocean, resulting in high precipitation levels on the wind side of the mountains and low levels on the left side.

name: washington
sentence: In both cases, slopes facing the southwest wind receive high precipitation and mild and cool temperatures.

sentence: Although the lowlands of the Puget Strait are known for clouds and rain in winter, the western slopes of the Cascades receive greater amounts of precipitation, often falling as snow at higher altitudes.

sentence: The state of Washington is one of seven states that do not levy personal income tax.

name: washington
sentence: Nor does the Crown collect corporate income tax or deductible.

name: washington
sentence: Washington businesses are responsible for various other government levies, including business tax and labour tax (B & O), a gross revenue tax that imposes variable rates for different types of businesses.

name: washington
sentence: The sales tax on the Washington State Base is 6.5%, which is combined with a local sales tax that varies by locality.

name: washington
sentence: The combined rates of government sales tax and local retail sales tax increase the taxes paid by consumers, depending on the variable rates of local sales tax, usually between 7.5% and 10%.

name: washington
sentence: As of March 2017, the combined sales tax rate in Seattle and Tacoma was 10.1%.

name: washington
sentence: The cities of Lynnwood and Mill Creek have the highest selling tax rate in the state at 10.5%.

name: washington
sentence: These taxes apply both to services and to products.

name: washington
sentence: Most food is exempt from sales tax.

name: washington
sentence: However, prepared foods, food supplements, and soft drinks remain taxable.

name: washington
sentence: An excise tax applies to certain products such as petrol, cigarettes and alcoholic beverages.

name: washington
sentence: Property tax was the first tax levied in the state of Washington, and its collection accounts for about 30 per cent of total government and local government revenue in Washington.

name: washington
sentence: It continues to be the primary source of income for public schools, fire protection, libraries, parks and recreation, and other special-purpose districts.

name: washington
sentence: All real and personal property is subject to tax unless specifically exempted by law.

name: washington
sentence: Most personal property belonging to individuals is exempt from tax.

name: washington
sentence: The personal property tax applies to personal property used in the conduct of a business or to other personal property not exempt by law.

name: washington
sentence: All property taxes are paid to the office of the treasurer of the county where the property is located.

name: washington
sentence: Washington does not impose taxes on intangible assets, such as bank accounts, shares or bonds.

name: washington
sentence: Nor does the Crown calculate tax on retirement income earned and received from another state.

name: washington
sentence: Washington does not charge taxes on the estate.

name: washington
sentence: However, estate tax is decoupled from federal estate tax laws and, therefore, the Crown imposes its own estate tax.

name: washington
sentence: The state of Washington has the 18th highest per capita effective tax rate in the United States in 2017.

name: west_virginia
sentence: West Virginia was the only state in the Union to separate from a Confederate State (Virginia) during the American Civil War.

name: west_virginia
sentence: In Richmond on April 17, 1861, the 1861 Virginia Secession Agreement voted for the secession of the Union, but of the 49 delegates from the northwest corner (who eventually became West Virginia) only 17 voted in favour of the secession order, while 30 voted against (with two abstentions).

Carlile favoured the immediate formation of a new state, while others led by Waitman Willey argued that since Virginia's secession had not yet been adopted by the required referendum (as happened on 23 May), such action would constitute a revolution against the United States.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The convention decided that if the Virginians adopted the secession order (of which there was little doubt), another convention including the elected members of the legislature would meet at Wheeling in June 1861.

sentence: On May 23, 1861, the secession was ratified by a large majority in Virginia as a whole, but in western counties 34,677 voted against and 19,121 voted in favour.

name: west_virginia
sentence: The Second Wheeling Convention met as agreed on 11 June and stated that, since the Secession Convention had been called without popular consent, all its actions were null and void and that all those who had acceded to it had left their offices.

sentence: The Wheeling Conventions, and the delegates themselves, were never elected by public ballot to act on behalf of West Virginia.

sentence: Wisconsin is a state in the U.S. Midwest Great Lakes region bordered by Minnesota to the west; Iowa to the southwest; Illinois to the south; Lake Michigan to the east; Michigan to the northeast; and Lake Superior to the north.

name: wisconsin
