name: wisconsin
sentence: The word Wisconsin comes from the name given to the Wisconsin River by one of the Algonquian Indian groups living in the region at the time of European contact.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The French explorer Jacques Marquette was the first European to reach the Wisconsin River, arriving in 1673 and calling the Meskousing River (probably "meskowsin") in his newspaper.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Subsequently, French writers changed the spelling from Meskousing to Ouisconsin, which over time became the name of the Wisconsin River and the surrounding lands.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Anglophones anglicize Ouisconsin's spelling in Wisconsin when they began to arrive in large numbers in the early 19th century.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Legislative Assembly of the territory of Wisconsin made the spelling in force in 1845.

name: wisconsin
sentence: The Algonquian word for Wisconsin and its original meaning became obscure.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Although interpretations vary, most involve the river and the red sandstone bordering its shores.

name: wisconsin
sentence: A main theory holds that the name comes from the word Miami Meskonsing, meaning "it is red", a reference to the setting of the Wisconsin River as it flows through the reddish sandstone of the Dells of Wisconsin.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Other theories include allegations that the name comes from a variety of Ojibwa words meaning "red stone place", "where waters come together," or "great rock."

sentence: Wisconsin has been home to a wide variety of crops over the last 14,000 years.

name: wisconsin

name: wisconsin
sentence: After the end of the glacial age around 8000 BC, the people of the next archaic period lived by hunting, fishing and gathering food from wild plants.

name: wisconsin
sentence: Agricultural societies gradually emerged during the timber period between 1000 and 1000 BC.

sentence: Towards the end of this period, Wisconsin was the heart of the "effigy mound culture", which built thousands of animal-shaped mounds across the landscape.

sentence: Later, between 1000 and 1500 CE, the Mississippi and Oneota cultures built important settlements, including the fortified village of Aztalan in southeastern Wisconsin.

sentence: The French residents at the trading post in what is today Green Bay, called the city "La Baye", however the British fur traders called it "Green Bay", because the water and the shore took green shades in early spring.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming (German: Wyoming) is a landlocked state in the western United States.

name: wyoming
sentence: The 10th largest state per zone, it is also the least populated and densely populated state of the contiguous United States.

name: wyoming
sentence: It is bordered by Montana to the north and north-west, South Dakota and Nebraska to the east, Idaho to the west, Utah to the south-west, and Colorado to the south.

name: wyoming
sentence: The state population was estimated at 578,759 in 2019.

name: wyoming
sentence: The capital of the State and the most populated city is Cheyenne, whose population is estimated at 63,957 in 2018.

name: wyoming
sentence: The western half of Wyoming is primarily covered by the ranges and routes of the Rocky Mountains, while the eastern half of the state is a high-altitude prairie called the High Plains.

name: wyoming
sentence: Almost half of Wyoming's land is owned by the U.S. government, which led Wyoming to rank sixth by region and fifth by proportion of federal government land.

name: wyoming
sentence: Federal lands include two national parks, Grand Teton and Yellowstone, two national recreational areas, two national monuments, several national forests, historic sites, fish hatcheries and wildlife refuges.

name: wyoming
sentence: The first inhabitants of the region are Arapaho, Crow, Lakota and Shoshone.

name: wyoming
sentence: The south-west of Wyoming was claimed by the Spanish Empire and then as Mexican territory until it was ceded to the United States in 1848, at the end of the war between Mexico and America.

name: wyoming
sentence: The region acquired the name of "Wyoming" when a bill was introduced in Congress in 1865 to provide a temporary government for Wyoming territory.

name: wyoming
sentence: The name had been used earlier for the Wyoming Valley in Pennsylvania, and is derived from the word Munsee xwé:wam=nk, meaning "to the large flat river".

name: wyoming
sentence: The main drivers of Wyoming's economy are tourism and the extraction of minerals such as coal, oil, natural gas and trone.

name: wyoming
sentence: Agricultural products include livestock, hay, sugar beet, grain (wheat and barley), and wool.

name: wyoming
sentence: The climate is semi-arid and continental, drier and windier than in the rest of the country with higher extreme temperatures.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming has been a politically conservative state since the 1950s, with the Republican candidate holding the state in each presidential election since 1968.

name: wyoming
sentence: One of the most important is Teton County, which has achieved the notability of being Wyoming's most democratic county and which has not voted for a Republican since 2000.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's climate is generally semi-arid and continental (Köppen BSk climate classification), and is drier and more windy than most United States with higher extreme temperatures.

name: wyoming
sentence: This is largely due to topography of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: Summers in Wyoming are warm with high July temperatures averaged between 85 and 95°F (29 and 35°C) in most states.

name: wyoming
sentence: However, with increasing elevation, this average decreases rapidly with locations above 9,000 feet (2,700 m) on average around 70°F (21°C).

name: wyoming
sentence: Summer nights through the state are characterized by rapid cooling with even the warmest places on average in the range of 50 to 60°F (10 to 16°C) at night.

name: wyoming
sentence: Most precipitation in most of the state tends to fall in late spring and early summer.

name: wyoming
sentence: Winters are cold, but are variable with periods sometimes extremely cold interspersed between generally mild periods, with Chinook winds providing exceptionally hot temperatures in some places.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is a dry condition where most land receives less than 10 inches (250 mm) of rain per year.

name: wyoming
sentence: Precipitation depends on altitude with lower areas in the Big Horn Basin on average from 5 to 8 inches (130 to 200 mm) (which makes the area almost a real desert).

name: wyoming
sentence: The lower areas in the North and the eastern plains generally have an average of about 10 to 12 inches (250 to 300 mm), resulting in a semi-arid climate.

name: wyoming
sentence: Some mountain areas receive a good amount of precipitation, 20 inches (510 mm) or more, largely as snow, sometimes 200 inches (510 cm) or more per year.

name: wyoming
sentence: The highest temperature recorded by the State was 114°F (46°C) at Basin on 12 July 1900, and the lowest recorded temperature was -66°F (−54°C) at Riverside on 9 February 1933.

name: wyoming
sentence: The number of storm days varies from state to state, with the southeast plains having the most storm days.

name: wyoming
sentence: Thunderstorm activity in the state was highest in late spring and early summer.

name: wyoming
sentence: The southeastern corner of the State is the most vulnerable part of the State to tornado activity.

name: wyoming
sentence: By moving away from this point and to the west, the incidence of tornadoes decreases considerably with the western part of the state showing little vulnerability.

name: wyoming
sentence: The tornadoes, where they occur, tend to be small and brief, unlike some that occur more to the east.

name: wyoming
sentence: As specified in Wyoming Territory Designation Legislation, the Wyoming boundaries are 41°N and 45°N latitude lines and 104°3'W and 111°3'W (27 and 34 west of the Washington Meridian), a geodetic quadrangle.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is one of the only three states (the others being Colorado and Utah) to have borders defined only by "right" lines.

name: wyoming
sentence: Due to the inaccuracy of surveys during the 19th century, Wyoming's legal boundary deviates from the actual latitude and longitude lines up to half a mile (0.8 km) in some places, especially in the mountainous region along the 45th parallel.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is bordered to the north by Montana, to the east by South Dakota and Nebraska, to the south by Colorado, to the southwest by Utah, and to the west by Idaho.

sentence: The Wind River Indian Reserve is shared by the East Shoshone and Northern Amerindian Arapaho tribes in the central western part of the state near Lander.

sentence: Several Amerindian groups originally inhabited the area known as Wyoming.

name: wyoming
sentence: What is now the southwest of Wyoming became part of the Spanish Empire, then the Mexican territory of Alta California, until it was ceded to the United States in 1848 at the end of the war between Mexico and America.

name: wyoming
sentence: French-Canadian trappers from Quebec and Montreal ventured into the region at the end of the 18th century, leaving French toponyms such as Téton and La Ramie.

name: wyoming
sentence: John Colter, a member of Expedition Lewis and Clark, himself led by Toussaint Charbonneau, a French Canadian, and his young wife Shoshone, Sacagawea, first described the region in 1807.

name: wyoming
sentence: At the time, his accounts of the Yellowstone area were considered fictional.

sentence: Robert Stuart and a group of five men returning from Astoria discovered South Pass in 1812.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 1850 Jim Bridger located what is now known as Bridger Pass, which the Union Pacific Railroad used in 1868, as did Interstate 80, 90 years later.

name: wyoming
sentence: Bridger also explored Yellowstone and filed reports on the area, which, like Colter's, were widely regarded as great stories at the time.

name: wyoming
sentence: The region acquired Wyoming's name in 1865, when Ohio's representative James Mitchell Ashley introduced a bill to Congress to provide a "temporary government for Wyoming's territory."

name: wyoming
sentence: The territory was named after the Wyoming Valley in Pennsylvania, made famous by the poem Gertrude of Wyoming of 1809 by Thomas Campbell, based on the Battle of Wyoming in the American Revolution War.

name: wyoming
sentence: In the end, the name derives from the word Munsee xwé:wam=nk, meaning "to the great dish of the river".

sentence: The population of the area continued to grow after the Union Pacific railway reached Cheyenne in 1867, and the federal government established Wyoming on July 25, 1868.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming lacked significant gold and silver deposits, unlike the mineral-rich Colorado, and did not experience the boom of the associated Colorado population.

sentence: Once the government-sponsored expeditions to Yellowstone began, Colter and Bridger's reports, previously thought apocryphal, proved true.

sentence: On December 10, 1869, Governor of the Territory John Allen Campbell extended the right to vote to women, making Wyoming the first territory and, later, the State of the United States, granting women the right to vote.

name: wyoming
sentence: Women first served on juries at Wyoming (Laramie, 1870).

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming was the first female judicial officer (Mary Atkinson, Laramie, 1870) and the country's first female justice of the peace (Esther Hobart Morris, South Pass City, 1870).

name: wyoming
sentence: In 1924, Wyoming became the first state to elect a woman governor, Nellie Tayloe Ross, who took office in January 1925.

name: wyoming
sentence: Due to its history of civil rights, one of Wyoming's nicknames is "the state of equality" and the official motto of the state is "equal rights".

sentence: Wyoming's constitution included women's suffrage and a pioneering article on water rights.

sentence: The Constitution of Wyoming established three powers: executive, legislative and judicial.

sentence: The small population of Wyoming earned him only one seat in the House of Representatives of the United States and thus only three votes in the electoral college.

sentence: With the exception of wine, the law of the State prohibits the purchase of alcoholic beverages intended for resale from any other source.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's highest court is the Supreme Court of Wyoming, with five judges presiding over appeals from the lower courts of the state.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming is unusual as it does not have an intermediate court of appeal, like most states.

name: wyoming
sentence: This is largely due to the population of the State and the decrease in the corresponding workload.

name: wyoming
sentence: Appeals from State District Courts are brought directly before the Wyoming Supreme Court.

sentence: Wyoming also has state district courts (formerly county courts) with limited jurisdiction, which deal with certain types of cases, such as lower-value civil claims, criminal offences and criminal prosecution.

sentence: The judges of the travelling courts also hear low-value cases on a regular basis.

name: wyoming
sentence: Before 1972, Wyoming judges were chosen by popular vote on a non-partisan vote.

name: wyoming
sentence: This earlier system was criticized by the State Bar, which requested the adoption of the Missouri Plan, a system designed to balance the independence of the judiciary with judicial responsibility.

name: wyoming
sentence: In 1972, an amendment to article 5 of the Wyoming Constitution, which included an amended version of the plan, was adopted by voters.

name: wyoming
sentence: Since the adoption of the amendment, all judges of Wyoming State Courts have been appointed by the Judges Appointment Commission and appointed by the Governor.

name: wyoming
sentence: They shall then be subject to a retention vote by the electorate one year after their appointment.

name: wyoming
sentence: Wyoming's political history challenges an easy classification.

name: wyoming
sentence: The State had been the first to grant women the right to vote and to elect a woman governor.

name: wyoming
sentence: On December 10, 1869, John Allen Campbell, First Governor of Wyoming Territory, approved the first law in U.S. history explicitly granting women the right to vote.

name: wyoming

sentence: On 5 November 1889, voters approved the first constitution in the world which grants women the right to vote in their own right.

name: wyoming
sentence: While the state elected prominent democrats to the federal office in the 1960s and 1970s, politics became resolutely more conservative since the 1980s, when the Republican Party came to dominate the delegation of the State Congress.

sentence: Today Wyoming is represented in Washington by his two senators, John Barrasso and Cynthia Lummis, and his only member of the House of Representatives, Liz Cheney, MP.

sentence: The state has not voted for a democrat for a president since 1964, one of only eight times since the state's status.

sentence: In the 2004 presidential election, George W. Bush won his second victory with 69% of the vote.

name: wyoming

name: wyoming
sentence: They have been a majority in the Senate since 1936 and in the State House since 1964.

name: wyoming

sentence: The Republicans have a majority of registered votes in all but two counties: Albany and Teton, where they have a plurality of registered voters.
